PROCTEXT.PARA: Mr SPEAKER (Hon. Leo McLeay) took the chair at 10 a.m, and read prayers.

DEBATE.TITLE: MINISTER FOR THE ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Suspension of Standing and Sessional Orders

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That so much of the Standing and Sessional Orders be suspended as would prevent the member for Pearce moving forthwith:

`That this House calls on the Minister for Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories to comply with the resolution of the Senate of 10 September 1991 and to table forthwith in this House, and to have tabled in the Senate, the tape recording of discussions between her and conservation organisations on 4 September 1991'.

I move this motion because the Parliament is now in the situation where the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Mrs Kelly) has clearly demonstrated her contempt for the parliamentary processes. She has done that both in Question Time and in her response to the motion which was moved and carried in the Senate yesterday, in these terms:

That there be laid on the table, on or before 11 September 1991, the tape recording of the discussions held on or about 4 September 1991 between the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, the Honourable R.J. Kelly, MP, and representatives of conservationist groups.

The reported response of the Minister to that is that this is a political stunt and she will ignore it. That is a response which is contemptuous of the obligations of the Parliament and completely ignores the responsibility of the Minister to the Parliament.
This motion is permitted under the Standing Orders of the House of Representatives, which provide, under standing order 316:

Papers may be ordered to be laid before the House, and the Clerk shall communicate to the Minister concerned all orders for papers made by the House; and such papers when received shall be laid on the Table by the Clerk.

This motion for the suspension of Standing Orders to enable the moving of the substantive motion follows a series of questions put to the relevant Minister which she has, in the main, refused to answer. She has, however, been prepared to indicate that the reason she is not releasing the tape is `simply because I believe the meeting was a private one'. That is one of a number of answers given by the Minister in similar terms over the last two days.

The sole ground which is claimed by this Minister for not releasing this tape is not some ground of Executive privilege or some esoteric legal or constitutional defence; it is the simple ground that, in her view, the meeting was a private one and therefore the record of the discussions was private. The patent absurdity of that situation is quite evident from the situation where numerous participants in those discussions have been happy to come forward to give their version of what happened, and of course the Minister herself has come into the chamber, and has also appeared on television and in the print media, and been prepared to give a quite different version. The problem for this House is that the version being given by the Minister is quite different from the version given by all other participants in the discussion. Those participants have reaffirmed their view over recent days since the controversy has erupted.

We are in a situation, therefore, where there is only one ground for refusal of disclosure, and that is the ground of privacy. That ground is clearly absurd. Only last night we had a new participant in the discussion. A Ms Sue Jackson, from the Northern Territory Environment Centre, was interviewed on the ABC radio program PM. She was the latest person to make it clear that she had absolutely no objection to the removal of the restrictions on the tape. She said:
I don't see why there's any reason why it should be restricted.
So there is only one person who is denying the access to this tape, and that is Minister Kelly.

What is the possible reason for the Minister's objection? Of course, there is only one logical and coherent reason that can be given and that is that the Minister has misled both this House and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). We all know that the Minister was woken from her slumber on Saturday morning by a rather cross Prime Minister. We know that the Minister gave him an explanation which is consistent with the explanation she has given this House--it just happens to be inconsistent with the version which is given by every other participant in this transaction.

We have a situation where the weight of evidence is clearly against the Minister and the only possible reason for not producing this tape is that it will disclose the truth. I quoted yesterday from public comments made by people far from the political process. The Courier-Mail said that this could all be solved so simply. Really, this is one of those rare political issues where the simplicity is evident to all. We have conflicts of evidence coming from the Minister as against multiple witnesses and a very simple method of solving this, yet the Minister refuses on the grounds of privacy which clearly no longer exist.

However, a more serious question arises with respect to the role of the Prime Minister. The Prime Minister has so far supported his Minister. That is, of course, consistent with the craven lack of leadership which the Prime Minister has been showing now for many months. What we have is a Minister who is frightened to reveal the tape because it might show the truth, and a Prime Minister who is frightened to have the tape revealed because it might disclose the weakness of his own position. If, as the evidence clearly indicates, the Minister has not given us the truth, and if the situation is that she has been critical of the Prime Minister and one of his core policies, the truth is that the Prime Minister will be shown up again to be a weak leader--a man without the capacity to exert any discipline.

Look at the political context in which this is occurring. The sad fact is that the edited tape--which, eventually, after the Prime Minister's second thoughts, was made available to a member of the Prime Minister's staff--was probably edited by a staffer who had worked for the Prime Minister's challenger, the honourable member for Blaxland (Mr Keating). Who do we have as the so-called press secretary for the Minister for the Environment at the moment but the previous press secretary for the honourable member for Blaxland, the previous Treasurer.

TALK.START.PARA: —-He still works for her.
—-I am reminded by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition that he still works for her and it is a matter of public record that he is handling the media inquiries for the honourable member for Blaxland.

SPEECH.PARA: We have a situation where there is absolutely no reason of principle--no constitutional legal reason--why this matter should not be disclosed; we have a situation where important questions of Government policy have been challenged by one of the Ministers in the Government which is supposed to be actively upholding those policies; and we have a situation where she is refusing to divulge to this House the truth.

The evidence is available. The evidence could bring this matter of controversy to an end in a matter of minutes. It would require merely the playing of this tape recording. The Opposition says, therefore, that this motion that the Standing Orders should be suspended should be passed, and that the motion I have given notice of in which we call on the Minister to comply with the resolution of the Senate of 10 September and to table this tape recording, should be mirrored in this House and acted on forthwith.

There are, of course, numerous precedents for the tabling of documents under a motion passed in the other chamber. For many years the procedure has not been followed in this House. No doubt that relates to the fact that the Government has the numbers in this House, it tables what documents it wishes to without any resolutions and there are probably few opportunities for an opposition to get a motion of this sort carried.

I make the point that in the whole history of the use of this procedure by the other place there are only two occasions on which the Government has not complied with the order. In the examination that we have made there are at least 19 occasions on which the order of the Senate has been followed by compliance on the part of the Government. On each of the two occasions when compliance has not been agreed to by the Government, there have been weighty questions of law and constitutional principles which have been debated in that chamber.

In the case of the 1975 summonsing of public servants before the House there was a claim of Executive privilege which, of course, went to issues which were subsequently subsumed in an election in which the Government which refused to answer the questions was consumed in the holocaust.

When I was a member of the Fraser Government in 1982 and indicated that on the advice of the Solicitor-General and the Commissioner of Taxation a limited class of documents should not be disclosed because that would prejudice the prosecution of certain alleged offenders, there were important issues of principle involved. None of those issues arise here. This matter should be addressed by this House. We should not leave it to the Senate to be the only sensible legislative check on the Executive. The House of Representatives should assert its authority and on this occasion should show some commitment to principle, not to mere party politics.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Is the motion seconded?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fischer Mr T.A.

TALKER.NAME: Mr TIM FISCHER
TALKER.ROLE: -Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —-I second the motion and strongly support the excellent comments made by the honourable member for Pearce (Mr Chaney) today. I want to build on his point in relation to the precedents which exist for this motion in this House. No fewer than 12 precedents for this type of motion have been successfully carried over a period of years: 1921; 1931, on three occasions; 1943; 1965; 1967; 1968; 1975; 1982; 1984, on two occasions; 1987; 1988, on four occasions; and 1989.

SPEECH.PARA: In other words, this is a perfectly reasonable matter to be before the Parliament. It is a perfectly reasonable motion, for which we demand of the Government of this day that it produce a perfectly reasonable result: the truth--nothing more, nothing less--of the matter of whether the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Mrs Kelly) has misled the Parliament, whether the Minister has misled the people, and whether the Minister has misled the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in relation to this critically important matter.

There is a superior principle involved in this matter. As the honourable member for Pearce has demonstratively proved, the meeting is no longer a private meeting by any definition. In any event, the superior principle goes to the core of leadership of this Government and goes to the core of ministerial integrity and probity. It is clear that the only way this matter can be properly settled once and for all is for the tape and the partial transcript to be produced in the Senate and the House of Representatives so that we can all see it. I warn the Government and I warn the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley) that they will bleed and they will continue to bleed until such time as they produce this tape. The sooner they produce this tape, the better, so that we can focus on many related issues.

In terms of the issue of focus, this matter is related to the economy, to the million people unemployed and to the monumental drift of direction in this Government, because this issue is the epitome of what is wrong with this Government as it is paralysed and so deeply divided in terms of the Hawke versus Keating battle, in terms of where the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories stands in relation to that battle, and as to why the Prime Minister will not take the one step necessary to bring this to fruition and produce the tape and the transcript. Worse still, this Minister is an incompetent Minister for the Environment. It would be in the interests of the nation if the Prime Minister took that step. He would look good; he would have a fraction of the chance to get back on the rails if he took the one action that everyone is trying to convince him to take by virtue of this motion.

The Minister has been incompetent, as the honourable member for Pearce has pointed out, over many months in relation to Wesley Vale, Ravenshoe and Coronation Hill. It is not only my own colleagues who have pointed that out, but also Peter Cleeland, a former member of this place who, I affirmed yesterday, has launched a strong attack on this Minister in respect of her action over Coronation Hill. That has been backed up by the Minister for Resources (Mr Griffiths). The Minister for Resources actually had a majority of Cabinet to proceed with the mining of Coronation Hill. Yet so divided, paralysed and negative is its attitude and modus operandi that, sadly, we have reached this stand-off which requires, quite responsibly, the Parliament to address this motion in the House of Representatives this morning following the excellent resolution and decision of the Senate yesterday.

We want action on this matter. We want the matter tidied up quickly. It can be done in the course of just two minutes by producing that tape and producing the transcript which we know exists; it has been proven by the Prime Minister to exist. We want the Prime Minister to show the sort of leadership so badly needed at this time of critical economic circumstance for Australia and to take the action to order the Minister for the Environment to come into this chamber and produce that tape and transcript as quickly as possible.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —-To some extent it has to be conceded that there is a degree of expertise on the part of the honourable member who moved this motion on the subject of avoiding decisions of the Senate that material ought to be tabled. As I look through the record of what has actually been refused in the Senate from time to time by the government of the day when things have been tabled, the frequency with which the now honourable member for Pearce (Mr Chaney), the then Minister for Social Security, appears is manifest. Those occasions relate to issues of tax evasion, bottom of the harbour schemes and papers that were relevant to his handling of the situation in the Department at the time. They were weighty matters, but the government of the day refused to table them in the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: How can one contrast a situation here, in which one has a minor meeting taking place with members of the constituency, if you like, of the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Mrs Kelly), to what was the major scandal of the later years of the Fraser administration, when the Government militantly refused to accept repeated motions by the Senate on related matters? Motions were carried by the Senate that the Government subsequently refused to deal with.

TALK.START.PARA: —-This is absolutely ridiculous. I tabled a number of documents.
—-Order! The honourable member for Bennelong will resume his seat.

—-The honourable member for Bennelong may well have tabled an enormous number of documents. I know he tabled a telephone book's worth of his negligence during the administration of his Treasury portfolio.
—-You are misleading the House.
—-Order! The honourable member for Bennelong will cease interjecting.
—-There was an absolute telephone book of his negligence.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Howard interjecting--

TALK.START.PARA: —-I warn the honourable member for Bennelong.
—-When we get to a subject like this the Opposition is enormously unctuous. Let us go through one of those particular propositions after refusal. In December 1982 the Senate:

SPEECH.PARA: (a) notes the refusal by the Government, communicated in the Acting Prime Minister's letter of 15 December, to comply with the Senate's direction to produce, subject to independent editing, certain papers relating to the Government's administration of tax evasion and avoidance laws;

(b) notes that this refusal is not based on any claim of Executive privilege, which claim would clearly under established law and practice be a matter for the Senate itself to determine, but upon a new and unprecedented claim--possibly capable of judicial determination--that the Senate has no constitutional power to require the production of documents relating to the exercise by the Executive of its law enforcement functions;

(c) is of the opinion that there is no foundation whatever in constitutional law or convention for any such claim, and that--subject only to reasonable claims of Executive privilege--both Houses of Parliament are fully entitled to scrutinise and demand accountability for all aspects of Executive behaviour;

(d) is further of the opinion that this latest obstructive stance by the Government, when seen in the light of the persistent obstruction and evasion which has occurred since the Senate first insisted on the production of the documents in question on 23 September, is now ample demonstration of the fact that the Government has something to hide which the documents in question would clearly reveal, namely that the Fraser Government was culpably negligent in failing to proceed effectively against those involved in bottom-of-the- harbour and related tax avoidance and evasion schemes from 1976 on;--
and on it goes. Who was the responsible Minister of the Government in the Senate at the time? The honourable member for Pearce.

Is a meeting during which the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories is alleged to have said that she had a few grievances with the process of Commonwealth-State relations and environmental issues to be compared by the Opposition, with its unctuous moralising, with what was the major scandal during the latter years of the Fraser administration on the issue of tax avoidance, which members of the Opposition when in government ran away from in the Senate? This shows a double standard by those on the other side, which is truly breathtaking.

Let us get this whole darned episode into perspective. It is, of course, an episode in the politics and life of this nation which is of infinitesimal significance in comparison with the significance of the issue that those opposite ran away from in the Senate in those years. There is a Freedom of Information Act; if people want to pursue a freedom of information claim through the normal processes, let them get out there and do it. I understand that there has been a request. I was not aware that there had been a request from the honourable member for Pearce, but there has been a request from the media for a freedom of information release of the materials.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Will you release it?

—-Just wait; we will see what happens with the freedom of information proposals that the Opposition has put forward. Those opposite should go through the appropriate processes. After all, we have a Freedom of Information Act operating in this place which gives those opposite at least an opportunity to ask whether or not this ought to be received because we broadened the application of that Act in such a way that honourable members could conduct an argument on it. We introduced the broadening of that Act, and that is the reason why honourable members opposite have any opportunity at all, as opposed to the total absence of opportunity that was presented on those major tax evasion issues that were directly connected with the administration of the coalition Government. It was not some little meeting that took place with a few people who were interested in government policy on the environment; the issue on which the coalition Government refused the Senate on that particular occasion went to the heart of the administration of the tax law. Those opposite are bumbling hypocrites when it comes to this matter.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Chaney interjecting--

TALK.START.PARA: —-Order! The honourable member for Pearce will withdraw that remark.
—-I withdraw the remark, Mr Speaker.
—-The member for Pearce will resume his seat.
—-Mr Speaker, I ask you to listen to the interjections on the other side and apply the same principle.
—-The member for Pearce will resume his seat.

—-It is absolutely open to the Opposition to proceed with its FOI request. Those opposite can do that in the normal course of events. We are not going to release notes from, or tapes of, any particular set of meetings that the Government has with anyone who comes to visit it, irrespective of whether or not those people who are party to those meetings happen to----
—-Why should Nixon have released his tapes?
—-Why did those opposite not release their tax evasion stuff? They were called to release it; why did they not release it? That was criminal negligence.

SPEECH.PARA: Dr Catley interjecting--

TALK.START.PARA: —-Order! The member for Mayo will cease interjecting. The member for Adelaide will cease interjecting.
—-We are dealing here with an absolutely nothing issue.
—-What are you panic-stricken about?

—-I am not particularly panic-stricken about this matter. The honourable member raised this issue in the House; he came in here and put this thing up. Quite obviously, we are not running around asking questions about it in the House. We are not operating on a panic-stricken basis; we are simply inviting those opposite to take advantage of a law that is there and contest whether or not this material should be released.

SPEECH.PARA: I can tell those opposite that we, as a government, will not be in the business of going around releasing notes of meetings-- irrespective of the attitudes of particular parties to those meetings--that take place between ourselves and other members of the community, the electorate or whatever. We are not going to be in that business. I cannot imagine that those opposite would have ever been in the business of releasing that sort of detail when they were in office. It is simply cant and hypocrisy on their part for Opposition members to wander in here and say that they were.

This is a negligible issue as far as the issues of the environment are concerned. It is nowhere near as significant as the issues and questions that those opposite have to come to before they come clean about what they intend to do about the consumption tax and the whole plethora of other policy issues that they are confronted with in their presentation to the electorate. We are not interested in the Opposition's views on whether or not it wants to get access to meetings that we happen to hold with constituent groups. Those opposite can use the facilities available to them--

TALK.START.PARA: —-Will you grant the FOI?
—-Order! The honourable member for Higgins!

—-They can use the facilities available to them and other citizens--other members of the public--as far as that is concerned. As far as we are concerned, we do not see any particular case to answer with regard to this situation of the Senate's decision on the tapes. (Time expired)
—-Mr Speaker, I seek leave to make a personal explanation.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —-Order! The time for the debate has expired. When we have dealt with this matter, we will deal with the honourable member's personal explanation.

On that basis, and that basis only, a limited number of documents were withheld. That matter was substantially debated in the Senate on a number of occasions--14 October and 25 November were two of them. I direct to the attention of honourable members the existence of those debates, which set out very clearly the principal basis on which there was a withholding of information. There was no question of simply trying to cover up; there was simply a question of maintaining the integrity of the prosecution process.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 3 September, on motion by Mr Tickner:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wooldridge Dr M.R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The coalition supports the Aboriginal Education (Supplementary Assistance) Amendment Bill 1991. This underpins the Aboriginal education policy, about which I will speak briefly. This is a machinery Bill that has no contentious provisions. It transfers the higher education funding component into the Higher Education Funding Act, which means that higher education institutions will provide supplementary assistance to Aboriginal students out of the global budget. This would seem to make sense.

SPEECH.PARA: Prior to the introduction of an Aboriginal education policy, there was good evidence that 10 per cent to 15 per cent of Aboriginal students in the compulsory schooling years were not participating in primary and basic secondary schooling, despite the national expectation that all school age children would receive such schooling. Also, participation rates for Aboriginal people in post-compulsory schooling are only about one-third of the number for all other Australians.

These concerns led to the development of an Aboriginal education policy which came out of the Hughes report of 1988. This report found that, despite improvements over the past two decades, Aboriginal people remain the most educationally disadvantaged group in Australia. The need to develop a comprehensive and coordinated national education policy for Aboriginal people was a priority. Based on these findings, the Aboriginal education policy was developed. This involved agreement between the Commonwealth and all State and Territory governments, and it had the full support of all political parties.

The key consideration in establishing the Aboriginal education policy was to define the respective roles of the Commonwealth, State and Territory governments. The Commonwealth has adopted a strategic planning and monitoring role, and the operation and implementation role is largely the function of the States. I suggest that this is a model that could certainly be looked at in other areas of Aboriginal programs.

There are two main programs under the Aboriginal education policy: firstly, the Aboriginal education strategic initiative program; and, secondly, Abstudy direct assistance. The Aboriginal education strategic initiative program funds operational plans, the Aboriginal student support and parents awareness program, and Aboriginal language initiatives. It includes supplementary funding for Aboriginal education strategies of higher education institutions, which has now been transferred. Abstudy direct assistance incorporates non-income support elements of Abstudy. It has two programs consisting of the Aboriginal tutorial assistance scheme and the vocational educational guidance for Aboriginals scheme.

As I said, this policy is quite new. There would appear to be some very obvious strengths in it. There is agreement among all levels of government, with the Commonwealth playing a strategic, planning and monitoring role and the States working on implementation. It is a strength that such a policy works on the basis of agreed goals. It has a high degree of Aboriginal input into decision making, and it works on a triennial basis, which gives it a high degree of predictability and planning.

The year 1990 was the first year of the triennium of operation. A review will take place in the first year of the Aboriginal tutorial assistance scheme. This year, 1991, is the first year of the vocational educational guidance for Aboriginals scheme. We are at a stage where it is not possible to fully assess the effectiveness of this scheme.

I perceive some areas of weakness that I would foreshadow. Firstly, the information coming back to the Federal Government, which is largely dependent upon the States for that information, indicates that the scheme appears to have been slow. Certainly, the Commonwealth's early monitoring of this scheme is not adequate. However, that may be overcome as the scheme gets over its early problems. Secondly, the Aboriginal tutorial assistance scheme, while a very good scheme in concept, works on the basis of establishing a large number of Aboriginal homework centres. This in itself is not a bad thing, given the home conditions under which many Aboriginal students try to work. It is very important that Aborigines have a place to do their homework.

I query the need to establish separate centres rather than looking at the further extension of already existing schools. I suspect this might have more to do with the policy of the teacher unions than with efficient delivery of services to Aboriginal people.

While this program does not relate directly to Abstudy, Abstudy is fundamental to Aboriginal education, and I have very great concerns that there is a very lax definition of Aboriginality for Abstudy payments. This has been raised by the Auditor-General. It is very easy to get an exact idea of the number of Aboriginal people in Australia because the definition of Aboriginality refers to `a person who identifies with an Aboriginal com- munity'. Those people who were sufficiently identified to put themselves down on the 1986 census can then be determined and predicted today with known mortality rates. If we look at this and then look at the take-up of Abstudy, we find that 72 per cent of all Aboriginal people between 12 and 18 years of age are getting some form of Abstudy, and that of those between 12 and 44 years of age more than one-third of every predicted Aboriginal person in Australia is receiving Abstudy. Clearly, not more than a third of all Aboriginal people between 12 and 44 years of age are getting some sort of higher education.

Aboriginal education is not an easy area. This was brought home to me very early on after taking this job when I visited a small school at a place called Ipolera in the Northern Territory. Ipolera is an out-station west of Alice Springs, and the two senior Aboriginal people there are Herman and Mavis Malbunka. They have a small school on that out-station which I visited. There were 15 students there, not one of whom spoke any sort of acceptable English; their language is Aranda. The newly arrived teacher had come from Newport Primary School in Melbourne. She did not speak any Aranda, the kids did not speak any English and so there was a rather wonderful chaos in the entire school.

This happens very much in remote Australia and is the reason language initiatives are so important. We assume that English is spoken widely around the country, but probably 10 per cent of Aboriginal people in Australia would not use English in the home. For many people English is not a second language, it is totally a foreign language. This is why it is so difficult for students coming into schools; they may have no working knowledge of English and a program entirely in English is irrelevant to their needs. The Northern Territory has been particularly innovative in this area and by far leads all the other States in Australia.

Good educational opportunities are fundamental to Aboriginal people having the opportunity to be full participants in Australian society. This was put very well by Charles Perkins in Alice Springs two weeks ago, when talking about education. Charles Perkins was the first Aboriginal Australian to graduate from university. That it was 1965 before any Aboriginal Australian did so is a shame that I believe we all wear. He said:

This has not received the focus it justifiably demands. It has been our greatest "blind spot" over the years in not realising the vital element of good education. We have usually left this to others or we have let our academic Aborigines tinker at the fringes with the Federal Government. . . The reality is we are in the majority, unskilled and uneducated, and as such, at the mercy of governments, bureaucrats, pathetic politics and the rise and fall of the economy.

We have in the Aboriginal education policy a goal driven cooperative policy that works on the basis of determining the respective roles of Commonwealth and State governments, with clear and agreed goals. It is for these reasons that the coalition continues to support this policy and supports this Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Snowdon The Hon W.E.

TALKER.NAME: Mr SNOWDON
TALKER.ROLE: - Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport and Communications)

TALK.START.PARA: —-It gives me pleasure to speak in this debate on the Aboriginal Education (Supplementary Assistance) Bill for a number of reasons, not the least of which is being able to follow the honourable member for Chisholm (Dr Wooldridge) and pick up on a couple of remarks which he has made. I will do that in the course of my contribution. I will certainly pick up on those remarks which relate to the cooperative nature of the relationship which we are supposed to have between the Commonwealth, the Northern Territory and the State governments. In my view, it has not been as successful as it ought, primarily because of the tardiness of the State and Territory governments, and I will allude particularly to the Northern Territory Government, whose efforts, in my view, have been less than satisfactory.

SPEECH.PARA: The amendments to this legislation are minor and relate to clarification of the indexation clause of the Act; amending the amounts appropriated in the 1991 and 1992 calendar years to reflect the transfer of the higher education component of the Aboriginal education strategic initiatives program, AESIP, to the Higher Education Funding Act; adjusting the amount appropriated under the special appropriation for the 1992 calendar year to reflect the transfer of the Aboriginal student support and parent awareness scheme, ASSPA, from the principal Act to Appropriation Bill (No. 1); and adjusting the amount appropriated under the special appropriation for the 1992 calendar year to reflect the transfer of funds formally allocated to the national Aborigines language program, NALP, from the principal Act to the Appropriation Bill.

In his second reading speech on the Bill, the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Tickner) noted the changes were minor and of an administrative nature. However, he also noted that the passage of the amendments also afforded an opportunity for the Parliament to give a commitment of support to the principles and practices of the Aboriginal education policy as a means of addressing the educational needs of Aboriginal Australians. It is the Aboriginal Education (Supplementary Assistance) Act which provides a legislative basis for the national Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander education policy, commonly referred to as AEP.

The AEP is a national policy. It is a policy which has received the agreement and endorsement of the Commonwealth and all State and Territory governments. It is an attempt to coordinate the efforts of all levels of government and non-government bodies to deliver educational services and to meet the educational needs of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people throughout Australia. It is this matter of coordination and cooperation between the Commonwealth and other levels of government and, in particular, the Northern Territory Government, to which I now turn.

Coordination is a matter of identifying common goals agreed upon through a process of discussion, formal consultation and negotiation between governments, and then implementing programs to achieve these goals. But when it comes to the Northern Territory Government I am afraid that coordination and cooperation are sadly lacking, for it appears that the attitude of the Northern Territory Government to the Aboriginal education policy is to present a facade of living up to the letter of its agreement with the Commonwealth while disregarding the spirit of that agreement, ensuring that it does not put one ounce of effort into addressing the educational needs of Aboriginal people over and above that specifically required under the agreement--and even that is questionable.

In the calendar year 1991, the Northern Territory Government is receiving some $10.6m from the Commonwealth under the Aboriginal education policy. That is money given to the Northern Territory Government in addition to normal allocations. It is money specifically aimed at achieving the agreed goals of the Aboriginal education policy through implementing a strategic plan formulated through discussion, consultation and negotiation with the Northern Territory Government. It is part of the agreement with the Northern Territory Government that none of the Territory's own expenditure in the area of Aboriginal education will be diminished as a result of the Aboriginal education policy.

Since the beginning of the first triennium of the Aboriginal education policy, and since the agreement of a strategic plan between the Commonwealth and the Territory to tackle issues confronting Aboriginal people in the area of education, there have been two significant developments. The first is the implementation of the Northern Territory Government's policy of devolution. The second is a wide range of cuts to the Northern Territory's badly managed Budget announced earlier this year as a result of an Expenditure Review Committee process.

Under devolution, school councils are compelled to accept responsibility for the day- to-day administration and policy development of their schools. If the councils decide, for whatever reason, that they do not want to assume that role, then the principal of the school will be compelled to take on that job. Devolution involves such work as administering the budget for the school, ensuring maintenance, new capital works, relief and ancillary staffing, purchasing and so on. It is an onerous load for an unpaid parents council. It is an onerous load for councils where there is a very sophisticated non-Aboriginal population with a high level of education and a high level of participation in school councils because it requires accounting expertise, public administration expertise, management expertise, industrial relations expertise and purchasing expertise--skills which in many respects one does not find in small communities. They are skills which require specialised knowledge, yet they are skills which the Northern Territory Government expects small Aboriginal communities to own.

It is indeed an onerous task, and an onerous load for unpaid parents councils. It is true that some parents councils will seek this load, but it is also true that there are many community councils and many communities in the Northern Territory which do not have the expertise and would, if the choice were available to them, revert to another situation in terms of the administration of these functions.

It demands an enormous commitment of time and the existence and development of a high level of skills, as I have said, particularly in the area of administration. Under the Aboriginal education policy there were to be more community liaison officers, there was to be assistance in setting up Aboriginal school councils and greater involvement in teacher selection, and so on. But under the Northern Territory Government's devolution proposal, any parents coming into a school will find themselves totally overtaken by the administrative matters thrown up by a purely European tradition of education and administration. Where they do not take on that responsibility--and I could hardly blame people for not doing so because of the daunting tasks that confront them--they will lose total control to the principal.

What does that say about devolution of responsibility? What more does it say about the intent of the Northern Territory community's aspirations in relation to education and its management? The Aboriginal education policy is attempting to give Aboriginal people a real say in how the schools are run. The devolution package put up by the Northern Territory Government aims to weigh down any parent game enough to give it a go. For those parents who are game enough to give it a go, all power to them.

It is a goal of the Aboriginal education policy to increase the number of Aboriginal people employed as teachers, administrators, liaison officers and so on. As I have said, it is a fine goal, but the reality is that the Northern Territory Government's ERC cuts have reduced the number of positions in schools. The effect at, say, Yirrkala is that, when the 19 students currently studying for their teaching qualifications at Batchelor College have completed their training, there will be only 14 jobs. Positions such as assistant teachers, linguists and literacy workers have all been cut as part of this Northern Territory Expenditure Review Committee's proposals. So the chances of greater Aboriginal involvement, as envisaged under the AEP, are being eroded by the Northern Territory Government's policy decisions and administrative practices.

As part of the Northern Territory Government's ERC processes, certain schools were earmarked for closure--six in all. I do not think it would fail to surprise honourable members that two of these have a very high Aboriginal enrolment. One, the Traeger Park school in Alice Springs, has achieved Australia-wide acclaim for its work in language development. Student-teacher ratios in bush schools have been increased and education officer and resource teacher positions for remote communities and out-stations have been abolished.

Let me give a stark example of the pathetic level of the Northern Territory CLP Government's commitment to Aboriginal education. It is a well-acknowledged fact that chronic otitis media--that is, middle ear disease--is prevalent among Aboriginal children in Australia, particularly in the bush. Research indicates that in the Northern Territory some 75 to 80 per cent of Aboriginal students suffer some form of hearing loss. At least 50 per cent of students outside the main towns will suffer some educationally significant hearing loss during their school life. The AEP recognises this fact. Under the Northern Territory strategic plan for the AEP it was set down as a goal:
To increase the level of special education assistance to students with health problems that impair hearing . . .

The reality is that in the East Arnhem region, under the Northern Territory Government's ERC processes, the position of adviser to teachers of hearing impaired students has been abolished. Some 75 to 80 per cent of Aboriginal students suffer from some form of hearing loss. Hearing problem assessors say that, with classroom acoustics, teaching in front of a class of Aboriginal students with hearing impairments is like trying to teach `in front of a running Mack truck while the kids are wearing earmuffs'.

What we are talking about is restricting the ability of young Aboriginal people to acquire an education because of ridiculous and stupid decisions made by the Northern Territory Government in relation to Aboriginal education--decisions which it need not have made, but which it has chosen to make and decisions which will palpably damage the educational opportunities of Aboriginal people in the Northern Territory.

Frankly, I am totally appalled at the failure of the CLP in the Northern Territory to deliver quality educational services to the entire population. In recent months my office has received representations from educators, parents and students from all over the Northern Territory. A few weeks ago I sat with a group of educators in the East Arnhem region who were expressing their disgust with the Northern Territory Government's practices--particularly those in relation to the Aboriginal education policy; the subsequent imposition of devolution; and the Estimates review cuts. I have received similar representations from Yuendumu, Hermannsburg, Elliot, Katherine, Tennant Creek, the Barkly region, the West Arnhem region, the Victoria River region--you name it.

People from those areas expressed their valid concerns about the state of Aboriginal education and the Northern Territory Government's commitment to this cooperative arrangement which it signed with this Commonwealth Government about the funding and future of Aboriginal education in the Northern Territory. It is of extreme importance that the Northern Territory Government live up to its responsibilities--accept its responsibilities--and acknowledge that it has not done the right thing.

In terms of the Traeger Park school, let me point out that this school is situated in Alice Springs. In excess of 90 per cent of the school population is Aboriginal. There was absolutely not one dot of consultation with the school community about the future of that school. The Northern Territory Minister responsible refused, at one point, to meet with a representative body from that school. He was not even prepared to countenance a change in Government policy.

It is not as if there are alternative arrangements. It has become clear, as parents of these students have said, that they are concerned that with the closure of the school their children simply will not go to school. That ought to be a problem. It is a problem, but one which is not being faced up to by the Northern Territory Government. It emphasises the Northern Territory Government's extreme lack of commitment to this AEP arrangement with the Commonwealth Government.

This is not the only area. I note that the shadow Minister spoke glowingly about the importance of this cooperative arrangement. Well, it is important and it is the way ahead, but cooperative arrangements work only if both sides stick to the bargain. The problem I have is that I doubt that the Northern Territory Government is sticking to the bargain--certainly not to the spirit of the agreement which has been made--not only in the area of school education but also in the area of post-school education.

We noted that the shadow Minister talked about Aboriginal graduates. The Northern Territory has a very fine institution which I have praised in the past and I acknowledge here in this House. Batchelor College is a very fine institution. It provides a model for how we can develop higher education programs for Aboriginal people in this country, and it ought to be seen as a model which can be used for that purpose.

The difficulty is that the Northern Territory Government, again, signed an agreement with this Government about triennial funding for Batchelor College and has, basically, withdrawn from that agreement. We are left in a situation where Batchelor College, assured of triennial funding from this Government-- guaranteed by agreement with the Northern Territory Government that it would get support from the Northern Territory Government--is now being told by the Northern Territory Government not to expect funding for certain courses in the next financial year.

What does that mean for Aboriginal education and the Northern Territory Government's commitment to it in the Northern Territory? It is similar to its commitment to Aboriginal living areas. While it is not the time in this debate to raise that issue, it is worth pointing out the discriminatory way in which Aboriginal people are treated by the Northern Territory Government. It is something which needs to be acknowledged not only by all the people in this House but also by the Northern Territory Government. It has shown that it is totally incapable of accepting the responsibility of governing in a proper way--good government for the whole population of the Northern Territory, not a selected few.

It has demonstrated time and time again that it cannot be trusted. It has demonstrated time and time again that it is prepared actively to oppose the interests of Aboriginal people in the area of education. It has treated with absolute contempt the advice of Aboriginal educators--teachers. I note the sly swipe that was made at teachers unions by the honourable member for Chisholm (Dr Wooldridge)--something which he should retract. The fact of the matter is that, without the dedication of these teachers in the Northern Territory and without their commitment and without their diligence, there would be absolutely no merit in acknowledging the support of this House for Aboriginal education because without those teachers there would be no Aboriginal education.

If we are to go ahead in this area--and I acknowledge the commitment of the honourable member for Chisholm to Aboriginal education--and put ourselves in a situation where we can proudly say, at the end of this triennial period when this agreement will be renewed, that everyone has done their job, then it is up to the Northern Territory Government to live up to its commitment. It has not lived up to its commitments. At the very least, it should show that it is prepared to rethink the absurd proposition of closing Traeger Park school. Propositions have been put to it about alternatives, but it has refused to acknowledge the legitimacy of those proposals.

It has been left to the school community in a very public way to fight the Northern Territory Government in this area. I acknowledge the work of Mervyn Franey and other people who are associated with the movement to maintain Traeger Park school in Alice Springs--Harold Ferber, who is now studying here in Canberra; Jeannie Egan from Yuendumu; and Mundawuy Yunupingu, an Aboriginal principal at Yirrkala in Eastern Arnhem Land, a very important person in his own culture and community, a headmaster of a school and a person who has indicated, through his school community and through the community at Yirrkala, abject opposition to the propositions which have been put forward by the Northern Territory Government in relation to the ERC cuts in Aboriginal education.

We have to look very carefully at what fronts up as an agreement with the Northern Territory Government. We have to reconcile ourselves to the fact that at the moment it is not doing its job properly--it is not pulling its weight. It has to pull its weight if we are to be successful in reaching our goals in Aboriginal education, employment and training. I commend the legislation to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Taylor Mr W.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —- Before I address the Aboriginal Education (Supplementary Assistance) Amendment Bill 1991 I wish to say to the honourable member for the Northern Territory (Mr Snowdon) that I agree with him that one aspect of Aboriginal education that needs to be addressed is this cooperative aspect. Whilst I understand what he is saying about the Northern Territory, I am sure that my colleague in the other place Senator Tambling would have something specifically to say about that when this legislation gets to that other place.

SPEECH.PARA: I would also say to the honourable member that his comments are not restricted to the Northern Territory. We find that the same problem exists with the Labor Government in the State of Queensland. It is not simply a question of the non-Labor side of politics wanting to drag the chain when it comes to Aboriginal education policy or Aboriginal policy in general--that also happens in some other States.

Before I address the specifics of the legislation, I congratulate the Minister at the table, the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Tickner), on his foresight in his public comments yesterday in relation to Aboriginal land rights and nickel mining at Yackabindie. I also congratulate him on his public statements that the Commonwealth will not be intervening in that very important project for the State of Western Australia. I have to be somewhat cynical, however, and make the point that I only wish that his attitude had been similar when it came to Coronation Hill. It leads one to ask the basic question as to whether the power of Bula is much stronger than the carpet snake and the dragonfly, which are very much part of the Yackabindie project.

Very few reasonable people could argue that our Aboriginal people are not disadvantaged to a greater degree than most Australians. The issues of unemployment, education, housing and health are central to the reversal of the Aboriginals' unfortunate lot in our society today. All of that will take time. However, it seems to me that time is fast running out if we are to make real progress in this particular area. They are some of the comments I made in this place on 5 June in the very important debate on the Aboriginal Reconciliation Bill. I reiterate those comments here this morning.

In the Minister's second reading speech to this Bill he said that it will not appropriate any additional funds and that the amendments to the amounts appropriated under the principal Act also reflect Budget neutral transfers between the special appropriation and the annual Appropriation Bills. I support him on that. He also went on to say that the central features of the Aboriginal education program, to which the honourable member for the Northern Territory referred, will remain the same. With the indulgence of the House, I refer to the policy document of October 1989 in relation to Aboriginal education policy, which said in part:
Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders are the indigenous peoples of Australia. Their distinctive cultures are a rich and important part of the nation's living heritage.

The historically-developed education processes of Aboriginal culture have been eroded in many communities for a variety of reasons. The education arrangements and procedures established from non-Aboriginal traditions have not adequately recognised and accommodated the particular needs and circumstances of Aboriginal people.
Not only have Aboriginal people been consequently disadvantaged, but Australian society generally has not come to understand and appreciate the significance of Aboriginal culture.

The Australian Government is a signatory to several international covenants recognising international standards for the protection of universal human rights and fundamental freedoms. These include the International Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Racial Discrimination and the Universal Declaration of Human Rights and the International Covenants on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights and Civil and Political Rights.
It goes on to say that education is fundamental in enabling Aboriginal people to exercise their rights and participate fully in Australian society.

In the time available to me, I would like to explore a little of the genesis of that policy. I go back to 1985, when the House of Representatives Select Committee on Aboriginal Education reported and made a number of findings and recommendations in relation to education in the Aboriginal community. The report found that absenteeism from secondary schools amongst Aboriginals was very high--as much as 70 per cent in some schools--and was not confined to Aboriginal- only schools. Secondary retention rates were poor, although improving. The retention rate for year 12 students increased from 7.5 per cent in 1979 to 9.9 per cent in 1982 and 13.1 per cent in 1984. The most recent estimate puts that rate at 22 per cent in 1988. That is in contrast to the general year 12 retention rate in 1988 of 57 per cent. The same general trends have been seen in post-secondary education.

That report in 1985 also found that Aboriginals lacked equality in educational opportunities and outcomes and noted the difficulties due to the Commonwealth's having responsibility for Aboriginal people and the States having responsibility for education, and the different views of the States and the Commonwealth on Aboriginal education referred to earlier by the honourable member for the Northern Territory.

The report also found that a major problem was lack of coordination in Aboriginal education. The recommended approach was that the Commonwealth rationalise its agencies before assuming a greater responsibility for the coordination and funding of Aboriginal education.

After a number of studies in 1985, 1986 and 1987, in 1988 the Commonwealth established an Aboriginal education policy task force to draw together the main findings of numerous reports over a period of three or four years with a view to developing a comprehensive long term approach to Aboriginal education policy. In July 1988 that task force found that Aboriginal people remain the most educationally disadvantaged group in Australia. The task force made specific recommendations about the need to develop a national Aboriginal education policy to redress the educational inequalities faced by those people. In part, it said:

Australians take it for granted, as an inalienable right of citizens in this country, that their children will receive at least 10 years of education, as well as the benefits of early childhood education. However, these fundamental rights have not been extended to all Aboriginal families. This is clearly demonstrated by the fact that in the compulsory school years, 1 in 8 Aboriginal children aged 5 to 9 years do not go to school or pre-school, and for those aged 10 to 15 years an appalling 1 in 6 do not have access to appropriate schooling. Moreover, access to and participation in education for Aborigines beyond the age of 15, whether in senior secondary school, technical and further education or higher education, remains at unacceptably low levels--generally at rates some 3 to 5 times lower than for the community as a whole.

The task force called for the development of a national policy to achieve broad equity between Aboriginal people and other Australians in access, participation and outcomes in all forms of education by the turn of the century. The task force stated that a new approach to Aboriginal education can succeed only if Aboriginals are fully involved in determining the policies and programs that are intended to provide appropriate education for their community.

In October 1988 the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) announced that the national Aboriginal education policy would be developed in conjunction with the States and Territories. This was developed over the calendar year 1989 and was tabled in this place in October of that year. The long term goals of that policy were outlined in the document I referred to earlier in this speech and include such things as increasing the involvement of Aboriginal people in educational decision making, ensuring equality of access to educational services, achieving equity of educational participation and enabling equitable and appropriate educational outcomes.

That education policy commenced on 1 January 1990 and embraces a number of programs referred to earlier by the honourable member for Chisholm (Dr Wooldridge), including the Aboriginal education strategic initiatives program, the Aboriginal student support and parent awareness program, the Aboriginal tutorial assistance scheme and, finally, the vocational educational guidance for Aboriginals scheme. As the honourable member for Chisholm said, two of those programs have been changed or amended in the context of the legislation before us this morning. That policy has been endorsed by all the governments of Australia and is financially underpinned by legislation in the form of the Aboriginal Education (Supplementary Assistance) Act 1989, the principal Act, which appropriated just under $240m in the triennium 1990 to 1992.

I refer to a couple of other recent reports which have been tabled in this place. The policy information paper on Australian language and literacy policy, released by the Minister for Employment, Education and Training only last month, stated, in part:

Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people have a particular need for more English language and literacy assistance. In the last census more than 5 per cent of Aboriginal Australians reported having little or no competency in English, and most Aboriginal adults have had little access to post- school training opportunities.
The Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody also referred, in part, to that same policy:

The utmost respect can be paid to the first long- term goal expressed in the policy, that is to establish effective arrangements for the participation of Aboriginal parents and community members in decisions regarding the planning, the delivery and the evaluation of pre-school, primary and secondary education services for their children . . and that it be recognised that the aims of that same policy are not only to achieve equity in education of Aboriginal people, but also to achieve strengthening of Aboriginal identity, their decision-making and their self-determination.

I conclude my contribution to this debate by again referring to the policy document and to a very important comment. It refers to the need for an Aboriginal education policy and says that that need arises from a number of factors:
. long-expressed educational aspirations of Aboriginal people that have as yet not been realised;
. persisting low levels of educational participation and attainment of Aboriginal people;
. deficiencies in the provision and quality of educational services for Aboriginal people;
. the joint responsibilities of the governments of the States and Territories and the Commonwealth for the provision of educational services for Aboriginal people;
. inadequate coordination--
which we have heard about before--
between State and Territory and Commonwealth, and non-government, education providers in respect of policies and programs for Aboriginal education;
a shared understanding--
a very important thing--
that most of the current deficiencies can be rectified--though not by any one government acting alone, and not immediately; but only through cooperative, long-term strategies.

Australians generally expect that policies and programs will be developed by the governments of the Commonwealth and the States and Territories, to overcome the economic and social disadvantages of Aboriginal Australians, help them to maintain their distinctive cultures, and enable them to achieve full recognition and status within the nation.

The need for a national policy to improve educational opportunities and outcomes for Aboriginal people is predicated upon the principles of social justice, equity, economic efficiency and cost-effective service delivery. It is also based upon the acceptance and valuing of cultural diversity.
It is with a great deal of pleasure that I support the legislation before us.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gibson Mr G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I appreciate the opportunity to speak on this Aboriginal Education (Supplementary Assistance) Amendment Bill 1991. I am also pleased to follow the honourable member for Groom (Mr Taylor). I certainly fully support his comments regarding the importance of the national Aboriginal education policy.

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill is a minor technical Bill in that it principally transfers funds from the principal Act, the Aboriginal Education (Supplementary Assistance) Act, to the Higher Education Funding Act and makes some changes to ASSPA and the national Aboriginal language program. However, it gives me an opportunity to speak a little about the national Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander education policy and to offer my full support for that. It is also an excellent opportunity for this House to confirm its support for that policy.

I want to make my contribution on a bit more of a personal level, probably having been one of the few people in this place who have actually taught in an Aboriginal community. My own experiences there have very much shaped my attitude towards Aboriginal issues, education issues and Aboriginal education issues. In fact, it would not be unreasonable to say that my experiences in the two years I spent at Yarrabah Aboriginal community shaped my desire to be more involved in the politics of administration of Aboriginal affairs and Aboriginal education in particular, because I started my teaching career straight out of university and teachers college at Yarrabah. It was my first experience as a teacher; it was certainly a very rewarding and interesting experience, and it was one that has certainly influenced my approach to Aboriginal education. I think the experience that I had as a brand new, very green teacher coming straight out of teachers college and going to a community some 1,800 kilometres away from my home, was one that has been faced by many hundreds and probably thousands of other teachers, but it is one of the problems we have had in Aboriginal education and it is one of the things that I am hopeful that the national Aboriginal education policy will rectify over time.

I had had very little experience with Aboriginal people and particularly with Aboriginal education. That was demonstrated in my first few fumbling months in front of the classroom there, because I really was having a great deal of difficulty. When I went to Yarrabah I knew absolutely nothing about the Yarrabah community, except that it was near Cairns. In fact, when I rang up the Education Department and said, `Look, I have been appointed to Yarrabah; where is it?', the people there said, `We are not really sure; we think it is on an island somewhere off the coast'. I said, `How am I supposed to get to this island off the coast?'. They said, `We think there is a barge once a week and you are supposed to go over and stay there'. I thought then that it was going to be very interesting.

I found out that my parents had friends in Cairns and I rang them up and said, `Where is Yarrabah?'. They said, `It is just a drive, 20 minutes away'. I said, `Is it on an island?'. They said, `No, it is not on an island at all'. That demonstrated to me the treatment that Aboriginal education, and an important Aboriginal community, received within the Education Department. I did not have to go by barge, of which I was most appreciative; in fact I was able to live in Cairns because my new wife at that time was starting to teach at Cairns High. When I turned up at Yarrabah I was one of five first-year teachers, and of the staff of 13 teachers at Yarrabah there were five first-years, four second-years, three third- years and one person who had taught for about 10 years. But 12 of the 13 people had three years or less teaching experience, and I think that was a great shame--not that young people starting out in teaching do not have a lot to offer, but in any school it is important for the successful delivery of education programs to have a good balance between new teachers and experienced teachers.

That experience at Yarrabah was unfortunately reflected on many Aboriginal communities through Queensland and probably many Aboriginal communities in other areas such as Western Australia and the Northern Territory. It exemplifies the fact that for too long the needs of Aboriginal people in the education field have been ignored, and the importance of education to Aboriginal people has also been largely ignored.

I think that fact has been exemplified by the figures which have been printed in the booklet on the national Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander education policy. That was one of the reasons why we developed this policy in the first place. I would like to cite some of these figures. They are based on the 1990 situation, and I think they have probably improved from when I was teaching in Yarrabah in 1977-78. The figures show that fewer than 50 per cent of Aboriginal children have had some pre-schooling experience, compared with a national equivalent rate of more than 90 per cent. Some 30 per cent of those aged 16 and 17 years are participating in education or formal training, compared with a national equivalent rate of 75 per cent. That shows that we have a very poor retention rate for Aboriginal students, compared with non-Aboriginal students in Australia. Some 7 per cent of those people aged 18 to 20 years are participating in education or formal training, compared with a national equivalent rate exceeding 40 per cent.

The figures keep getting worse and worse. Eleven per cent of all Aboriginal people aged 15 years and over have never attended a school; and 10 per cent of the Aboriginal population aged 15 years and over have post- school educational qualifications, compared with a national proportion of 31 per cent. It is those types of figures, which we still have in 1991, that exemplify the longstanding neglect of Aboriginal education that has been shown up through the various reports and task forces that have been mentioned previously in the contributions this morning and which were the basis of the national Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander education policy.

I hope that, through this policy State governments such as the Queensland Government will come a long way in their approach to Aboriginal education. I would hate to think we still have situations where Aboriginal schools are staffed nine-tenths with first or second year teachers, compared with the average in most other schools where there are three or four teachers beginning their training and a balanced mix of experienced teachers who can provide a stronger foundation for the education program in that school.

The national Aboriginal education policy was developed by the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) when he was the Minister responsible for Aboriginal education. It is a cooperative effort to address the educational needs of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people by focussing on the educational strategies of the Commonwealth, States and Territories, non- government education authorities and educational institutions in achieving agreed national goals. It was one of the first instances where the Commonwealth, States and Territories sat down and actually tried to develop a national approach to a problem; and they succeeded. They developed a very good national approach. It is that success that I think has laid the foundations for other initiatives in other areas which are now a part of the Federal-State relations program.

I certainly agree with my colleague the honourable member for the Northern Territory (Mr Snowdon) in saying that when we sit down and develop these national goals and say that these are the ways we wish to go as a nation--with the States, Territories and the Commonwealth working together to achieve these established goals--it is a two-edged sword. We all have to agree and we have to stick with our decisions. I am disappointed to hear from the honourable member for the Northern Territory that decisions are being made by the Northern Territory Government to cut back significantly on some successful education programs that are occurring, particularly in Aboriginal schools.

One of the other strengths that has come through the national Aboriginal education policy is the importance of involvement by the Aboriginal community in the delivery of education services to Aboriginal people in their community. That is the rock upon which this policy is founded. I quote from the national Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander education policy joint policy statement which says:

The fundamental purpose of the National Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Education Policy is to develop appropriate ways of responding effectively and sensitively to the educational needs and aspirations of Aboriginal people. This requires an holistic approach, under the guidance of Aboriginal people, to achieve educational equity while accommodating cultural difference and recognising socio-economic disadvantage.

That goes to the very reason why almost all Commonwealth, State and Territory educational programs affecting Aboriginal people have basically failed up until this point in time and why, if we are to have any chance of succeeding with the national Aboriginal education policy, that community involvement--that involvement by Aboriginal people themselves in the running of their schools, the determination of curriculum and structures, and also the involvement of Aboriginal people as teachers--is fundamental to any chance of success of education for Aboriginal people.

If one looks at the successful examples where Aboriginal communities have been involved in the running of their schools, it proves the very essence of that statement by the national Aboriginal education policy. Since I have come to this place I have been involved in both the Standing Committee on Aboriginal Affairs and the Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training. In my work with the Aboriginal Affairs Standing Committee I have had the opportunity and the pleasure to visit a number of Aboriginal communities across this country-- places that I had not had the opportunity to visit before. Through those visits I can contrast very clearly the successes that some communities have had in their school programs and in the delivery of education to their children, to others where this seems to be failing.

I was delighted to have the opportunity to visit places such as Yirrkala school at Nhulunbuy in the Northern Territory. I found that to be a very exciting place. There were lots of things happening: the children were motivated, they were attending, the program seemed relevant to their needs, and the community was actively involved in the running of that school. It was a very successful program for that reason--the community felt that it was its school. Regardless of whether we are talking about Aboriginal or non-Aboriginal people in this country, if the community does not feel that it is its school--that it is an important part of the Aboriginal society and that the people have a stake in the educational policies of that school--then the educational system fails. It is the same in the suburbs of my electorate of Moreton as it is in Aboriginal communities.

The success of Yirrkala school and the success of another school which we visited in the Northern Territory, Yipirinya school in Alice Springs, is because of that strong community involvement. The people believe that is their school; they have a stake in the success of that school so they get themselves involved.

I contrast that with what has been happening for a number of years in Aurukun in far north Queensland. I visited Aurukun a couple of weeks ago with the Aboriginal Affairs Committee, together with my friend and colleague the honourable member for Oxley (Mr Les Scott) and the honourable member for Aston (Mr Nugent), who is another member of the Aboriginal Affairs Committee. We had the opportunity to talk to people in Aurukun. Some honourable members may not be aware of the difficulties that have hit Aurukun, but the Queensland Government recently made a decision to take I think about eight teachers out of the school. It had a staff of about 10 or 11 and the Government has transferred eight teachers out of the school because, although the school has a notional enrolment of some 260 students, only 30 were turning up each day.

We could try to lay blame for that. We could try to work out why that is happening; we could say that maybe the community is not concerned about education. We all know that there have been a lot of alcohol problems in the community; there has been a lot of violence and threats have been made against teachers. I am not criticising the Queensland Government for its decision to transfer teachers out of that place, particularly if there were safety reasons behind it. But I look at that school and I say, `Why is this school failing to address the needs of the community? Why is the community not supporting the Aurukun school?'. I think one of the reasons why is that the community does not believe the Aurukun school is relevant to its needs, and that is a great disappointment. I do not think the Aurukun community is fully involved in its school.

That is a pity, because in the late 1970s and early 1980s Aurukun was a very successful school. It had a bilingual program going in the school which was working really well. It had very strong enrolments occurring, the average attendance of any other school, of around 92 or 93 per cent, and the community was fully involved. One of the reasons it was so fully involved was that bilingual program. The community felt that the school reflected the needs of the community, because the people of Aurukun still speak their own language very strongly. They are still active Wik speakers and they were pleased that the education system recognised their language and actually taught in their language as well as in English. The bilingual program meant that students not only were becoming literate in their own language of Wik but also were becoming more fluent and literate in English.

I have yet to be given an explanation as to why the bilingual program was taken out, but since the removal of that program the whole fabric of the school has wound away and enrolments have fallen back. The school no longer has the support of the community and the children of Aurukun are missing out because of the lack of community involvement. I am very disappointed that that is happening and I hope that some time in the next few months the Queensland Education Minister is able to fully examine the ways in which Aboriginal education is delivered at Aurukun and whether or not there are some alternative methods that he needs to consider for delivery of educational services.

One thing that is happening at Aurukun is that a number of people are moving out of Aurukun to out-stations around the community. That was one of the reasons why a number of the children were not present at the school. Over 120, and possibly 160, people are living on out-stations, and perhaps the Queensland Education Minister needs to consider ways of taking some educational services out to the people on those out-stations as well.

The strength of the national Aboriginal education policy lies in the fact that it relies on community involvement. That is highlighted by the success of the ASSPA program through which funds are dedicated to Aboriginal schools or schools with significant Aboriginal enrolments so that the parents of those Aboriginal students can determine which resources, programs or specific services they want. That has shown that Aboriginal parents do wish to be involved, because in every place where ASSPA has been offered and has got off the ground, it has succeeded and is operating very well. This is because Aboriginal parents are willing to be involved, get behind their children, sit as a committee, decide what resources they want and where they want the funding to go to address the particular needs of the students in that school. ASSPA highlights the fact that Aboriginal people do wish to be involved, as every other parent does, in the delivery of education.

I hope that over time that element of the national Aboriginal education policy will grow stronger and stronger, that is, the communities are the very foundation of the delivery of successful education and we need to strongly encourage Aboriginal people to be involved in and take charge of the delivery of education in their communities. It has been proven that only in that way will we have students fully involved and receiving the same educational opportunities as those offered to the rest of Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charles Mr R.E.
