TALK.START.PARA: —-I am indeed pleased to be able to speak to the Aboriginal Education (Supplementary Assistance) Amendment Bill, but regret that I will not be able to bring to this debate the richness of personal experience that we have just heard from the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Gibson). Education is the door to a prosperous and rewarding future for all Australians. The keys to the door are literacy and numeracy which, in the hands of our Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people, offer them a golden opportunity.

SPEECH.PARA: The Commonwealth is to be commended for its attention to the provision of the Aboriginal education program, and the cooperation between Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people and the Government in the establishment of that program is an example of interaction at the coalface. It is extremely important for consultations to be not only undertaken but actually taken into consideration when programs which impact on particular communities are being determined. The Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people have particular and distinctive needs in education and those needs may vary from community to community. As we have just heard from the honourable member for Moreton, that community involvement is critical to the success not only of educational programs but of all sorts of programs which are offered by the Government.

I remind the honourable member for Moreton that he and his colleagues on the Government side of the House still support the centralised bureaucracy of the education system that has been built up and up under the current Ministers. The Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people have particular and distinctive needs in education. When reforms are being considered there must be real consultation and attention to the detailed needs expressed by those communities in order to achieve maximum desirable impact with minimum conflict.

In his second reading speech the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Aboriginal Reconciliation (Mr Tickner) mentioned several major reports which have identified Aboriginal people as the most educationally disadvantaged group in Australia. When referring to the AEP he said:

It has four main long term objectives: to increase the involvement of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people in educational decision making; to ensure equality of access to educational services; to ensure equity of educational participation; and to achieve equitable and appropriate educational outcomes.

The designation of four separate long term objectives of the Aboriginal educational program is somewhat disappointing. It is just another example of bureaucratic activity that simply confuses the real issues. Surely, the four objectives could be enunciated in one simple objective, which, furthermore, should not be long term.

Restated, the objectives might be read as follows: to increase the involvement of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people in educational decision making and to ensure equality of access, participation and outcomes.

Last week the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) released a White Paper on the Australian language and literacy policy titled Australia's Language. The Minister's paper discusses the need for plain English and in fact defines plain English as `clear, intelligible English'. The paper states:
It does not mean simplistic English. Plain English should be used in public documents issued by Governments and the private sector. It is not an attempt to strip English literature of its richness.

That is all good stuff, but the Dawkins paper is so riddled with bureaucratic doublespeak that it is very difficult to determine the real policy objectives or the methods which will be used to achieve the policy outcome that is sought.

Of course, the bureaucracy has its own agenda, which includes self-generation. As long as the language in documents is obscure, difficult to interpret and, to some, incomprehensible, we will need the bureaucrats to translate for us the meaning of our own language. I ask honourable members whether those from Anglo-Saxon, English speaking backgrounds have some difficulty at times, or perhaps frequently, with Australian Government bureaucratic double speak. Imagine then the discomfort, difficulty and disillusionment felt by those from the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities who join with others from non-English speaking backgrounds as part of the Australian society who have difficulty coping with government documentation.

If we are to improve the educational position of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders, it is imperative that the main objective of the Aboriginal educational program be to immediately provide greater access to educational services. With access comes greater participation. With greater participation at a face to face level comes increased involvement, with resultant enhanced outcomes.

The four objectives as enunciated by the Minister are all part of the pathway which leads from easier access through greater participation in education to a more highly educated people. They are not, and cannot be, considered as separate and individual objectives. Access is a stepping stone to participation which leads to involvement of families and friends resulting in greater achievement with improved outcomes and enhanced self- reliance.

Simplicity should be the fundamental basis of all education programs, whether they are for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people or others. It is time that this Government woke up to this very simple basic fact. I venture to suggest that all of us on both sides of the House have a commitment to the provision of effective and worthwhile educational programs for all Aust- ralians. However, that admirable commitment will have little value if we do not also simplify the processes of delivery in order to maximise the dollar value at the coalface--in the classroom, face to face with the consumers of education.

The Government is very good at talking about commitment and establishing goals and objectives but when it comes to actual delivery the filter that is the bureaucracy often leaves little but the dregs for the actual consumer. Appropriation Bills Nos 1 and 2, which are still before the House, increase expenditure on tertiary education by 7.7 per cent. The Budget increases expenditure on student financial assistance by 18.5 per cent. It increases expenditure on general administration and overheads by 18.7 per cent. It is axiomatic that we have little hope of increasing real educational outcomes if we spend our money on the bureaucracy and living expenses to the detriment of the real delivery of real teaching programs in real schools.

I am pleased to note the Minister's emphasis on the involvement of Aboriginals in decision making. It is crucial that such involvement occur and become an ongoing process. I note that parents and teachers meet on a regular basis to discuss program priorities in the schools. Such interaction benefits all parties. In the Cockatoo Primary School in my electorate of La Trobe the parents, friends and relations of students have become closely involved with all aspects of schooling, particularly the reading program. As a result of that interaction literacy levels have increased in leaps and bounds not only among the students but also within the community at large. It has been exciting to watch the development of enhanced literacy skills throughout the whole community--something which has occurred to such an extent that Cockatoo Primary School is no longer considered a disadvantaged school.

I am sure that such outcomes can also be achieved in Aboriginal communities. Education is such a wonderful experience when the students are given the basic skills--those of literacy and numeracy--that the desire to learn becomes endemic. For too long in this nation of diverse cultural backgrounds learning and the skills of learning have not always been available to the less advantaged. Equitable access to participation in and results from education will benefit our nation as a whole. The quest for knowledge can be contagious. The Minister in his second reading speech indicated:

The policy emphasises a cooperative approach at every level and operates with cross-party support. It links the work of education providers and State and Territory governments of all kinds through an agreed national approach.

I am delighted to note the Minister's acknowledgment of cross-party support. Education is an issue so important to the future of Australia that it should be non-political. Unfortunately, the teachers unions do not always agree. I will give honourable members an example. In Victoria we have recently had industrial action that denied primary students from non-government schools access to the education facilities at the Royal Melbourne Zoo. I ask honourable members: how can we as a nation ever become a clever country when primary school children become the butt of some union's sick joke? It is absolutely imperative that such rebel action not be allowed to continue.

Cooperative approaches at all levels of education, not just Aboriginal, and the depoliticising of education policy can only make a positive contribution towards a smarter nation. All providers of education at both Federal and State levels must work together in a spirit of cooperation to ensure that the very best outcomes are available to all who would seek to be educated.

It is important to note the signs that indicate an increase in Aboriginal school retention rates. Of the 4,226 Aboriginal students in receipt of Absec and Abstudy allowances in year 8 in 1976, only 325 were still in the system and in receipt of those allowances when they completed year 12 in 1980--an apparent retention rate of 7.69 per cent. I say `apparent' because the figures do not necessarily indicate that all non-recipients had dropped out of school. The statistic simply measures the number of students who were still in receipt of educational allowances. It is assumed that non-recipients of allowances were no longer in the schooling system.

There were 4,980 Aboriginal students in receipt of Absec and Abstudy allowances in year 8 in 1980. That figure fell to 3,540 completing year 10 two years later. Only 656 were recorded as being left in the system in year 12 in 1984--an apparent retention rate of 13.17 per cent. That is almost double that of the figure two years before. By 1984 there were 5,640 students in year 8 receiving Absec and Abstudy allowances. Two years later, 4,356 students were studying year 10. In 1988 some 1,292 were still recorded as being in education studying year 12--an apparent retention rate of 22.9 per cent.

Although the retention rates are assumed because only those students in receipt of educational allowances are included, one factor that is very apparent is the steady increase in apparent retention rates during the terms not only of the Hawke Labor Government, as the Minister claimed, but also during the Fraser years.

The desire to pursue higher education that is being demonstrated by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people is to be applauded and encouraged. It is essential that all Australians, regardless of cultural background, exercise their rights to an education. It behoves the Government to provide the opportunities. Education is an essential ingredient in the maturing of a nation; its significance cannot and indeed must not be underestimated. I am somewhat concerned at the Minister's comment in his second reading speech when he said:

The reconciliation process emphasises education as a central and essential concern. . . There is a need to educate all Australians about Aboriginal history and culture and about the reasons for Aboriginal social and economic disadvantage.

Education of all Australians about the contribution Aboriginals have made to this country we call home is important--very important. However, we must be very careful in the structuring of the studies of Aboriginal culture and history that we do not get caught up in the guilt complex merry-go-round that some of our lefty and trendy teachers would hang on us. We must be careful not to attempt to rewrite our early history books in order to satisfy a new awakening of Aboriginal history. I do not condone or attempt to justify the many acts of aggression against our Aboriginal people by the early settlers, but recognition of those acts must be taught in the context of the times. Many similar acts were also being perpetrated against various sections of the settler community.

To teach an unbalanced view has the potential to perpetuate discord. Let the emphasis be on cooperation, accord, harmony, and results in education rather than on guilt and disadvantage. There is a saying, `If you tell a person they are smart, stupid, attractive, or whatever, often enough, soon enough they will start believing it'. The Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders may be disadvantaged, but to continually harp on the disadvantage perpetuates that belief.

Education is about changing one's view of oneself. Education is knowing that one can succeed. Education is about learning how to learn. Education is about transformation in all facets of life for all people--whether Aboriginal or non-Aboriginal. We are indeed one nation and one people. We in this place have an obligation to encourage the education of our Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people in such a way as to emphasise the positive features of their culture and heritage, and to let that positive emphasis permeate the whole Australian education system so that we can have a nation that practises reconciliation and cooperation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Mr L.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I start by picking up a point from the second reading speech of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Tickner) which was mentioned by the honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Charles). The honourable member quoted the Minister as saying:

SPEECH.PARA: The reconciliation process emphasises education as a central and essential concern. As the Bill, supported unanimously in both Houses of Parliament, stresses, there is a need to educate all Australians about Aboriginal history and culture and about the reasons for Aboriginal social and economic disadvantage.
I think this point made by the Minister, who is at the table, is very important, because it is about something that all Australians have missed out on--that is, Aborigine culture.

We have a lot to learn from our Aborigine brothers and sisters. The last 12 months or so, in which time I have been involved in the Standing Committee on Aboriginal Affairs, have been very educational for me. I think it has been said by some of my colleagues on the other side of the House that perhaps we all should take the opportunity to participate in such committees, because we do have the opportunity to learn more about Aborigine culture and the needs of these wonderful people. They have a great history and Australia certainly is a greater place for the contribution they make.

But there are difficulties, particularly in the education field, and that is the subject of the Aboriginal Education (Supplementary Assistance) Amendment Bill. Whilst we can describe the amendments as minor, they are very important. The main purpose of this Bill is to amend the principal Act, the Aboriginal
Education (Supplementary Assistance) Act 1989. There are four parts to these amendments, which previously have been outlined by the Minister and others, so I will not go through them again.

The national Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander education policy, a joint policy statement, certainly is worth reading. I commend it to all honourable members. The Aboriginal education policy task force was established in 1988 to bring together many reports, ranging from a report on Aboriginal education in 1985 by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Aboriginal Affairs to a number of other reports put out by the National Aboriginal Education Committee. Some of the comments in that report are very frightening. The report states:

Australians take it for granted, as an inalienable right of citizens of this country, that their children will receive at least 10 years of education, as well as the benefits of early childhood education. However, these fundamental rights have not been extended to all Aboriginal families. This is clearly demonstrated by the fact that in the compulsory school years, 1 in 8 Aboriginal children aged 5 to 9 years do not go to school or pre-school, and for those aged 10 to 15 years an appalling 1 in 6 do not have access to appropriate schooling. Moreover, access to and participation in education for Aborigines beyond the age of 15, whether in senior secondary school, technical and further education or higher education, remains at unacceptably low levels--generally at rates some 3 to 5 times lower than for the community as a whole.

This certainly is an appalling situation, about which I am sure all honourable members share my concern. I know that the Minister at the table does. That report highlights the point which we are talking about in Aborigine education.

Earlier, the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Gibson) referred to his and my participation in various aspects of our work with the Aboriginal Affairs Committee. Recently, I went with him on a trip to north Queensland. When we go to these places we see the problems that exist in them. I do not pretend to have the answers to them, but I think the commitment that this Government has given to Aborigine education policy goes a long way towards finding them. I think it is only with cooperation at all levels of government--and the National Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander education policy goes a long way towards achieving that--that we will overcome a lot of these difficulties.

The honourable member for Moreton referred to Aurukun in north Queensland, where there have been difficulties in recent times. I hope that the Queensland Education Minister, in trying to get those teachers back into that area, picks up some of the points made by the honourable member for Moreton, because the attendance rate at the school in Aurukun is appalling. The teachers were taken out of the school because of the low number of children attending.

In contrast, on that same visit to north Queensland, we also went to Kowanyama. Interestingly enough, the number of children attending schools there was very similar to the numbers in mainstream education in the rest of Queensland. We spoke to the headmaster of the school, who mentioned that the attendance rate at his school was the norm for most other communities throughout the State. I thought that was encouraging. It seemed to be a very vibrant community which had a lot of work going on. It was quite a contrast. I think we should look at different areas in which Aborigine communities are working together well in the interests of their families, because that is certainly something that needs to be addressed.

Whilst the honourable member for Moreton remained at Aurukun, I, along with the honourable member for Aston (Mr Nugent), had the opportunity to go to an out-station. We flew there in a little aircraft, which I was not really keen on flying in, but it was a great opportunity. That is why the honourable member for Moreton did not go--he does not like flying in little aircraft. It was an interesting trip.

People wish to move out to these areas. They are developing and getting back to their own cultures more now than they have in the past. The education question will need to be addressed because that is one of the things that will be lacking in these out-stations. They will need assistance to apply themselves. I think they will be able to do that with the assistance that can be provided by Government, provided the people themselves are involved in that education. Today various speakers have mentioned how the Aboriginal people themselves need to be involved in decision making processes.

The honourable member for the Northern Territory (Mr Snowdon) highlighted some problems in the Northern Territory. I think most of us are aware of the attitude of the Government up there. Consultation is essential, and it is essential that the education centres for all people do belong to the people and that people do participate in them. I am sure that in our own communities, from our involvement with local schools, we all know that where there is a sense of belonging there is much greater participation by all the families associated with those schools.

It is exactly the same as any other community, including communities comprising Aboriginal families who participate in those activities. I have had the opportunity to visit schools in Aboriginal communities and I have noticed that the successful schools have a greater participation rate of local people compared with the schools which impose a system of involvement on the local people. Many teachers are very dedicated to the work they do in those communities.

I will not speak at great length on this legislation, but I wish to make a couple of points. If there are problems with housing and living standards, they flow right through the education system. Aborigines are very proud people. If they do not have good living standards and proper housing, the children are not properly prepared to go to school. In many cases, as a result of those poor conditions, the children do not go to school at all. These points were made to the Standing Committee on Aboriginal Affairs, and they highlight the need to address a whole range of problems. It is not possible to look at education or housing in isolation. These problems, including the living standards of Aboriginal people in these communities in particular, must be addressed.

I commend the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs for the work he is doing. I call on our State colleagues to provide the necessary support. I am a Queenslander. Some unfortunate situations have occurred recently in Queensland which have not pleased me. I have stated that publicly on other occasions. I hope that some of the difficulties confronting Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders in Queensland will be addressed very quickly by the Queensland State Government. If the Federal Parliament is fair dinkum about the reconciliation process--this Government and the Opposition have already said that they are committed to it--it will not augur well if State and Territory governments fail to show a commitment to the reconciliation process that we are working towards.

I come back to the point where I started. Education is certainly a fundamental element in the reconciliation process, and it was also central to the findings of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody. Education seems to be the cornerstone of the processes involved in the resolution of problems that really need to be addressed.

I am pleased that members of the Opposition support this legislation. They have worked in a bipartisan way to deal with these matters. I am pleased to have the opportunity to support this legislation and commend it to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hulls Mr R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I cannot understand the city representatives of this Parliament who do not like flying around in small aircraft. Once in a while, they ought to get out into the real world. They should visit the electorate of Kennedy, which is 772,000 square kilometres. It is impossible to walk around the electorate, so they would have to fly.

SPEECH.PARA: At the outset, while I welcome the bipartisan support for the Aboriginal Education (Supplementary Assistance) Amendment Bill 1991, I must say that some of the comments made by the honourable member for Groom (Mr Taylor) about Bula and carpet snakes smack of--dare I use the expression?--crass politics. I think his comments show a lack of understanding of the totality of the real issues involved in the Coronation Hill decision. I have not the slightest doubt that the Coronation Hill decision was absolutely correct. If the honourable member for Groom took the time to fully explore the complexity of the issues, I am sure he would come to the same conclusion without reverting to patronisation.

During this debate, the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Gibson) related very well his personal experiences as a teacher in Aboriginal communities generally, and Yarrabah in particular. He referred to the lack of interest demonstrated in the past in Aboriginal education. I, too, have a story to relate from my early days as a solicitor when I was retained by the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Legal Service in north-west Queensland. This is a true story. It reflects the lack of appropriate education of Aboriginal people in the past in Queensland.

Not long after arriving in Mount Isa, I was speaking to a police prosecutor who told me about the difficulties encountered by Aboriginal people in understanding the criminal justice system. I must say that he agreed that this related to a lack of educational opportunities. He told me about an old Aboriginal bloke who was merely a witness to a fatal car crash. The old bloke was subpoenaed to give evidence at a coronial inquest. He came to court and, when it was time to give evidence, he was put into the witness box. He looked around the room and saw a room full of stuffed shirts. There were lawyers, a magistrate and court reporters present, and it must have been a very daunting experience for him.

He looked around the room--honourable members should not forget that he was a witness to this car crash--and called out, `I plead guilty'. The court room roared with laughter, but the Aboriginal witness was not laughing. He had been subjected to a system that offered him no chance of acquiring an education and, therefore, no chance of understanding the system of justice in this country. Thankfully, things are slowly changing.

The Aboriginal Education (Supplementary Assistance) Amendment Bill 1991 amends the principal Act, the Aboriginal Education (Supplementary Assistance) Act 1989. As we have heard, the principal Act provides a legislative base for a consolidated program and funding approach that is supplementary to mainstream funding. The Act underpins the national Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander education policy, known as the AEP, which has been endorsed by Commonwealth, State and Territory governments.

This Act leaves intact the essential features of the AEP. However, as a result of this legislation, the administrative arrangements under which funding is disbursed will be different under the AEP. The administrative amendments reflect the transfer of the higher education funding component within the Aboriginal Education (Supplementary Assistance) Act 1989 to the Higher Education Funding Act and minor changes to the Aboriginal education strategic initiatives program.

While the changes to the legislation are merely administrative, the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Tickner) has noted in his second reading speech--this has also been referred to by the honourable member for the Northern Territory (Mr Snowdon), and I think it is worth repeating--that the passage of the amendments provides an opportunity for the Parliament to give a commitment of support to the principles and practices of the AEP as a means of addressing the educational needs of Aboriginal Australians. I wholeheartedly agree with the Minister, and I certainly welcome that opportunity.

The origins of the AEP date back to 1988 when the Federal Government established an education policy task force to examine Aboriginal education. The task force conducted its own investigations and held its own consultations. It drew together the main findings of several major reports into Aboriginal education over the past decade. The Government endorsed the main findings of the task force report and responded by developing the national Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander education policy in conjunction with State and Territory governments, educational institutions and Aboriginal groups. The policy was announced in October 1989 and resulted in the passage of the principal Act.

The honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Charles) mentioned that the national policy has four long term goals: the involvement of Aboriginal people in education decision making; equality of access to educational services; equity in educational participation; and equitable and appropriate educational outcomes. Through the national policy, the Government has allocated funds to preschools, primary and secondary schools including post- compulsory schooling, technical and further education colleges, adult education and higher education.

I do not wish to go into much detail on each of these long term goals. However, I take this opportunity to put on the record the success of the Aboriginal student support and parent awareness program, known as ASSPA, at Mount Isa's Central State School. The Mount Isa Central State School's ASSPA committee is one of over 2,000 similar committees throughout Australia. For the benefit of those who do not know, let me say that ASSPA committees are made up of Aboriginal parents and teachers who meet to discuss program priorities for schools.

Before I was elected to Parliament, I used to work with a woman by the name of Amanda Brazier, who is now secretary and treasurer of the Mount Isa State School ASSPA committee. According to Amanda, the committee is operating extremely well. Not only is it giving Aboriginal parents such as Amanda the opportunity to discuss the educational needs and priorities of their children but it also gives teachers the opportunity, which is equally important, to learn about Aboriginal culture.

Items on the agenda at ASSPA committee meetings can include: ways of assisting Aboriginal children to learn two separate cultures; how to make Aboriginal culture accessible to new teachers arriving from southern cities; the inclusion of Aboriginal history and culture on the school curriculum; and National Aboriginal and Islander Day of Celebrations, which is known as NAIDOC.

National Aboriginal and Islander Day is being celebrated in Mount Isa this week and Central State School has had a variety of projects happening all week that have encouraged young Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander children to be proud of their culture, and has brought some of the mystery and excitement of that culture to non-Aboriginal children. I want to take this opportunity to congratulate Amanda Brazier, the Central State School ASSPA Committee and all other hardworking ASSPA committees in Mount Isa and around Queensland that have contributed very well to NAIDOC celebrations this week.

The importance of the success of the ASSPA program and the other elements of the AEP--such as the Aboriginal tutorial assistance scheme, which is also working very well in Mount Isa, and schemes for the vocational and educational guidance for Aboriginals--is made all too clear when we look at the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander education retention and participation rates, which have been referred to by some of the previous speakers. The AEP task force reported in 1988 that education participation and retention rates of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander students were still well below those of the rest of Australia. About 13 per cent of Aboriginal students aged 5 to 15 years do not take part in compulsory education, whereas almost all other Australians of the same age group do.

The number of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander students taking part in post-compulsory education also reflects considerable inequities between Aboriginal people and other Australians. Aboriginal participation in years 11 and 12, TAFE and higher education is only about one-third of the rate of the rest of the community. There has been considerable improvement in recent years. The number of Aboriginal students staying on to finish year 12 has increased markedly from about 11 per cent in 1983 to almost 23 per cent in 1988. Aboriginal enrolments in higher education have also increased considerably from 700 in 1983 to 2,604 in 1988.

While the record is improving, it is important to acknowledge the conclusion of the report of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody in this regard. In volume 2 of the national report, in the chapter on schooling, Commissioner Elliott Johnston, QC, noted that, although there has been significant improvement in Aboriginal education indicators in the past two decades, Aboriginal people are still identifiable as the most poorly educated group in Australia. The report provides an excellent analysis of the factors influencing Aboriginal education, including inhibiting factors such as cultural difference, health, parental roles, the mobility of families, social conflict, poverty and living conditions, role models, curriculum, peer group pressure, general attitudes and unwillingness to leave home.

The report also considered the AEP in some detail. Despite some criticism of the AEP concerning who should define appropriate outcomes, the Commission did conclude that the AEP provides a model set of cooperative arrangements that enable Aboriginal participation in decision making. The Commission recommended:
That:
a. At every stage of the application of the National Aboriginal Education Policy the utmost respect be paid to the first long-term goal expressed in the policy, that is:

To establish effective arrangements for the participation of Aboriginal parents and community members in decisions regarding the planning, delivery, and evaluation of pre-school, primary, and secondary education services for their children.

b. It be recognized that the aims of the Policy are not only to achieve equity in education for Aboriginal people but also to achieve a strengthening of Aboriginal identity, decision making and self-determination; and
c. It is unlikely that either of these aims--
the above two aims referred to--
can be achieved without the achieving of the other.

I am confident that, if the level of commitment on the part of Aboriginal parents and teachers at Mount Isa Central State School is typical of ASSPA committees around Australia, the AEP will ultimately achieve its aims.

The AEP is integrally related to the process of Aboriginal reconciliation, as set out in the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation Act 1991. As the Minister has said, the reconciliation process emphasises the essential role of education and, specifically, that there is an urgent need to educate non-Aboriginal Australians about the cultures of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders. As I have said before in this House, I believe that the tragic history of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people must be told with the objective not of creating guilt but of fostering compassion and empathy for Australia's indigenous people. It will be a central role of the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation to bring the history and the suffering of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people out into the open. The stories of abuse, murder, alienation and dislocation must be told--and non-Aboriginal people must listen.

The AEP provides the framework for the national reconciliation and schooling strategy that is an integral part of this process. We should applaud, I think, the success to date of the AEP and look forward to the day when the four objectives have been met fully. I certainly have pleasure in fully supporting the Bill now before the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tickner The Hon R.E.

TALKER.NAME: Mr TICKNER
TALKER.ROLE: -Minister for Aboriginal Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Aboriginal Reconciliation)

TALK.START.PARA: —-in reply--There has been quite a wide ranging debate which has reflected virtually an absolute cross-party commitment not only to the Aboriginal Education (Supplementary Assistance) Amendment Bill which is before the House but also, even more importantly, to the Aboriginal education policy which has been so extensively debated in the course of the Bill's passage through the House. However, I ought to respond to a number of things that have been raised in the course of debate, and I will proceed to do that as expeditiously as possible.

SPEECH.PARA: At the outset, I would like again, as often is my lot in this House, to pay credit to the honourable member for Chisholm (Dr Wooldridge) for his constructive contribution to the Bill. He highlighted two very important matters which I want to give further emphasis to: firstly, the need for inter-governmental cooperation in relation to the Aboriginal education policy and, secondly, the importance of monitoring the outcomes of that policy.

There was held in Alice Springs a week ago a meeting of Commonwealth and State Ministers for Aboriginal affairs. One of the results of that meeting was a decision taken by Ministers to go forward to the Special Premiers Conference to bring about some very practical proposals for greater inter-governmental cooperation in Aboriginal affairs generally. I do believe that the Aboriginal education policy shows the way that such cooperation could be achieved. But it is important, both in terms of the broader initiatives of Federal, State and Territory Ministers in Aboriginal affairs and in relation to the AEP, that we have comprehensive monitoring of outcomes.

I emphasise that because, as a number of speakers in the course of this debate have said, it is a principle of the reconciliation strategy that has been unanimously supported by the Parliament that the question of Aboriginal education be afforded a high priority, partly for reasons just mentioned by the honourable member for Kennedy (Mr Hulls), which I will allude to further in a moment, and also because of a central principle of the reconciliation strategy that the governments of Australia need to work with Aboriginal people to address critical issues of Aboriginal disadvantage. The preamble to the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation Bill says:

. . . as a part of the reconciliation process, the Commonwealth will seek an ongoing national commitment from governments at all levels to co- operate and to co-ordinate with the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission as appropriate to address progressively Aboriginal disadvantage and aspirations in relation to. . .
Of course, one of the matters that is mentioned there is education, and it is seen as a major objective of the reconciliation strategy leading to the centenary of Australian federation.

I raise that because if the Aboriginal education policy is going to be effective we have to be in there as a nation for the long haul. The extent of the disadvantage, as many speakers have recognised, is so great that it will take a vast and ongoing commitment of resources. We have to be sure that the programs put in place under the AEP are adequately monitored to see that they are achieving the results that we have set out to achieve under the policy. So I endorse what I understand to be the sentiments of the honourable member for Chisholm in raising those matters.

I turn to the contribution of the honourable member for the Northern Territory (Mr Snowdon). In the context of referring to his contribution, I pick up the general sentiments put forward by the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Gibson), the honourable member for Oxley (Mr Les Scott) and the honourable member for Kennedy in their contributions to the debate. All those Government members I believe made forthright and highly principled contributions. They made me exceptionally proud to be a member of this side of the House, because the Hansard will show that they took up in a forthright way issues of concern in relation to the Aboriginal education policy. The honourable member for Moreton, the honourable member for Oxley and the honourable member for Kennedy directly made reference to policies and issues of concern to them in relation to Queensland.

I think it is important that honourable members of this House be able to speak forthrightly on matters of concern, especially in relation to Aboriginal affairs. If occasionally party allegiances get in the way of those forthright and heartfelt concerns, then I am proud that people on this side of the House--and I do hope, in years to come, on the other side of the House--can stick to their principles, stand up for their beliefs, and support the principles that underlie Aboriginal education policies. So I thank them for their contributions. I think they were constructively and moderately put, and no doubt they will be pursuing those matters further.

I prefaced my comments in relation to the honourable member for the Northern Territory by referring to contributions made by other colleagues because I would not want it to be thought that the statements made by him are motivated by some short term, head kicking, party political agenda. The honourable member is deeply committed not only to his electorate but also to the Aboriginal education policy. I do not think I am betraying a confidence by saying that his persistent representations to me on that policy and the need for it to work effectively occupy a vast amount of

my ministerial staff's time. I know his sentiments were deeply felt. I believe, frankly, that they reflect some very real concerns which we ought to have about Aboriginal education in the Northern Territory. Having said that, it is not my intention to use this occasion to pursue those matters; that remains to be done at another time and place.

In the main, I welcomed the contribution made by the honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Charles). I would take this opportunity, however, to highlight to him--as the honourable member for Kennedy did--that the reconciliation initiative that the Commonwealth Parliament has unanimously committed itself to certainly does have as one of its major objectives the education of non-Aboriginal Australians about Aboriginal history, culture, dispossession, the nature of the disadvantage which Aboriginal people continue to experience, and the need to address that disadvantage.

As the honourable member for Kennedy said, that is not about a guilt trip. Both the honourable member for Chisholm and I have repeatedly emphasised that, but it is important that, as a nation, we come to terms honestly with our own history. We ought not to be afraid to learn about aspects of Australian history that perhaps do not reflect particularly well on the times, even taking into consideration, as the honourable member for La Trobe said, the social and political circumstances existing at that time. It is important that those matters be seriously addressed.

The issue of rewriting textbooks was raised by the honourable member for La Trobe and, at the risk of repeating excessively a matter that I have raised elsewhere, let me say that in some cases school textbooks and other textbooks do have to be rewritten because they do not portray Aboriginal Australia in anything like an accurate way. They are simply not good history books. I think that view has been endorsed by many eminent Australian historians, not the least of whom was the late Professor Manning Clark.

Turning to the contribution made by the honourable member for Groom (Mr Taylor), I endorse virtually all of his contribution. I was particularly heartened by his concluding remarks about the Aboriginal education policy and his endorsement of the principles underlying that policy. However, I should not let pass his comments in relation to Coronation Hill and Aboriginal heritage issues. Although they were only brief comments, let me briefly say in reply that Aboriginal heritage issues are extremely difficult and sensitive political matters. All I would ask is that honourable members of this House from all sides pay due regard to Aboriginal heritage and spiritual values and give them no lesser respect than would be accorded to the deeply held beliefs of any other Australian who practises a faith or holds spiritual beliefs in relation to what are commonly regarded as non-Aboriginal religious philosophies. That question of respect is one that needs to be continually emphasised.

I do not believe there are any other matters that I have not addressed. Let me conclude by saying that I welcome the constructive and measured contributions made by honourable members from both sides of the House. I again make the point that the Aboriginal education policy is for the long haul. We have got to ensure continuing commitment not only by the national Government but also by State and Territory governments because it is absolutely true that addressing Aboriginal education disadvantage is one of the key prerequisites for an effective process of reconciliation. I thank the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith.
Bill (on motion by Mr Tickner) read a third time.
