QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories

TALK.START.PARA: —-My question is directed to the Prime Minister. I remind the Prime Minister of his recent commitment to sack the next Minister who criticises Government policy. I repeat the question I asked yesterday: if the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories is shown to have misled the Prime Minister or this House will she be sacked if she does not resign?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —-When I have finished answering this question, the Leader of the Opposition is the one who ought to resign. The Minister for the Environment has made it plain to this House that she regards the 4 September meeting as private and confidential.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition members interjecting--

TALK.START.PARA: —-Opposition members should contain themselves. This has been widely supported today, I might say, by the Green groups involved in that meeting. For that reason, the Minister for the Environment has taken the correct attitude that, as a matter of principle, the tape of this meeting should not be made public.

ANSWER.PARA: For its own purposes, this Opposition, in a desperate attempt to divert attention from its own discomfiture with regard to the consumption tax, has decided that questions of principle do not matter. I make it quite clear that I fully respect the Minister's attitude to privacy in this matter but, in view of this unwarranted attack on her integrity and the false allegations made about her, I will read to the House the relevant departmental extract of the meeting to put this issue to rest, once and for all, and to demonstrate that her denial of this accusation is fully substantiated.
I intend now to read from that extract. Mr Speaker, I ask you, if you can, to ensure that what I read in its totality is heard in silence so that it will be fully understood.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order regarding standing order 145 and relevance. Why is the Prime Minister reading a departmental extract? Why is he not reading his own? Is it to avoid lying to the Parliament?
—-Order! There is no point of order.

—-It is for the simple reason that, as distinct from the honourable member for O'Connor, I have more important things to do than sit down and make a transcript of a tape when the transcript has been provided by the Department. No wonder he is sitting in Opposition if that is how he uses his time. Mr Speaker, as I say, I ask that those opposite who have made such fools of themselves on this issue listen in silence. This is the Minister speaking.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition members interjecting--

TALK.START.PARA: —-Opposition members obviously do not want to hear the facts.
—-Order! Members of the Opposition will cease interjecting. The House is interested in the answer which the Prime Minister has.
—-This is the extract:

ANSWER.PARA: I've really outlined the sort of structure of the EPA,--and where that's going. I'll just go into the intergovernmental agreement. The first draft, let me tell you about, the intergovernmental agreement--as you know has emerged basically from the Prime Minister's initiative with the States and it is really crass politics, at the lowest common denominator--it is all about mainly the people who are involved in it are not the environment Ministers or their departments, they're Premiers and the bottom line for them all this is the bucks, the big dollars. They would sell their mothers for a few bucks and so the bottom line of much of this negotiation is what we--if they get what they want on transport and housing in terms of untied grants and social serv. . . security they would give us anything, if they don't they're going to make our lives a misery and that's not so very satisfactory but that's the harsh reality of it.
That is the end of the extract. I table the extract. Let me make it clear that obviously----

TALK.START.PARA: —-Table the whole thing.
—-That is it. That is the totality of the transcript which relates----

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition members interjecting--

TALK.START.PARA: —-Order! The House will come to order.

—-That is the totality of the transcript which relates to this reference to crass politics. Quite obviously, as even these miserable people opposite will understand, throughout, the Minister is referring to the first draft of the intergovernmental agreement on the environment and the States' attitude to that. That is beyond dispute. That is the reference to crass politics and there is not one person in this House, or any analyst of that transcript, who can take any other point about it. That is what she was referring to.

ANSWER.PARA: As I said to the House on Monday, I accepted the Minister's word. I accepted it immediately when she spoke to me on Saturday. I have never had any reason in my dealings with this Minister to do other than accept her word on what she has said to me. I accepted her word and what I have just read to this House fully vindicates the Minister without any qualification at all, and demonstrates the accuracy of what I said at Question Time on Monday and yesterday.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr Sharp

TALK.START.PARA: —-Where is the tape?

INTERJECT.PARA: SPEAKER--Order! The honourable member for Gilmore will cease interjecting.

TALK.START.PARA: —-It is about time that this miserable collection of idealist people on the other side of the House got down to the fundamental questions, asked some real questions about real issues and did the job of formulating policies instead of attempting to get down in the gutter and question the integrity of a very fine and competent Minister.
—-My question is directed to the Treasurer. What is the size of the black economy in Australia? What measures has the Government taken to ensure a fairer and more effective tax system?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Members of this House will not be surprised to know that there are various estimates which purport to represent the size of the so-called black economy. For example, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition believes that the size of the black economy in August of this year was $20 billion. In August he agreed with the Leader of the National Party who said, on 25 July:

ANSWER.PARA: The black economy, or cash economy, has now reached some $20 billion.
But in the same month, in August, the shadow Treasurer doubled his estimate. On 29 August the honourable member for Flinders said:
Well, there's about $40 billion, we reckon.
Who reckons? The honourable member for Farrer or the Deputy Leader of the Opposition? He went on, amazingly, and said:
I think that's a pretty conservative figure.
Against what? Strangely, also in August--a very strange month--Senator Margaret Reid was published as saying:
By definition, the size of the black economy is unknown.

If I am going to be forced to chose between these various sources on the grounds of veracity and reliability, members of this House will not be surprised to know that I am going to back Senator Reid because Senator Reid, as the Opposition Whip in the Senate, has demonstrated time and time again her uncanny arithmetical skills and we know that she can add two and two together.

What has characterised this Government has been our absolute determination--translated into concrete policy action--to reclaim the Australian taxation system from the corporate creatures of the night. We resolved that we would reclaim the Australian taxation system for the Australian people from the commercial gipsies, tramps and thieves who were running it when the honourable members for Bennelong and Wentworth admittedly had some little responsibility for the tax system's operation.

I will go through some of the reforms which this Government has put in place to ensure that we have a fairer, more efficient tax system. We introduced the capital gains tax, opposed by the Opposition, which still opposes it. We introduced the fringe benefits tax, opposed by the Opposition. We abolished the entertainment expenses as a tax deduction, opposed by the Opposition. We introduced the resource rent tax, opposed by the Opposition in 1987. We introduced dividend imputation, we taxed foreign income and we wiped out all the shelters. We put in substantiation requirements and the reforms to the prescribed payments system, we increased audit activity by the Tax Office and introduced the tax file number. These reforms have all acted to reduce evasion.

Nearly every time these reforms were introduced, they were opposed by the Opposition. All this hard work by the Government has made the taxation system tighter, fairer and more equitable. Some figures have come out quite recently that show that total tax revenue as a proportion of GDP in Australia is now the second lowest in the OECD.

I challenge the Leader of the Opposition in his speech to the Press Club on 25 September to identify how the Opposition would preserve the integrity of the taxation system, given its appalling track record and its commitment to a manifestly unfair and inefficient alternative package. The Leader of the Opposition will not because he cannot.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories

TALK.START.PARA: —-My question is directed to the Minister for Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories.
—-Apologise!
—-Order! The member for the Northern Territory!
—-I am not sure whether they are asking the Minister to apologise for a failure to meet the order of the Senate.
—-The honourable member will get to his question.

—-I ask the Minister: who prepared the very brief extract that was just read by the Prime Minister? Who made the decision as to which part of the three-hour meeting was to be transcribed? In light of the Prime Minister's statement this morning that he was not unhappy for her to table the transcript of her meeting, when will she conform with the order of the Senate made yesterday that the thing should be tabled?
—-You are deliberately misleading the House.
—-Order! The House will come to order.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kelly The Hon R.J.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: THE ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —-This morning the Prime Minister referred to the issue of the tape. He said he did not agree that it should be released, and neither do I. I have said on previous occasions that it is a record of a private meeting. The extract that the Prime Minister read was prepared by a person in my office in full consultation with my Department. The tape is currently held in my Department. The honourable member can ask my secretary whether what is in that is an accurate assessment. He will tell him that it is.
—-At least your secretary would have more integrity than you have.
—-Order! The honourable member for Mayo will cease interjecting.
—-I warn the honourable member for Mackellar.

—-My question is addressed to the Treasurer. I preface it by drawing his attention to a seminar to be held at the Sydney Hilton on 11 November. Is he aware that the purpose of this seminar is to provide advice to executives on how they can `minimise the impact of consumption tax'? I ask the Treasurer: will the Government ensure that all Australians pay their fair share of tax?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —-As I said a moment ago, this Government has cleaned up the tax system. In these last eight years the Opposition has been prepared only to oppose, to reject and to battle our attempts to make the tax system fairer and more efficient. I can assure this House of the Government's absolute commitment to an efficient tax administration and a progressive, fair and efficient taxation system--and our record proves it.

ANSWER.PARA: Our hard work has cleaned out the taxation carpetbaggers who previously regarded paying tax as optional. I pick up the honourable gentleman's question because honourable members of this House will therefore be profoundly disturbed--or, more accurately, some members of this House will be profoundly disturbed--to learn that the tax minimisation industry is planning a comeback.

I am aware of the seminar to which the honourable member refers. The covering letter is headlined `How to Minimise the Impact of a Consumption Tax'. It represents the worst type of get rich quick opportunism. It also represents a fundamental attack on the specious claims of the Opposition that a consumption tax would have those in the undefined black economy pay their share. I will read part of this covering letter to the House. It says that this seminar:
. . . will teach you how to minimise your tax liabilities.
This seminar . . . will prevent the administrative nightmare that a consumption tax will cause.
Under the heading `Have you considered how purchasing patterns will change?' it says:

Companies and consumers will alter their buying habits. They will delay the purchase of goods whose prices will fall and speed up the purchase of goods and services whose prices will rise. You need to know what these effects will be, so that you can anticipate the needs of your market.

This means a dead weight loss. It is like the Libs carrying the Nats--a dead weight loss. The letter says that there will be an impressive array of speakers, including Sir Roger Douglas and others. Let us look at some of the topics: `Selling the benefits to business--how?; The costs of compliance (and the hidden costs); Avoiding an administrative nightmare; Anticipating market response to a price hike; and Overcoming customer resistance to your new prices' and--here is the best of the lot--`Reducing your exposure to a new consumption tax'. The boy from Bennelong will be back in business.

As I said before to this House, under this Government Australians can be reassured that economic growth will not result because of a boom in tax avoidance and tax evasion. Sadly, that is not the case with the Opposition. I conclude with the words of Mr Neil Warren, senior lecturer in economics at the University of New South Wales:
A broad-based consumption tax should not be argued as a way to tax personal income tax avoiders and evaders--this is too tenuous.

Again, the challenge for the Leader of the Opposition on 25 September--he will not face open press meetings but he is going to the National Press Club--is to answer how he will keep the carpetbaggers at bay. I will give the answer now: he will not, because he cannot.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Will the Prime Minister set aside the crass politics of the so-called Kellygate affair and inform the House of the real significance of new federalism? Under new federalism, will the Government abandon the environment to the States or will it have any role in protecting the environment? If so, what will that role be?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I very sincerely thank the honourable member for North Sydney for a sensible, constructive and realistic question. If I were to fully answer the question of all the implications of the new federalism, I am afraid that we would not get our mandatory 14 questions and answers in, so I will attempt to do this briefly. If the honourable gentleman would like to come round and talk to me at length in my office at some later stage I would be more than happy.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition members interjecting--

TALK.START.PARA: —-Order! The House will come to order.
—-Order! The honourable member for Gilmore!

—-I can assure the honourable gentlemen opposite that that is totally within the code of conduct. The basic point and thrust of the new federalism is that we live today in a society which is governed by a constitution drawn up 100 years ago by six reluctant colonies which knew that they had to come together because there were certain things that were required to be done that they were not able to do. They very reluctantly gave a number of powers to a new federation and kept as much as they could for themselves.

ANSWER.PARA: I think the men--they were men; there were no women involved in those three constitutional conventions--did an honourable job. But they obviously were not able at that time, in the last decade of the nineteenth century, to put together a constitutional instrument which is entirely appropriate for the needs of an Australia in the last decade of the twentieth century and in a world which is so entirely different from that in which the Constitution was finally accepted in 1898.

We have a position where there is a division of responsibilities between the Commonwealth and the States in a range of matters of very considerable importance to the citizens of this country--not only to the Commonwealth and the States, and I know this will be of interest to the honourable gentleman, but also, very importantly, to that tier of government which is too often overlooked, local government. Local government in a daily sense is always involved in providing services to the people of this country.

My concept in the new federalism of calling the people together--the States and local government in the Special Premiers Conference--was to see constructively together whether there are ways in which we may be able to deliver cooperatively services and structure our financial relationships which will serve people better, without seeking to say, `This is a Commonwealth right, that is a State right, that is a local government right'. The only rights in the end that matter to me are the rights of the people of Australia and how can we best together deliver those rights.

It is obviously the fact, as the honourable gentleman would know from his own extensive experience in the other levels of government, that there are areas of duplication and that if we sensibly talk together about how we may be able to get one area of government to do more than it is now, so one area hands over part of its responsibilities, it is very likely that services will be better delivered. Incidentally--but it is only an incidental objective of what I am about-- there may be some savings involved. But this is not a savings exercise. This is an exercise to deliver services better to the people of this country. That is what the conference has been about. Fortunately, of course, we already have so many runs on the board.

I ask the honourable gentleman to recall what came out of the July Special Premiers Conference. We have the position now, as a result of this constructive approach, that when we meet a lot of preliminary work has already been done by our officials. We now have a National Rail Corporation. What is that going to mean? It is going to mean that for the first time in the history of this federation we can go and book some freight on a rail service on one side of Australia and have it sent to the other. We have never been able to do that before. We are going to have a national road commission, so that for the first time we are going to be----

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr Andrews

TALK.START.PARA: —-Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. Standing order 145 says:

INTERJECT.PARA: The honourable member for North Sydney specifically asked the Prime Minister about new federalism and the environment. The Prime Minister has not yet said a word about the environment.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Order! There is no point of order.

—-I hope the honourable member for North Sydney will not object to my saying this, but I discern from his demeanour that he is interested in my response. Without, of course, going to all the details of what has already been achieved, one of the problems we have in this country concerning environmental issues is this: there is a real concern at all levels of government about the environment. I do not say that we have a monopoly of concern about issues of the environment. There are concerns at the State government level, and the States feel that they have a responsibility to exercise powers to protect the environment for future generations. In their way, of course, so do local governments.

ANSWER.PARA: We are about seeing whether, as a result of discussions with the States and local government, we can get a greater degree of coordination in our approach so that those who are concerned with making decisions involving environmental considerations are hopefully not going to be faced with a situation where they have to deal with the Commonwealth, State and local governments. It would be much better if, through our cooperative discussion, we can have a situation where there is a degree of coordination.

Finally, I say to the honourable member that the way we are doing that is this: we agreed at the meeting in July and recognised the fact that there were these nine groups meeting under the environmentally sustainable development process, or ESD--the States, the Commonwealth, the environmentalists, the mineral groups and the forestry groups. They are going to be giving their reports during the latter part of this year. We will not have time at the Special Premiers Conference in November finally to put our position following consideration of their reports, so we have agreed that we will get their reports, look at those matters raised and then have another Special Premiers Conference in the early part of next year, with the laudable, honourable objective of reaching a position where we can have an agreement which does not, from our point of view, involve any abrogation of the responsibilities that we feel we must discharge as a Commonwealth for protecting the environment but enables us to cooperate with the States, fully able to, and conscious that we will, discharge our own responsibilities to put in place a cooperative regime which will be better for everyone in this country--those concerned with development and those concerned with the environment. I thank the honourable member for his question.

TALK.START.PARA: —-My question is directed to the Prime Minister. I refer to the growing and real concern out there in the community about the policy being espoused by the Liberal and National Party coalition to impose a goods and services tax on all Australians, should it ever gain office in this country. I remind the Prime Minister that both the Leader of the Opposition and the shadow Treasurer constantly referred to overseas rates that have been introduced.
—-Oh, what a preamble!
—-Order!
—-I ask the Prime Minister----
—-Mr Speaker, on a point of order: the question is completely out of order.
—-I think we are waiting till we get to the question. I hope that members of the Opposition are not suggesting that we should not have preambles to questions.

—-My question is: will the Prime Minister inform the House what would be the effect on all Australians if the rates that the Opposition constantly says have been introduced overseas were introduced in Australia? Also, will he advise the House whether this Government intends to impose such a burden on all Australians?
—-Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order. The first part of the actual question is clearly out of order because it asks the Prime Minister for an opinion.
—-The question is in order. The Prime Minister will answer the question.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Of course, the impact upon Australians of the imposition of a broad-based consumption tax in this country would be totally devastating because it would totally smash the advances we have made in achieving a low inflation rate, it would increase unemployment and it would be regressive in that it would impose a much greater burden on the least privileged in this country.
—-What about what you said in 1985?
—-Order! The honourable member for Gilmore will cease interjecting.

—-The shadow Treasurer has often said that nearly all OECD countries have a consumption tax, therefore we should have one, too. It is an argument that this side of the House emphatically rejects but, as the shadow Treasurer is interested in what has happened in the OECD, let me tell him a little more about it. I know that the honourable gentleman would like this information. In virtually all OECD countries that have introduced a consumption tax, the rate has been subsequently increased--and increased substantially. For example, in the United Kingdom the rate has increased from 10 per cent to 17.5 per cent; in France the standard rate has increased from 13.6 per cent to 18.6 per cent; and--cop this one--in Austria the standard rate has increased from 8 per cent to 20 per cent.
—-I am shocked.
—-Order! Order!
—-In Denmark the rate has increased from 10 per cent to 22 per cent.
—-That number. That's where it came from.

—-The magic 22 per cent; see, it is the Denmark model. In Germany the standard rate has increased from 10 per cent to 14 per cent and will increase further to 15 per cent in 1992. In Italy the standard rate has increased from 12 per cent to 19 per cent, and of course in New Zealand, the world champions at reducing inflation----
—-It was the Labor Party that did that.
—-The rate increased from 10 per cent to 12.5 per cent without compensation in 1989, just three years after the introduction of the tax. So the list goes on.
—-Your mates! Your mates did that.
—-Order!
—-Yes, the Labor Party was the one that did that.
—-Order! I warn the member for Mayo. The member for Mayo might not be here later this afternoon if he continues.

—-Mr Speaker, whatever the rate proposed by the coalition, we can be sure that it would be subsequently increased as it has been all over the world. It would merely be the launching pad for its regressive inequities. I remind the House of the shadow Treasurer's remarks when he was asked whether he could provide a guarantee that the rate would not increase. There has been reference to this classic reply before, but in this context it should be stated again. When asked whether he would provide a guarantee that the rate would not increase, his answer--the classic answer--was, `No, I am saying that we will tell people in advance and give them the choice as to how they will vote one way or the other; I mean, obviously, you know, the future is the future; there are always things beyond our control'.

ANSWER.PARA: It raises the very real question: is the real agenda - the secret agenda--to increase the consumption tax rate to pay for a flat rate income tax? Those opposite have admitted that they have considered a flat rate tax and they will not rule it out. This is an absolute disgrace. A consumption tax would be a devastating blow for ordinary working men and women in this country and their families.

I conclude by saying to the Leader of the Opposition and the shadow Treasurer that it is no wonder that their colleagues are running away from them at 100 miles an hour. Kennett, the honourable member for Ryan, the honourable member for O'Connor, the honourable member for New England, Wal Murray, Dr Metherell, the Queensland Nationals and the Western Australian Nationals are running away from them because they know that the Australian people will never accept this iniquitous tax.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories

TALK.START.PARA: —-My question is directed to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. Firstly, was the Minister seriously suggesting to the House of Representatives that I asked her secretary who was it who made the decision about what part of the tape to transcribe? That is what she said. I ask her whether that was a serious suggestion. Secondly, did her secretary make the decision about whether this tiny extract was the only part relevant to the issues which have been raised and, if not the secretary, who did make that decision? Finally, in light of the fact that no-one else who participated in this discussion objects to the tabling of the tape, what does the Minister have to hide?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kelly The Hon R.J.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: THE ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —-I have been accused in this House over the last few days of lying and misleading the House. The Prime Minister today has stated clearly what was said----
—-Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. Are you going to permit the Minister to use the word `lying'?
—-The Minister said she has been accused of it.
—-As I said, the Opposition has accused me of lying and misleading the House----

ANSWER.PARA: Honourable members interjecting--

TALK.START.PARA: —-Order! The House will come to order. Obviously the Rt Hon. member for New England could not hear the Minister because there were so many interjections. The House might come to order and then we could all hear the Minister.

—-All of this has been in relation to the words `crass politics'. What the Prime Minister did today was release the extract from the tape that related to `crass politics' and that is that. In relation to misleading this House, yesterday the honourable member for Pearce misled the House----
—-He did it again.

—-And he has just done so again, because he said that the participants at that meeting demand the transcript be released. That is not so. Let me tell the House how this man--this despicable man over there----
—-That is not what I said.
—-Order! The House will come to order.

—-Let me tell the House how this man of no principles misleads and distorts a reputable and honourable person. He referred yesterday to a comment made by Phillip Toyne, the director of the Australian Conservation Foundation. He claimed in this House that Phillip Toyne--who, by the way, was not at the meeting--said that he had no objection to the release of the tape. What Phillip Toyne actually said to the honourable member for Pearce was that he would have no objection to the release of the tape if the Government took that action. But he made it clear----

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition members interjecting--

TALK.START.PARA: —-He was not there.
—-Those opposite do not like hearing the truth.

ANSWER.PARA: Honourable members interjecting--

TALK.START.PARA: —-Order! The House will come to order.

—-But he made it very clear to the honourable member for Pearce that the meeting was held on a confidential and private basis. Today I have also received some correspondence from other participants in that meeting which I regard as private. I have a letter which is from the Australian Council of National Trusts. It is signed by two people, one is Duncan Marshall and the other is a fellow called Harry Barber. Both of those people were present at the meeting and I will read that letter to the House. It states:

ANSWER.PARA: Dear Minister
The Australian Council of National Trusts and Conservation Council of Victoria write to support a call for all parties to respect the privacy of Peak Conservation Group meetings.
The above groups are participants in Peak meetings. These meetings occur regularly and involve discussions with Ministers, Shadow Ministers and other parliamentarians.

TALK.START.PARA: —-How much money do they get from the Government?
—-What is wrong with that?
—-The honourable member for Warringah will cease those sorts of interjections. Order! The House will come to order.
—-Order! The honourable member for the Northern Territory will cease interjecting.
—-Withdraw!
—-I won't. It is a perfectly legitimate interjection. I will not withdraw.
—-If the honourable member for Bennelong continues to interject I will name him.
—-What about them?
—-Members on my right will cease interjecting as well.
—-Name him.
—-I warn the honourable member for Bruce.
—-Those opposite put themselves in the gutter and they respond accordingly. The letter continues:

ANSWER.PARA: Recent controversy surrounding a Peak meeting has only distracted attention from the major environment issues including the Inter-governmental Agreement on the Environment.

Peak meetings have, in the past, been an opportunity for a frank exchange between conservation groups and politicians of all parties. They have been private meetings. If these meetings are to continue to be fruitful then they should remain private meetings. We believe the precedent should not be established of releasing tape recordings of these meetings.
I would also like to read another letter that I received today from the World Wide Fund for Nature signed by Don Henry.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Did you solicit that letter?
—-They do not like the truth, do they?

ANSWER.PARA: Honourable members interjecting--

TALK.START.PARA: —-Order! The House will come to order.
—-The letter reads:

ANSWER.PARA: Dear Minister,

World Wide Fund for Nature Australia believes that the privacy of Peak Conservation Group Meetings should be respected. It has been our understanding in the past that no formal transcript of the meeting has been made, rather, that a listing of action points from the meeting is developed.

The meetings have, in the past, been an opportunity for a frank exchange between conservation groups, including ourselves, and politicians of all parties. We have always viewed them as private meetings. This ensures a full and frank exchange of views on all important environmental issues facing Australia.

Finally, I would like to quote a section from an interview with a woman called Rosie Crisp--who was also at the meeting--from the Queensland Conservation Council who spoke on Queensland radio this morning. She said:
Well I mean, as I said to you before, I consider it a private meeting and what was discussed there in detail is not for public viewing.
But I think she sums up the whole issue when she says:
But I feel that crass politics now is being played by the Liberal Party. There's been political grandstanding from a party--
Opposition members interjecting--

TALK.START.PARA: —-Opposition members should listen to this because this summarises their attitude on the environment.

ANSWER.PARA: Government members interjecting--

TALK.START.PARA: —-Order! The House will come to order.
—-Why does the honourable member for Pearce not look at me? He runs away from the truth, does he not?

ANSWER.PARA: Honourable members interjecting--

TALK.START.PARA: —-Order! The House will come to order.
—-He does not like to face up to the truth, does he? He runs away from the truth. Let me sum up this whole incident. Ms Crisp continued:

ANSWER.PARA: There's been political grandstanding from a party--
Mr Filing interjecting--

TALK.START.PARA: —-I warn the honourable member for Moore.
—-She states:

ANSWER.PARA: There's been political grandstanding from a party that has totally and inadequate environment policies.

TALK.START.PARA: —-My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. Is the Minister aware of claims that the abolition of the existing wholesale sales tax and the introduction of a value added type of tax would be of benefit to both Telecom Australia and Australian telephone users? Will the Minister explain how such a tax charge would affect Telecom and telephone users?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Previously in this House and over the weekend in a note written in the Forbes Advocate by one of the Opposition's members, the honourable member for Parkes, the Opposition has suggested that the abolition of the wholesale sales tax on Telecom would liberate $375m, which could then be made available to the general public through something like a $50 saving on their annual telephone bill. Indeed, when the Opposition went through the consumption tax issue across the board, it made great play of the fact that there is a trade-off for a reduction in the wholesale sales tax and an elimination of the tax in some areas in the process of introducing the consumption tax. When I had the opportunity to read the propositions put forward by the honourable member for Parkes, the real situation was more clearly outlined. He said:

ANSWER.PARA: Under the coalition's tax reform proposals, including a goods and services tax, all the GST paid by Telecom on capital equipment purchases will be rebatable. That is, Telecom will get effectively a $375m boost to its capital equipment program.

That is exactly what I said when I answered a question on this matter in the House the other week. Telecom's management will have available to it any particular course of action it so chooses in regard to dealing with that $375m. It is not obliged to pass it on to the consumer if it obtains that money. It may indeed choose to use it in exactly the way the honourable member for Parkes suggested that it should, that is, by putting it into its capital works program. Of course, all sorts of other implications are raised by that, because Telecom does not operate in an isolated financial environment. Even though the Opposition has said that it will privatise Telecom, it would be some years before Telecom were privatised to the point where it was off the public sector borrowing requirement. In all likelihood, the Opposition of the day--having seen that $375m go to Telecom--would choose simply to take it off Telecom's borrowings that year as its borrowings basically tend to go to its capital equipment program. What would result would be no savings for those people who are Telecom's subscribers and, in the end, no benefit for Telecom's capital works program.

Having taken that $375m aside, the imposition of the consumption tax at a rate of 15 per cent has several effects. It has the effect of a $1.3 billion tax on Telecom's users. So far I have been using the $1.3 billion exclusively from Telecom, but sorrowfully over the last couple of weeks I have neglected to inform the House what it would mean for OTC. A VAT could conceivably collect an additional $225m from OTC. If the two figures are combined, we are talking about a $1.5 billion collection, at a rate of 15 per cent, from the Telecom user. As opposed to the $50 that would come off the bill of the average telephone user, this would add at least $205 per year to each subscriber's telephone bill--and that would be a modest estimate.

In the end we do not know at what rate a consumption tax would be set, so in answering the honourable member's question I am unable to advise him fully as to what the implications would be. However, we do know what some of the Opposition's Liberal colleagues think it might be. An interesting interview on the John Laws program was held with Dr Metherell. He said:

And Eric Risstrom said last night, and no-one disputed it, that the tax--I think it is in Sweden--is now up to 25 or 27% on goods and services having started down at 1 or 2%. And I know from somebody coming back from Italy walked into my office yesterday and said to me that the GST or VAT, its equivalent in Europe. . . in Italy is now up to 19%. So, you know, I suppose the big doubt in my mind is the will that politicians of all political parties have to reduce government expenditure if they have in their pocket a new tax that allows them to actually increase taxation--that's my real doubt.

May well he have those doubts, because that is exactly what the agenda of the Opposition is. Nobody in this country can now seriously believe--and nobody does seriously believe--that the last word on the consumption tax will be the rate at which it is released by the Opposition when it eventually gets around to doing it sometime between now and Christmas. Sometime between now and Christmas the Opposition will produce a number. The number will be interesting and it will be capable of analysis, but the number will be merely that--a number--because what lies behind it is an ongoing intention by the Opposition to keep ramping up that tax. It is a launching pad for a massive take from ordinary Australians to benefit the wealthy members of this community.
Mr Nugent interjecting--

TALK.START.PARA: —-Order! The member for Aston!
—-My question without notice is to the Prime Minister.
—-Order! The House will come to order. Members on my right!

—-Does the Prime Minister agree that the Premiers would sell their mothers for a few bucks, as claimed by the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories in relation to his new federalism policy? If so, could the Prime Minister identify which Premiers he has in mind?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I wonder whether I could have a few minutes to recover from this blow, Mr Speaker? It is a fantastic question. I know that the Opposition Leader is pretty much of an apprentice in politics, but let me inform him that in this federal system of ours we cannot always rely on getting bouquets from State politicians, even from those in one's own party. Mr Speaker, I know that you would find it very difficult to understand, but it has been known that some members of my party from your State at the State level have said less than complimentary things about me and my Government.
—-Terribly untrue, Prime Minister.
—-There are a lot in here as well.
—-Order! The member for Gippsland!

—-I might say that this has caused me considerable disquiet and some nights I have not been able to get to sleep worrying about the fact that these naughty State politicians, for the sake of trying to score a little political point, have had a shot at me.
—-What about the Federal ones?
—-Order! I warn the member for Gippsland.

—-May I say that I then go to sleep on the basis that I know that this is not an exclusive prerogative of members of the Labor Party at the State level. I will tell this newly arrived member of the Federal Parliament that it has even happened that Liberal Party politicians at the State level and National Party politicians at the State level----

ANSWER.PARA: Government members--Oh, no; no!

TALK.START.PARA: —-Yes, yes; seriously. They have had some tough things to say about their Federal party members. I say to the Leader of the Opposition that I do not think that these State Premiers, who are men and women of very considerable political experience, will lose very much sleep, if any at all, about the remarks that have been made in passing by my Minister for the Environment.

—-My question is to the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services. In light of today's release of the Australian Bureau of Statistics dwelling commencement figures for the June quarter, which showed that the housing industry has indeed moved into recovery, can the Minister inform the House of the developments to further promote the objective of providing more affordable housing?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: DEPUTY PRIME MINISTER; HEALTH, HOUSING AND COMMUNITY SERVICES

TALK.START.PARA: —-I thank the honourable member for her question, which concerned statistics released this morning by the ABS confirming that the housing recovery is under way and that commencements in the quarter have increased by 2.4 per cent over the March quarter. I might also note in passing that included in those figures was an increase in medium density housing in particular. Although this is an early figure, it is certainly consistent with the need that must be recognised to restructure the housing industry in this country, putting greater emphasis on medium density housing and providing a greater choice of housing.

ANSWER.PARA: Clearly, if we are going to be able to come out of the recession in terms of not only a strong recovery but also more affordable housing, it is important that the Commonwealth, together with the States and, importantly, local government, develop strategies that not only enable us to make housing more affordable and more accessible but also contribute to the task of building in this country cities which are more accessible and which display more equity.

I refer to the latest evidence about housing recovery which is on track with the forecast of the Indicative Planning Council. Of course, against that we need to take account of the fact that the Opposition has made, during a very difficult period in housing, very little contribution to any serious policy debate. We have heard virtually nothing from the Opposition about partnership with the States or restructuring of the housing industry. Of course, we have heard something about the Opposition's taxation policies, the details of which still need to be announced. We know that a goods and services tax would have quite an impact on home purchase--indeed, pushing the costs of both purchase and renting through the roof.

A 15 per cent tax--or would it be a 22 per cent tax?--on materials would push home purchase out of the reach of many families. It would erode savings and prolong the wait for many others. The tax would add to the already substantial costs of transacting home purchase. A 15 per cent tax would need to be added to bank loan charges, to agents' fees, to conveyancing costs, to stamp duties and to removal costs. This obscenity is illustrated by the comparison between the outcome of a prospective home buyer and the prospective buyer of a luxury car. On the equivalent price of a modest home or a Mercedes or BMW, say $100,000, the family seeking its new home would have to pay $115,000, not $100,000, while the luxury car buyer would pay only $85,000.

That is an example of tory, conservative, equity. On the one hand, we make luxury vehicles more affordable and cheaper. On the other hand, effectively, we say to the new home buyer, `Let's make that more expensive'. Interestingly enough, some conservative politicians who are moving around the electorate are beginning to be asked the sorts of very specific questions that we are expecting the Leader of the Opposition to be able to answer. We have already heard one reference to Dr Metherell, who is taking the opportunity now to get back to the grassroots and talk to people. He is finding that people are asking some very interesting questions.

In the interview referred to earlier he was asked about the difference between established and new houses. It was a question which he did not know the answer to, so he approached Senator Bronwyn Bishop. Senator Bishop was able, apparently, to satisfy Dr Metherell with an answer. As he said, she tried to give him an open and an honest answer. The answer that she was able to provide, although these details are not yet clear, was that if one was buying an established house there would be no 15 per cent, as in New Zealand, but for a new house the 15 per cent would apply.
Extraordinarily, for Dr Metherell, now back in contact with his electorate, that raises a question of equity. I just conclude by quoting from Dr Metherell. He said:

Now, O.K., that may answer the question but it raises a new question in my mind: how do I say to a young family going out to western Sydney, `You're going to pay a 15 per cent tax on a new house out there and if I sold a house in Frenchs Forest that's an established house, I don't pay the tax'.
Dr Metherell continued:
Now that doesn't seem to me very equitable and very reasonable as a political proposition put to young families in western Sydney.

That is the difference between the Government and the Opposition. In terms of Government housing policy, we are about making housing more affordable and more acceptable and we are about dealing with the problems of access in cities and responding to the needs of people. If people contrast our policy with that of the Opposition, whether it is in terms of BMWs over and against new houses or whether it is in terms of disability payments over and against certain types of luxury car, they will make a choice; they will have to live with that choice.
Dr Hewson interjecting--

TALK.START.PARA: —-Order! The Leader of the Opposition will cease interjecting!
—-We will be out there talking to the ordinary people about equity and fairness. Frankly, they will agree with us.
—-Mr Speaker, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.
