DEBATE.TITLE: DISCUSSION OF MATTER OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —-I have received a letter from the honourable member for Barker (Mr McLachlan) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The urgent need for a non-inflationary pro- growth, pro-investment, pro-jobs strategy to counter the devastating impact of the Government's anti- investment policies.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places--

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLachlan Mr I.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —- There is no doubt that what this country needs is growth, investment and jobs--things that this Government has not provided for a long time. There is no doubt that the country needs to go back to the business of creating wealth--new wealth created by new mines, new industry, new industrial relations arrangements and sensible cost saving proceedings at every level of Australian business and at every level of Australian life. Until we have made the changes that are necessary, we will not get a new sense of direction and excitement in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: Not long ago at a lunch in Hobart the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), when addressing a business group and discussing the subject of Coronation Hill, said:

When Aboriginal people take a view that it would be sacrilegious desecration of a sacred site to proceed, they are entitled to have that taken as determining the issue. . . When it is a matter of whether something should proceed, that is only one amongst a number of issues.

In effect, he said that if Aboriginal people take the view that it would be sacrilegious desecration to proceed, that was the preclusive determinant. The Prime Minister is saying that it does not matter what venture one had in mind, whether it be mining, forestry, pulp mills, perhaps even farming--or will that be part of a `better farming' program in the future--and no matter whether that venture would produce more wealth, jobs or vitally needed investor confidence for future ventures, which we are so short of in this country, a group of Australians will have exclusive autonomy over a decision concerning development in Australia if they judge that they should have it. In this case he was talking about 300 Australians having exclusive autonomy if they judge that they should have it. That is what he said in Hobart on 26 June, so we can only assume that that is what he meant. We can imagine how much excitement that produced amongst those lunch guests.

Can it possibly be true that the other Government members believe this? Do they believe all this nonsense? We know that the Prime Minister had submerged a Cabinet decision on the subject of Coronation Hill; but do Government members really support the view that a small group of Australians should have the preclusive determination of an investment of $2 billion or more? I do not. Where, we might ask, are those staunch defenders of human rights, the rights of the human race in this country--the press, which always leaves the gallery during these debates on MPIs--whilst the Prime Minister has lost his senses? There has not been much commentary on this sad state of affairs.

I believe that the beliefs of the Jawoyn tribe, Christians or any other religious group should be respected, but not to the exclusion of all else. To ask us to swallow that this self- confessed agnostic who sits on the other side of the table really believes that he has embraced the spirit of Bula with Shi-ite fervour is just too much. In fact, if we say those two words together quickly enough, we will get a much closer approximation of what I think of the Prime Minister's latter-day conversion. If Government members do not think so, they are letting down this country, because it is a damn lot of nonsense.

Combine this with the conservation--or should I say `preservation'--lobby and some of the bureaucratic delays that we have been having in this country for many a year now, and we can quite quickly arrive at a figure of $15 billion of investment not undertaken or delayed or locked up. Fifteen billion dollars is quite a lot of money. The investment that has not been undertaken must be much more than that because of the atmosphere of despair amongst those who wish to develop this country. That $15 billion worth of investment has been impounded or locked up. Looking at some of those investments, we see that in one case we had an investment of over $2 billion, seven investments of over $1 billion and 20- odd investments that add up to that sort of figure.

I spend a little of my spare time--what little spare time we have--on wetlands and reafforestation projects; some of them commercial but not very successful. But that coalition of interests called Aboriginal rights and preservationists' whim simply has gone too far in this country. Altogether that combination has cost us at least $15 billion in investment; therefore, jobs directly employing tens of thousands of people have been opposed or delayed and, in some cases, simply shut down. So we have forgone the resultant $3 billion of income that Australians would have received from that--or, at a local level, $300 of household income per annum--let alone the indirect wealth it would have created.

The second much talked about area is the cost of failing to implement reforms on the waterfront, in rail, in post and telecommunications, in assistance--although it is just starting--and the failure to contract out government services. What are the costs of being so uncompetitive? The costs of not being competitive, as identified by the Industry Commission, include: transport, $6.7 billion; rail, $4 billion; post and telecommunications, $1.7 billion; contracting out not done by this Government, $3.4 billion; assistance reform not carried out by this Government, $3.7 billion; and electricity not done by this Government, $1.4 billion. If we had reformed our waterworks, as the Prime Minister had done not long ago, we could have saved another $1 billion. That alone would have provided a 7 per cent reduction in the level of prices in this country--in other words, in inflation--and produced thousands of extra jobs. The equation comes out at another $2,300 per household. Our running total is now $2,600 per household, per annum, income forgone. We then have to add the great cost of the accord--yes, the cost of the accord--because we can measure that cost these days. But before we measure that cost, I think we ought to look at somebody else's view of this tragedy.
I have in my hand a document produced by Peter Hartley and Michael Porter of the Tasman Institute. They have called the article, `Treasurer Keating's Legacy.'

TALK.START.PARA: —-Gap! Where is his gap?
—-The gap is coming in just a minute. There are several gaps to which I will refer. Let me repeat what they said about this legacy in the article in which they describe the Keating gap:

SPEECH.PARA: At the end of the day, it is Keating's adherence to the Accord that must be held accountable for much of the unfinished business in micro-economic reform. The Accord is the classic example of Keating's deal-making, of centralism, of excluding individuals and groups of individuals from negotiating the terms of their own agreements to trade.
There is another comment:
The Accord gave the ACTU an effective veto over micro-economic reforms.
The third comment reads:
In the end, these deals also destroy many opportunities for growth in productive employment, opportunities and real wages.
That is what these gentlemen said. They also said that the accord, implemented with the ACTU, had provided those tragic results.

It is incredible to think that just this week people associated with the ACTU who have been part of that accord, part of that disaster and part of that dereliction of duty to this country are now calling for pump-priming exercises. They are waiting at the pump to have it primed. They were sitting at a conference bemoaning the fact that unemployment is ravaging the country, and they caused a lot of it. They did that, and this Government did that, in that reactionary process. The fact of the matter is that this Government has become a reactionary government--a government of no ideas, no investment and no jobs.

I wonder whether people in this Government really think that the Business Council of Australia was wrong when it stated that there was another $20 billion to be picked up by making the labour market competitive. I have never heard one member of the Government refer to that figure. I have never heard anybody analyse it, say it was right, or say it was wrong. All I have heard is that the Government is far enough along the way towards arranging its industrial relations changes to the procedures that already exist so that the reforms will take place.

Those reforms will not take place, and they are not taking place. Let me add them up: $22 billion for micro-economic reform; $14 billion for debt liabilities; $21 billion for industrial relations inefficiencies; $4 billion for the GST--it will be possible to pick up $4 billion if the Government wants to have a GST; and $3 billion for lost investment. The total is $64 billion in lost opportunities, minimum. That is $6,500 per household or 150,000 direct jobs not provided by this Government.

Who causes all of this? The Prime Minister, whose gap in logic is such that he can perpetrate the Bula nonsense and whose memory gap is such that he can perpetuate the quiet myth that corporate profits and profit share have been higher under Labor than at any other time, causes all of this. This assertion is not true; in fact, in gross operating services the share is higher. When company tax is added, it is still quite high; but when interest rates are added, it is on the way to rock bottom. That is the secret underlying Australia's economic disaster. It is, in fact, the Keating gap, as described in the document to which I have referred.

It is not memory failure about telephone calls to and from Mr Robert Holmes a Court; nor is it the gap between 44 and 66. It is the gap in inflation costs between us and the rest of the world between 1984 and 1990, and it consequentially becomes the gap in interest rates between us and the rest of the world. The inflation rates in the document are shown in orange and they are changing to red. If we examine what has really happened, we see that we have finished up with an enormous excess in interest rates which has devastated this country.

Consequentially, it is the gap between our interest rates and those of the rest of the world that has broken half a nation and sent the other half reeling. This is the gap that has caused the Reserve Bank to say that Australia has $29 billion in non-performing debt, which is a fraction over the level of shareholders' funds; this is the gap that will cause much of that debt to be written off; this is the gap that has broken 100,000 businesses in the last 12 months, which will soon result in a million people being out of work.

There are billions of dollars of investment opportunities out there for the taking. Investors are waiting for the right signals; they are waiting for people to make the types of decisions that will get them excited again--the types of decisions that they can trust; and they are waiting for the types of decisions that will give them the idea that whatever arrangements they make with a government, either at the State level or federally, will stick.

There are even more billions of dollars waiting not only for future investment but to be saved and thus reinvested in the new wealth creating activity that I have just described. Is it $60 billion, or is it much more than that? My guess is that the amount is much more than that. It is true that, if we give this country a chance, we will find out whether it is $60 billion or more than that. If the Government is not going to ring the changes, then the Opposition will.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Free The Hon R.V.

TALKER.NAME: Mr FREE
TALKER.ROLE: -Minister for Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —-The honourable member for Barker (Mr McLachlan) has called for a non-inflationary, pro-growth, pro- investment and pro-job strategy. I am pleased to inform the honourable member for Barker that this Government already has one. Evidence will increasingly emerge to show that this Government has produced the right policy mix to ensure that this country comes out of the recession into a period of sustained non- inflationary growth.

SPEECH.PARA: I listened in vain throughout the speech made by the honourable member for Barker for news of alternatives from the Opposition, because politics is about alternatives. At election time, particularly, it is about choices. What alternative policy descriptions or choices did the honourable member for Barker offer the House this afternoon? The answer is none. Instead, in a series of cheap jibes he attacked the beliefs of some original Australians. I say to the honourable member for Barker: there is no substitute for the hard slog involved in building proper policies. I must say that I am disappointed to see him emerge in this place this afternoon as the master of the cheap shot because I believe his supporters have the right to expect more.

TALK.START.PARA: —-He has written all of this before he heard the speech of the honourable member for Barker.
—- Order! The honourable member for Gippsland will remain silent. The previous speaker was heard in silence, and the Minister will be heard in silence, too.

—-During Question Time today, evidence was given to show that the recovery process is well and truly under way. Without doubt, Australia is emerging from the recession. We are emerging in better shape because the macro-economic settings are right. Fiscal policy is structurally correct, and it has been clear in relation to wages policy that the accord has been essential in producing the current low levels of inflation. Inflation is presently running at record low levels--a fact that the Opposition never likes to acknowledge; nevertheless, it is true.

SPEECH.PARA: In regard to monetary policy, I point out that interest rates are now down by 8.5 percentage points since their peak. Unemployment is this Government's major concern--of course it is, because by and large our people are suffering. As the Treasurer (Mr Kerin) has indicated, unemployment levels will always lag, but the numbers of unemployed will certainly come down and employment opportunities will grow in a sustainable way.

We occasionally see members of the Opposition cry crocodile tears for the unemployed. One might well ask: what exactly does the Opposition have in mind for unemployed people? It wants to chop the dole after nine months. Its cuts would undoubtedly lead to the destruction of labour market programs.

Let us have a closer look at some of the Opposition's proposals. This matter of public importance calls for a non-inflationary strategy. What does that mean? Are members of the Opposition talking about zero inflation? If they are, how do they intend to achieve it? Are they going to achieve it through monetary policy? If they are, then interest rates will be higher for longer than they have ever been before. It should be remembered that this matter of public importance has been brought on by an Opposition that has opposed every drop in interest rates, including the most recent one. There is no doubt that this Opposition wants interest rates higher and that it wants them higher for longer.

Let us look now at fiscal policy. Once upon a time, the Opposition had a policy to cut $3 billion off government expenditure. It has even said that the last Budget could have been balanced. That would have resulted in cuts of $4.7 billion. We are entitled to ask from this side of the House and from the wider community: where exactly would these cuts come from? They can only come from where the Opposition has flagged privatisation--privatisation of social security, to begin with. And how high would interest rates have to go with its 15 per cent to 22 per cent GST?

Quite frankly, if one looks at the Opposition's policies, one sees regression running right through them: the consumption tax; the abolition of company tax; the abolition of the capital gains tax; the levying of income tax

by the States, for heaven's sake; zero wage increases, and that zero inflation target to be brought about by that draconian monetary policy, by education vouchers and by health vouchers; and no lump sums for workers until they are aged 65. That $4.7 billion cut in government spending will be levied mainly on the weak and the defenceless in the community. No Opposition in my time in parliament has ever campaigned on a more regressive policy than that.

Returning briefly to the Opposition's GST--it will add to inflation, on some counts, by around 7 per cent. This is coming from an Opposition whose representative today is calling for a non-inflationary strategy. A GST will add to inflation and will not wash out of the system. Some proponents on the Opposition side have argued that a GST will boost national savings and thereby provide additional funds for investment. There is no proof for the claim that a GST will add to savings and release funds for investment. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a table which provides the evidence for that statement.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —-Provided that table meets the guidelines set by the Speaker, it will be incorporated.

INTERJECT.PARA: [TBLE OMITTED FROM DATABASE - SEE HARD COPY PAGE 1120]

TALK.START.PARA: —-Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. The table shows net household savings as a percentage of disposable income for the OECD countries. The evidence from the examination of trends in saving ratios in other OECD countries, many of which have consumption taxes, shows no correlation between tax mix and savings. If one conducts a horizontal analysis--that is, examining one country over time, measuring savings ratios before and after the introduction of a consumption tax--no pattern of increase can be discerned. Alternatively, a vertical analysis-- that is, examining different countries with different tax mixes during a fixed period--also shows no evidence to support the hypothesis that a consumption tax increases savings.

SPEECH.PARA: Looking at most of those countries, it is obvious that since the early 1970s there has been a downward trend in savings. The trend has been just as marked in countries which have had consumption taxes for the whole period. Sweden, for example, introduced a consumption tax in 1969. In 1974, it had net household savings of 5 per cent, but by 1990 that ratio was minus 0.2 per cent. Italy introduced its tax in 1973. Gross household savings in that country went from 26.3 per cent in 1974 to 15.1 per cent in 1990. So much for the argument that a GST will add to savings and so boost investment!

As the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) said today, there are many people in the Opposition parties who are running from the idea of a GST at 100 miles an hour--or perhaps that should be 122 1/2 miles an hour. Certainly, the Nationals are in Western Australia; certainly the Nationals are in Queensland; certainly Wal Murray is in New South Wales--and a consumption tax is about the only thing that could get the Deputy Premier of New South Wales running, I can tell you. That tax expert from the New South Wales Opposition, Dr Terry Metherell, hates a consumption tax, and this is one instance of course in which he is right.
I say again to the honourable member for Barker that the economy is on the road to recovery. As the Treasurer told EPAC at its most recent meeting on Friday last, this Budget:

is a Budget which reinforces the Government's overall economic strategy of ensuring that the recovery in prospect in the short-term is converted into sustained medium-term growth . . . the fundamental objective of economic policy is to achieve strong but sustainable economic growth.

We want to build on the gains that have been made. We want to lock in recent gains which have been made against inflation; we want to reduce the current account deficit with a view to stabilising our external debt relative to GDP; and we want to promote sustainable reductions in the level of unemployment. Government policy is directed towards those ends of promoting a sustainable recovery in a non-inflationary environment because, with lower inflation, we should see better quality investment and we should see more of it.

It would be foolish to attempt to attain these goals at the cost of an economic scorched earth policy, which, in many respects, is what the Opposition would seek to do. Those in our community who are least able to protect themselves would suffer most. The Treasurer is right when he says that achieving these goals requires a balance in economic policy. In the short term, our objective is to manage the recovery carefully. We need to coordinate those main arms of macro-economic policy to which I referred--fiscal, monetary and wages policy--so that the appropriate degree of stimulus can be delivered at the appropriate time.

Our balanced approach contrasts with that of our political opponents, who say that in the 1991-92 Budget there should have been no deficit. Apparently, they believe, and persist in the belief, that those outlays could have been cut by another $4.7 billion. As I mentioned earlier, I wonder where those cuts would have fallen? Who would have paid for them? Would it have been the pensioners? Would it have been the sick? It certainly would have been the unemployed, Aborigines, families and single parents. What an impact on the economy that would have made. In fact, such a prescription shows a remarkable disregard for the aspirations of ordinary Australians, with whom the honourable member for Barker mixes so infrequently. According to those economic models which the Opposition itself relies on, such a policy prescription would involve significant additional job losses--possibly up to 50,000 in the coming year.

The honourable member for Barker has referred to the Government's policies by the descriptive term `anti-investment policies'. Let me go briefly to the recent history of investment in Australia. Private business investment as a share of our GDP reached record levels in the year 1989-90, when it was 13.2 per cent, compared with a long term average of 11.2 per cent, reflecting strong growth in both the traded and the non-traded sector investment since 1983-84, the year in which we came to office. Honourable members opposite should study Budget chart No. 4, which looks at investment performance since the early 1950s, before making too many comparisons with the past.

Why has this investment occurred? I refer to some underlying reasons. There have been strong average growth rates over the second part of the 1980s, originally driven by domestic demand, and now we expect to be driven by export growth. Increasingly over those years, the profit share of GDP has increased, and also over those years we have experienced falling real unit labour costs, down by 10 per cent since the mid-1980s. There has been a greater recognised need for business to improve its competitiveness as tariffs have come down.

I refer briefly in the time I have remaining to an investment update. If the performance has been so bad, I would be interested in the comments of the supporting Opposition speaker on some of these examples of investments made recently or planned. In the food processing area we have: at Blayney in the central west of New South Wales a $25m investment by Nestle in a pet food plant; in Wodonga, Uncle Ben's pet food plant, a $130m investment; Kellogg at Botany, an investment of over $30m; and at Manildra, again in New South Wales, an investment of $40m.

In the pulp and paper industry we have: Pratt Group's VisyBoard plant in Melbourne, an investment of $100m; tissue paper plants by Kimberly-Clark, an investment of $100m; and by Bowater in Victoria of $100m. In the chemicals industry: ICI has invested $100m in a polyethylene plant at Botany; Shell has an investment in its polypropylene plant at Clyde of $170m; and Altona Petro-Chemicals has investments in ethylene and polyethylene plants of $150m.

In the area of basic metals, BHP has raw steel expansion plans worth $1.15 billion. As an example, there has been a $200m investment in a continuous caster at Whyalla. We have Alcoa's expansion to its alumina refinery in Western Australia worth $300m. There was Toyota's announcement in July of its decision to build a new car manufacturing plant at Altona in Melbourne. I refer to the portfolio Minister's press release of April 1991 expressing delight--well might he express delight--at the decision by the Boeing aeroplane company to sign contracts worth an estimated $455m with two Australian aerospace companies. It is the largest single order ever placed by an overseas company with the Australian aerospace industry. It was announced earlier this year that $600m would be spent on the expansion of the Tomago smelter in the Hunter region. There have been further investments in the motor vehicle industry as well. Pacific Dunlop has said it will be entering the food processing industry in Australia.

In other words, our record throughout this difficult period in investment gives every reason for us to look towards the future with optimism to see that we will come out of this recession with sustained, non-inflationary growth. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cobb Mr M.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I was interested to listen to the delivery of the previous speaker, the honourable member for Lindsay (Mr Free). I never cease to be fascinated by listening to honourable members from the Government side. If we took what they said at face value we would think the country was going well. I do not know whether they ever get on a plane to travel out of Canberra and go to places such as Victoria to walk up and down the main streets of country towns to see what is going on but, from listening to those opposite we would think the country was going well, for heaven's sake!

SPEECH.PARA: There was no hint of reality in the delivery of the previous speaker. He spent most of the first half of his speech talking about how bad a goods and services tax is going to be. Again, there was no mention that the sales tax that the Government has been administering has tripled in the time it has been in office. It has gone from about $3.5 billion to about $10.5 billion, though it would be marginally below that now as a result of the recession. But there has not been a cent of compensation to the poor. The honourable member talked about the regressive nature of this tax, but there has not been one cent of compensation to the poor from a tax that the Government has tripled in the short few years it has been in office. I advise the honourable member that the goods and services tax will at least be an honest, fair and equitable tax. There will be full compensation to those minority groups which are disadvantaged.

I travelled to New Zealand recently and spent a week there talking to groups right across the political spectrum. I did not meet one person--whether it be from the left, the centre or the right, or whether they be poor, rich or whatever--who wanted to go back to the system they had before.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The system we have now.

—-The system we have now, as the honourable member for Dawson interjects so correctly. Everybody there may have had a grumble or two about it, but they said it was fair or equitable or that it was better; and at least it was an honest tax. But getting back to the state that Australia is in today, by almost any criteria which are applied Australia is in an absolute mess--a stagnant mess--which is not what it should be in. The degree and the depth of this mess is almost entirely of the Government's making. Australia, even by the Government's own admission, is in a recession. If one talked to lots of groups out there, one would find they are saying Australia is in a depression. I can attest that that is what they are saying out in the countryside.
—-The Minister said we were coming out of it.

—-The Minister has a lot to learn. We have almost a disinvestment policy in this country today. I would invite the Minister or any honourable member of the Government--I do not know whether they do these things--to walk into a shopping centre, particularly in a country town, and stand for a while and have a look around. They should not be fooled by the facade of activity they might see. I invite them to look a little closer, to examine the empty shopfronts that are in the shopping centres now. It is quite frightening. They will see in almost every shopping centre signs for a closing down sale in at least one or two businesses. If they stroll into the businesses that are still operating and talk to the owners, they will be told about the distress of trying to meet wage deadlines or trying to service overdraft commitments and things like that.

SPEECH.PARA: If honourable members then look around outside the shopping centres they will see the unemployed youth drifting around aimlessly. There are plenty of them to see because one in every three in this country who now wants a job cannot get one--an horrific figure. Over and above that we have a phenomenon in this country that we have not seen for over half a century: the unemployed in the over 40-year- old group. They will be wandering around too, faces almost as vacant as the shopfronts that I was talking about earlier. They are expressionless and shattered. These people are wondering what they are going to do. They are waiting for the next election when they can vote this Government out of office. We have almost a million people in this country unemployed today and probably half as many again underemployed, working 15 or 20 hours a week, when they would work 35, 40 or more hours a week if they had the chance.

The Government's answer to all this is to spend more money in job creation programs, and this sort of nonsense. It does not seem to be able to grasp that these people will not be employed properly and for a long period of time unless they get a genuine job. Implementing the programs the Government is trying to put in place costs money. Where does that money come from? It comes from increasing taxes. Increasing taxes ultimately puts someone else out of a job. So we have got a million or more people around Australia today whose dignity is stripped away. It is a tragedy, especially because there is no need for so much of this.

Sure, times are tough in the world and, sure, there is a flatness in commodity prices, but much of what we are experiencing today is of the Government's own making. The opportunities that this Government has let slip, the project applications that have been refused, and the sensible solutions which have been suggested but ignored are a millstone around this Government's neck.

What other country would hinder, let alone ban, the starting up of such major projects as the Wesley Vale pulp mill in Tasmania, the Coronation Hill mineral project in the Northern Territory that the honourable member for Barker (Mr McLachlan) referred to, or the third runway development at Sydney Airport? Why would the Government want to stop these projects, for heaven's sake? It is done for blatant, political reasons, all to do with keeping the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in his job.

The honourable member for Barker has referred to $15 billion of investment that has slipped away and to the fact that the Industry Commission has identified $22 billion in micro-reform savings which is out there just going begging. I refer to two or three of these projects--firstly, the pulp mill in Tasmania. That was put on hold and stopped purely to get the greenie preferences at the last election. It mattered not that this pulp mill would have been the cleanest in the world. It matters not, now, that we have to buy these products from overseas mills that are less environmentally friendly than this one would have been in Tasmania, and it matters not that this value adding opportunity has been let go, with hundreds of jobs sacrificed and with Tasmania put in a worse position than it would otherwise have been in.

What about Coronation Hill? Hundreds of millions of dollars profit slipped by there. There was the loss of hundreds of jobs--many of them Aboriginal jobs. So much for the compassion that this Government talks about here every day about workers in remote areas and about Aborigines. There is this affected sincerity that it exudes all the time----

TALK.START.PARA: —-No social justice.

—-No social justice, as the honourable member for Dawson says. Then there is the third runway at Sydney Airport. That is another area of complete Government paralysis. Everyone who has looked at that project rationally agrees that it should be built and should have been built years ago. It would cut the noise down; it would be safer; it would be more convenient; it would expand the capacity of the airport; and it would get jobs and the economy going down in that area. But the Government's only answer seems to be rationing. This is the typical socialist solution: ration something.

SPEECH.PARA: People who have never created anything in their lives say they are rationing by bringing in this peak period landing charge of $250 a movement, whether it be for a small or large plane. That is killing country air services and has reduced the people in my electorate to second class citizens, in effect.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Second-class representation.
—-It is second-class representation for the honourable member for Lindsay, I can tell him, and for his neighbour next door.

SPEECH.PARA: Hazelton Airlines has just shut down services in the towns. It has reduced its staff from 169 to 109--pilots, engineers and others have been put off in country towns needlessly. Fleet aircraft will have to be reduced from 18 to 12. Some of them will probably be sold overseas and the country airports will become even less viable than they are now. The councils cannot fund these country airstrips now and government charges are going up all the time. Five years ago they were 2 per cent of the ticket, today they are 17.6 per cent of the cost of the ticket--almost a nine-fold increase. That is $25 on the price of a ticket from Dubbo to Sydney.

This is Government policy. This is the Government's answer to the country which it says is running well. It is actually going backwards. All this is done to save the Prime Minister's job and is nothing to do with the good of the country at all. It is almost traitorous and treasonable behaviour. As soon as the people of Australia have an opportunity to go to the ballot box to reverse these insane policies the better.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bevis Mr A.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I have listened for 25 minutes to the honourable member for Barker (Mr McLachlan) and the honourable member for Parkes (Mr Cobb) speak about this MPI. During those 25 minutes they have managed to identify three things they would do. For all of those ills which they identify and claim exist within the country, they have three programs that will rectify the problems--mine Coronation Hill, put in the Wesley Vale pulp mill and build a third runway at Sydney Airport.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to say a couple of things about that before I speak about the MPI. The building of the third runway is a decision that the Government has made and, in spite of the misgivings that some members on both sides of the House have, it will, in fact, proceed. So far as Coronation Hill and Wesley Vale are concerned I thought it interesting that the shadow Minister for the Environment, the honourable member for Pearce (Mr Chaney) was not here because, with his renewed Green credentials of the last couple of days I would have welcomed his contribution to that debate. I look forward to his contribution the next opportunity he has in this place to tell us what his view is on those two matters.

I want to spend some time speaking about the MPI. When I read the MPI I found it very interesting. It is a collection of cliches that look as if they have been picked up at a jargon jumble sale and put together for the purposes of today's debate. Instead of talking around the issue, I want to address a couple of those items that do impinge upon employment and investment in this country--things like interest rates, Budget policy, industrial relations, industry policy and national savings.

I wish to start with interest rates because that is timely. It is not that long ago that we saw a substantial one per cent fall in interest rates. In fact, over the last 18 months we have seen interest rates come down by 8 1/2 per cent. On nearly every occasion that interest rates fell, members of the Opposition, including the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) and the shadow Treasurer, have attacked the Government. On the most recent occasion, when interest rates fell by one per cent, they failed to endorse it and have attacked it as being a decision that was made without economic merit.

They should come clean with the people of this country. They should come clean with the Parliament. They should be able to stand up in here and tell us what their policy is on interest rates. At the end of 1990 when we started to bring interest rates down they attacked us; in 1991 when we brought interest rates down they attacked us; and, last week, when interest rates came down, they attacked us again. Their policy is to maintain a high interest rate regime--to squeeze the people of Australia harder, tighter and for longer than this Government would ever contemplate and longer than the people of Australia could tolerate.

Home loan interest rates are now well below the old fixed rate level. Home loan interest rates are now available at 12 1/2 per cent, which is a lower level than they have been for nigh on a decade. That is an achievement which all people in this place should welcome but there has not been one word of praise from the Opposition, only criticism and attack that interest rates have fallen. In spite of the fact that those things have happened and in spite of the fact that the long term interest rate is now lower than it has been for more than a decade, those in the Opposition have a policy that would maintain higher interest rates.

Let us turn to the Budget because the Budget is a key vehicle through which the economy can be stimulated and jobs created. The Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Free) has already referred to the Opposition's position on this. The Opposition maintains a policy of a balanced Budget this year. Last year, when we had a budgeted surplus, that was not good enough. Opposition members did not want to balance the Budget--they did not even want to accept the surplus that we had. Last year they advocated a $3 billion cut over and above the surplus that we had budgeted for.

This year the Government has budgeted for a $4.7 billion deficit. The Opposition is now saying that $4.7 billion deficit should not occur and that there should be a balanced Budget. There are only two ways to do that: either generate another $4.7 billion worth of revenue--and that means taxes; or cut expenditure. Members of the Opposition have failed throughout the period since the Budget was delivered to identify which of those two courses they prefer and to set out clearly for the Australian people what its policy is.

Let us make no mistake about it, a $4.7 billion cut will hurt ordinary Australians--it will hurt the people who are unemployed and it will hurt the people who are now in employment. The sorts of initiatives that we have introduced in this Budget go to issues such as Austudy--creating greater opportunities for Australians, young and old, to enter and re- enter the education system; and the family allowance supplement, where thousands more families will be able to receive that benefit of government payment. They are the sorts of provisions that those opposite want to cut, yet they parade themselves as in some way endeavouring to stimulate the economy and provide some assistance to those in our community who need it most.

The real test comes with employment. Twelve months ago when the Opposition was parading its policies of reducing government spending the National Institute of Economic and Industry Research estimated the effects that a $2.1 billion reduction in recurrent expenditure would have on various aspects of our economy. I want to refer, importantly, to the area of employment. I remind the House that it is a $2.1 billion cut which these projections are based on. The people opposite want us to take out of the Budget more than twice that in the current year.

Had there been a $2.1 billion cut in government outlays for recurrent expenditure in the financial year just ended, the Institute forecast that unemployment in 1992 would rise by an additional 60,000 people and by 1993 it would rise by 80,000 people. Those opposite want to double that figure this year. The policies of the people opposite in this place would, in fact, put on the unemployment list within two years an additional 120,000 to 160,000 Australians. Those are the policies which the Opposition has announced in other places. These are the estimates of independent research on Opposition policies, yet members of the Opposition have the gall to stand here in this place on a matter of public importance with a jumble of jargon and fail to substantiate it with any comment in the debate.

I will turn to industry policy. I am glad that it was the honourable member for Barker who moved this MPI because on an earlier occasion I had the opportunity to refer to this article. I am pleased he is here because it is an article that mentions him. One of the key areas of industry policy development over the last decade has been the vehicle industry. Recently, the honourable member for Barker was featured in an article in the Bulletin magazine that looked at the Opposition's policy affecting the vehicle industry. The Bulletin magazine article was headlined, `Libs pull the wheels off the car plan'. The article went on to state:
Australia's car-makers are running scared of a coalition victory in the next federal election.

What is the reason? It goes on to explain that the honourable member for Barker addressed a Federal Chamber of Automotive Industries meeting and told it about the savage cuts he would make in the future industry plan and protection plan that this Government has put in place which is known, gradual and accepted by the industry and the trades union movement alike. The honourable member for Barker went to a meeting of those employers and managed to frighten the wits out of them. They do not want him and they do not want his policies either.

Let us look at the question of the pool of funds in Australia. One of the difficulties we have as a nation is the size of our population, the size of our domestic market and, partly as a factor of that, the size of the pool of funds that are here onshore to invest. One of the initiatives that this Government has taken, which is designed primarily to improve the quality of life of Australian citizens in retirement, is to promote and establish superannuation schemes for all. This is not just for the elite, not just for public servants and not just for the high fliers in the private sector who can get non-contributory superannuation where they do not pay a cent and the employer pays the lot. It used to be a good tax dodge once upon a time; that loophole has been closed.

We have introduced a process whereby all Australians, irrespective of where they work, can reasonably expect to benefit from a superannuation scheme. One of the benefits of that is that it will provide a substantial pool of funds onshore here in Australia to be invested in Australia's future. It is an initiative which we all should applaud, though those in the Opposition do not. In 1986, when award superannuation was first introduced to cover everybody, the Opposition and its employer friends opposed it and said it would wreck the economy and they could not afford it. Some five or six years on we have introduced a guarantee levy in the Budget to ensure that all Australians are covered. The Opposition has again opposed it, saying, `We support the idea in principle but not now'.

The Opposition's position on economic management has been discredited time and again in this place. When it comes clean with the Australian people and puts its policies before the public it will reap the consequences of those policies, which aim to assist the privileged in our society at the cost of ordinary Australian wage and salary earners.

TALK.START.PARA: —- The debate has concluded.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Joint Standing Committee on the Parliamentary Zone

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Public Works Committee: Stage 3 Development of RAAF Base, Tindal, Northern Territory

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baldwin The Hon P.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BALDWIN
TALKER.ROLE: -Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —-On behalf of the Minister for Small Business and Customs (Mr Beddall), who represents the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus), I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, the following proposed work be referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works for consideration and report: Stage 3 Development of RAAF Base, Tindal, Northern Territory.

Following parliamentary approval in 1984, RAAF base Tindal was redeveloped as a home base for 75 Squadron and it has been re-equipped with Hornet aircraft. Stage 1 of the development provided essential facilities consisting of operational, technical support and domestic facilities, aircraft pavements and associated engineering services. Construction began in 1984 and critical facilities were completed in time for flying operations to begin in October 1988. This stage is now substantially complete at a cost of approximately $251m.

The second stage of development received parliamentary approval in 1988 and consists of the replacement of interim equipment, warehouse and general engineering workshop facilities and the augmentation of stage 1 facilities. Subsequent to parliamentary approval, stage 2 development was divided into three phases for programming reasons. The first phase is complete and the second phase is under construction. The third phase has been deferred.

This motion now refers to stage 3 of the development and will involve the provision of air defence facilities, comprising the sector operational centre and No. 2 control and reporting unit headquarters, live-in accommodation associated with the projected personnel increases stemming from the air defence facilities, deployed squadron operational and technical facilities, aircraft pavements, aircraft shelters and associated engineering services.

With the operational commissioning of the stage 1 facilities, RAAF base Tindal has become the major technical fighter base in northern Australia and is the focus of air operations in the north. However, the base can accommodate only a single squadron of Hornet aircraft and some transit aircraft, and the deployment of military aircraft is hampered by the lack of ordnance loading areas. This also presents some limitations on the use of the nearby air weapons range by deployed squadrons.

The operational capability of the airfield needs to be enhanced. This is planned to be achieved by providing an additional dispersal area with the ordnance loading aprons and additional taxiways which will enhance aircraft traffic management and aircraft deployment capability. Relocation of No. 2 control and reporting units at Tindal accords with Defence's intention to transfer many of RAAF Darwin's functions to Tindal. It is planned to coordinate this with an air defence equipment replacement program currently scheduled for 1984. No further major development proposals for Tindal are foreseen at present.

The estimate for these works is $53.5m at April 1991 prices. It is planned that the work will go to tender in March 1992, with completion by 1996. I table selected drawings of the proposed stage 3 development at RAAF base Tindal and I commend the motion to the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Public Works Committee: North Ryde, New South Wales--CSIRO Redevelopment

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baldwin The Hon P.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BALDWIN
TALKER.ROLE: -Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —-On behalf of the Minister for Small Business and Customs (Mr Beddall), who represents the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus), I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, the following proposed work be referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works for consideration and report: North Ryde, New South Wales--CSIRO Redevelopment.

In April 1989 the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works recommended to Parliament the construction of the stage 1 redevelopment facilities at CSIRO North Ryde at an estimated cost of $18 1/2m at August 1988 prices. CSIRO sought funds in the Budget context for this development to proceed. However, funds were not provided and it was decided that the project should be funded through rationalising CSIRO's property holdings at North Ryde. A review of the North Ryde site was undertaken and a redevelopment strategy proposed. The strategy involved the identification of staged development and release of certain lands for high technology business park purposes. The proceeds from the staged land releases would be used to consolidate CSIRO activities on the site and upgrade and replace substandard facilities.

The main elements of the proposed strategy are: a rationalisation and consolidation of the CSIRO accommodation at North Ryde; a progressive release of approximately 15.8 hectares of identified surplus land and up to 11 indicative development lots to create a science and technology park; the retention of principal CSIRO buildings in good condition to form the nucleus of the redevelopment in the divisional precincts; the provision for all of CSIRO's anticipated accommodation needs for the foreseeable future in retained existing buildings, upgraded as necessary, and state of the art new buildings; provision of controlled access to the site to address urgent safety issues; an orderly continuous redevelopment program anticipated to run some nine years, but the program to permit on-site research to proceed with little interruption; and the whole redevelopment is to be self-funding. The work will be undertaken for an out-turn cost of $101m and will be funded from the sale and/or lease of identified surplus land.

To accelerate the construction timetable from 12 to 13 years down to nine years, the Government has provided a loan of $10m. The planned redevelopment represents a major opportunity for the CSIRO to provide good accommodation for its staff into the next century. I commend the motion to the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Public Works Committee: Parkville, Victoria--CSIRO Redevelopment

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baldwin The Hon P.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BALDWIN
TALKER.ROLE: -Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —-On behalf of the Minister for Small Business and Customs (Mr Beddall), who represents the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus), I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, the following proposed work be referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works for consideration and report: Parkville, Victoria--CSIRO Redevelopment.

In 1988, as a result of new research directions, the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation redirected the activities of the former Division of Protein Chemistry towards the pharmaceutical and health care industries. As a result, the Division of Protein Chemistry was dissolved and the wool protein and leather research activities were relocated to more compatible facilities at Geelong and Clayton and the residual biomolecular research conducted at Parkville was strengthened through the transfer of related activities from CSIRO's campus at Clayton and by joining with the Division of Biotechnology at North Ryde to form the Division of Biomolecular Engineering. The amalgamation will allow the Parkville laboratory to focus on research for the pharmaceutical and health care industries with an emphasis on sophisticated computer based instrumentation and microanalytical techniques.

In line with these requirements, the CSIRO is now proposing to redevelop the Parkville site as a major research complex and to provide the headquarters for the Division of Biomolecular Engineering. The redeveloped facility will provide for 140 people and development works will be undertaken in three stages to satisfy client requirements that the site remain operational at all times.

The work will include: demolition of an old two-storey wing along the western boundary and construction of a new four-storey wing linked to the existing main laboratory; upgrading and refurbishing the existing main laboratory in the administration building to house administration amenities, research services and support units, including stores and workshops; and demolition of a portion of Mayfair, an old Victorian residence, and redevelopment of this area of the site as landscaped open space for increased staff recreation.

The project is estimated to take approximately four years to complete and will cost $12.25m at August 1991 prices. These funds have been programmed into CSIRO's capital investment plan. I table the supporting drawings and commend the motion to the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Public Works Committee: Stage 2 Development of HMAS Albatross, Nowra, New South Wales

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baldwin The Hon P.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BALDWIN
TALKER.ROLE: -Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —-On behalf of the Minister for Small Business and Customs (Mr Beddall), who represents the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus), I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, it is expedient to carry out the following proposed work which was referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works and on which the Committee has duly reported to Parliament: Stage 2 Development of HMAS Albatross, Nowra, New South Wales

Following Government approval in 1985 and 1986 to purchase the new Seahawk helicopters for the Royal Australian Navy, further development of the naval air station HMAS Albatross near Nowra, New South Wales, was prompted. The first stage of this development commenced in 1987 and it is now completed.

This motion now refers to stage 2 of the development program. Stage 2 will involve the provision of a new building to house the command operations, communications and administration of the naval air station, and the provision of a new building to provide office facilities for both technical and administrative staff of Nos 723 and 817 squadrons. Upgrading of associated hangar annexes, high voltage reticulation and emergency power supplies will also be provided.

At present the command operations, communications and administration functions are conducted from six widely separated buildings, two of which are temporary buildings of World War II design. Technical staff of Nos 723 and 817 squadrons operate from temporary and unsatisfactory accommodation. Squadron administration and aircrew operate from old corrugated iron and timber huts which are energy inefficient and noisy and which continually require repairs and maintenance. Critical upgrading of the high voltage reticulation system was undertaken in stage 1, but with the passage of time further works are now required. The central emergency power station upgrade will now provide a stand-by power supply to satisfy the current increased operational requirements.

These proposed works will complete the current major development project at HMAS Albatross. The limit of cost estimates for these works is $9.9m at December 1990 prices. It is planned that the work will go to tender in September 1991, with completion of two new buildings expected by late 1992. It is expected that the project will create about 70 jobs in the Nowra area.

In its report the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works determined that there is a need to construct buildings and associated engineering works at HMAS Albatross for the provision of facilities to accommodate support functions of the naval air station at Nowra to squadron staff and upgrading of high voltage electrical services and energy generation. The Committee agreed that these proposed works will be adequate to provide working accommodation and engineering services to support the functions of the naval air station at Nowra. The Committee recommended that as part of the stage 2 development of HMAS Albatross an energy audit should be undertaken to identify methods by which the use of electricity can be reduced. Consistent with this recommendation, the Committee also recommended that the buildings in the proposal requiring the provision of hot water should be provided with adequate solar hot water heaters.

The Department of Defence accepts the recommendations in the Public Works Committee report and will comply with the specific issues raised. I thank the subcommittee for its support and I commend the motion to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawker Mr D.P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The Opposition supports this motion, but I would like to make a couple of observations about one aspect and also draw on some of the comments that my colleague the honourable member for Gilmore (Mr Sharp) made when referring to the report of the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works that was tabled in the House last week.

SPEECH.PARA: On the question of energy conservation, I think all honourable members would support the moves that are being made, but it is worth reiterating the point that I raised here last week on this very issue, that is, while using solar hot water heaters is certainly a worthy move in saving energy and will make some contribution to Australia's efforts to reduce our emissions of greenhouse gasses, it is worth making the observation, as the Public Works Committee did in its report, that this will increase the life cycle costs of these hot water services by about 70 per cent. That would be a very significant increase for householders who had to install the same type of equipment.

I make that observation because I again draw to the attention of all honourable members that these are the sorts of difficulties that householders are facing when it comes to trying to look at ways and means of conserving energy. While it may be said that the Government should be leading the way and therefore the extra 70 per cent increase in costs is not unreasonable, it nonetheless does highlight the fact that it will cost more, and it would cost more for individuals.

Secondly, I would like to talk about the points that were raised by my colleague the honourable member for Gilmore last week. In fact, HMAS Albatross is within his electorate. He pointed out that it has suffered quite badly over the last seven years because of the Government decision to scrap the fixed wing component of the Navy air arm. That in itself was probably difficult enough for people in the Nowra area to take, but the real insult that he drew attention to, and to which the attention of honourable members should be drawn yet again, is that the Government, in its haste to sell off the Navy's ability to defend itself with its fixed wing squadron, sold its Skyhawks--the A4s--to the New Zealanders at a fire sale price, but having done that the Government then found itself in the embarrassing position, a few years later, of having to lease them back at, as my colleague the honourable member for Gilmore pointed out, an annual lease rate that is not much different from the total capital sale price of the planes two years before. I really do think that the Government ought to be reminded of the stupidity of some of its decisions, and that was one.
Nonetheless, I am sure all residents of the Shoalhaven area near HMAS Albatross will be pleased to hear of the work that is being undertaken and will look forward to seeing its completion.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Public Works Committee: Redevelopment by the Defence Housing Authority of Seaward Village, Perth, Western Australia

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baldwin The Hon P.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BALDWIN
TALKER.ROLE: -Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —-On behalf of the Minister for Small Business and Customs (Mr Beddall), who represents the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus), I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, it is expedient to carry out the following proposed work which was referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works and on which the committee has duly reported to Parliament: Redevelopment by the Defence Housing Authority of Seaward Village, Perth, Western Australia

The proposed work recommended by the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works involves the redevelopment by the Defence Housing Authority of Seaward Village, Perth. The redevelopment is in line with the Government's commitment to improve housing for Defence families and will be undertaken in three stages at an estimated cost of $12.814m, with a completion target of 1994. The redevelopment will replace 77 unsuitable and poor quality houses at Seaward Village, which is located on base adjacent to Campbell Barracks, the home of the Special Air Service regiment at Swanbourne, a coastal suburb of Perth. The scope of the works provides for the redevelopment of Seaward Village and its continued integration with the adjacent Seaview Heights Village of 28 good quality houses to be retained.

Work will include the demolition or sale of the poor quality houses and the construction of good housing suitable for the Defence families involved. Existing substandard sewerage, stormwater drainage and water supply services are also to be replaced as part of the new subdivision works.

In response to the Committee's recommendations, the Defence Housing Authority will follow the code of practice for the safe removal of asbestos during the demolition and removal or disposal of the houses. The Authority is also currently reviewing the Committee's recommendations regarding the installation of solar hot water heaters in all houses and will endeavour to establish reasons as to why constant maintenance is required with this type of water heater.
I thank the Committee, and in particular its Chair, the honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis), who is present in the chamber, for its report, and I commend the motion to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawker Mr D.P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —-In supporting this motion I would again like to draw attention to a couple of points. The first is that this motion comes out of the reference that was reported back to the House on 17 April this year. While the delay has not been unreasonable, I note it is a bit different from the previous motion from the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services (Mr Baldwin). In fact, that report was tabled here only last week.

SPEECH.PARA: We are talking about improving housing for Australian Defence Force personnel. As is rightly pointed out, this concerns the replacement of 77 substandard houses with 123 new houses. While it is commendable and welcome and I am sure that all of our Defence Force personnel would be very pleased to see that progress, I draw the attention of the House to the fact that the Cross report, which was tabled over four years ago, drew attention to the fact that, of the 23,000 houses that are provided for our Defence Force personnel, nearly half were substandard. So while the replacement of 77 is welcome, it is but a small move toward taking up what was clearly a very urgent problem identified by a parliamentary committee over four years ago--a problem which, at the time, had led to substantial increases in the resignation rate of our Defence Force personnel.

While we do welcome this, I think the Government has been very tardy in addressing the problem of improving Defence Force personnel housing. I urge the Government, therefore, to have another look at the Cross report. It is over four years since it was tabled and it showed very clearly the problems that Defence Force personnel--the very fine men and women who are serving in our defence forces--have to tolerate with regard to the standard of housing provided for them.

I also note that the Minister will examine further why the cost of using solar heating in the housing is not only considerably more expensive--70 per cent more, as I pointed out in the previous motion--but also that it needs continuing maintenance. I suspect that that is because the type of solar heating being used has a panel which moves with the sun and, therefore, would require some maintenance. Nonetheless, it again highlights the difficulty that private citizens with their own homes face when trying to make the decision about whether or not to put in solar hot water heating.

I draw this to the attention of the Government because I think it is a matter that it will have to look at some time down the track. While the Government may set these targets for reducing greenhouse emissions, it also has to look at the practical aspects of these targets and what they mean to average citizens. Bearing in mind that citizens of Australia are now facing a very severe recession--one that the former Treasurer, the honourable member for Blaxland (Mr Keating), seemed to be quite proud that he had inflicted upon this nation--particularly during these times, I think it is worth reminding the Minister that in those circumstances it is rather difficult to be asking citizens of this nation to be following the same course as the Government in considering their new hot water services when it will cost them 70 per cent more.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hollis Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I do not want to delay the House, but I want to correct one thing that the honourable member for Wannon (Mr Hawker) said and put the record straight with regard to this reference. The Joint Statutory Committee on Public Works did actually bring in the report last week. The date that the honourable member quoted--17 April--was the date on which it was actually referred to the Committee. I wanted to make that comment in order to set the record straight.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —-Yesterday the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer) raised, as a matter of privilege, the question of whether a witness to the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration may have misled that Committee. The essence of the honourable member's complaint was that a Mr Paddison, a senior executive of the State Bank of South Australia, had given a certain response to a question about non-performing loans and possible bank losses when appearing before the Committee on 30 April. The honourable member said that he had since received a document which indicated that, well before the evidence in question was given to the Committee, substantially higher estimates of non-performing loans and possible bank losses had been prepared at a senior level within the bank and notified to the bank's board.

INTERJECT.PARA: The honourable member has since made available to me a copy of a chart he received which he felt substantiated his concern that the Committee may have been misled. Whilst I have no means of knowing the authenticity of the document or the validity of any of the statements that have been made, on its face the document does appear to reveal a discrepancy between the response given by Mr Paddison on 30 April and projections on the same matters apparently known at senior levels within the bank.

Whilst I would normally ask the Committee to consider the matter itself, I think at this stage the House might deal with it. Misleading a committee is certainly a traditional category of contempt and on the information available to me, although it is not a completely clear cut matter, I am prepared to accord precedence to a motion in respect of the matter raised by the honourable member for Mayo.

That the House refer to the Committee of Privileges the question of whether Mr Stephen Paddison of the State Bank of South Australia misled the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration in an answer given to the Committee on 30 April this year in response to a question about non-performing loans and losses by the bank.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baldwin The Hon P.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BALDWIN
TALKER.ROLE: -Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —- I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Customs Tariff Proposal No. 7 (1991).

The tariff proposal which I have just tabled contains alterations to the Customs Tariff Act 1987. The proposal extends the provisions of the Australian system of tariff preferences to Czechoslovakia and Namibia. The proposal has effect on and from 1 October 1991.

The Government supports the action being taken by Western industrialised countries to encourage changes presently taking place in central Europe. We have already accorded preferential treatment to other countries of central Europe, most recently to Poland and Hungary. In view of the political and economic reforms which have also taken place in Czechoslovakia, we are now extending preferential treatment to that country.

The Government's decision to accord Namibia preferential status is consistent with Australia's long involvement in international efforts to assist Namibia and other southern African states to reduce their economic dependence on South Africa. Our action, in respect of both Czechoslovakia and Namibia, is consistent with measures already adopted, or being adopted, in other countries, such as the United States of America, and by the European Community.

The measures in this proposal are contained in schedule 6 to the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1991, which I will now introduce. This proposal will ensure that the measures are in place on 1 October and will avoid the necessity of waiting for passage of the legislation through Parliament before the preference measures can be implemented.
I commend the proposal to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Prosser) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Baldwin, for Mr Beddall, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baldwin The Hon P.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BALDWIN
TALKER.ROLE: -Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1991, which is now before the House, contains a number of amendments to the Customs Tariff Act 1987. Some of these amendments have previously been introduced as Customs Tariff Proposals.

Sections 3 and 4 of the Bill are operative on and from 12 March 1991 and contain administrative amendments to the Customs Tariff Act 1987. Section 3 contains a change to section 14 of the principal Act to ensure that `free' is a rate of duty for the purposes of section 19 of the principal Act, which was amended by the Customs Tariff Amendment Act 1991.

Section 4 defines the developing country rate of duty for certain goods presently covered by quota arrangements which end in 1993. This is necessary to implement new preference arrangements for the Republic of Korea, Hong Kong, Taiwan Province and Singapore in respect of these goods. These preference arrangements have effect from 1 July 1992 and correct tariff changes contained in the Customs Tariff Amendment Act 1991.

Section 13 amends paragraph 10(1)(b) of the Customs Tariff Amendment Act 1991 by inserting a reference to 1 July 1992. This amendment takes effect on 12 March this year and ensures the correct implementation of phasing rates of duty announced in the Government's industry statement.

Schedule 1 provides a duty free rate for pre-tanned bovine and equine leather. This corrects an anomaly introduced at the time of conversion to the harmonised tariff and operates on and from 1 January 1988.

Schedule 2 provides a free rate of duty for parts of wheelchairs. This results from a Government decision on the Industry Commission's report on aids and appliances for people with disabilities. Minor amendments are also made to two subheadings of chapter 90 following printing errors in the Customs Tariff Amendment Act 1991. This schedule operates on and from 1 January 1991.

Schedule 3 is operative on and from 12 March 1991. It implements phasing rates of duty for certain goods of 2204 and 2205, in accordance with the Government's industry statement. For technical reasons, these changes were not able to be implemented by the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill 1991. Minor administrative changes are made to two subheadings of chapter 63 and to subitems 11A and 21V in schedule 5.

Schedule 4, which is operative on and from 10 April 1991, contains a new additional note to chapter 20. This note defines orange juice to include products of oranges, regardless of methods of derivation. This amendment restores the intended rates of assistance for orange juice, following representations from the local citrus industry.

Schedule 5 is operative on and from 1 July 1991. It contains administrative amendments to subheadings in chapters 7 and 17. Rates of duty for Canada are inserted in two subheadings of chapter 20. These amendments correct administrative oversights in the Customs Tariff Amendment Act 1991.

The rate of duty on aviation gasoline has been reduced by 0.321c per litre. This results from a decision by the Civil Aviation Authority to withdraw its rescue and firefighting service from capital city secondary airports. Part of the customs duty collected on aviation gasoline was regarded as an offset against the cost of providing this service.

Minor amendments are made to note 1 and subnote 2(b) to chapter 43 to conform with changes to the harmonised nomenclature. Schedule 5 also implements measures to facilitate Australia's partial accession to the 1950 UNESCO Agreement, more commonly known as the Florence Agreement. The changes introduce free rates of duty for educational, scientific and cultural material.

Schedule 6, which is operative on and from 1 October 1991, accords Czechoslovakia developing country status, as announced by the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) on 14 August. The Government has also accorded this status to Namibia.

Schedule 7 is operative on and from 1 January 1992. It includes changes to various section and chapter notes, headings and interpretative rules in the harmonised nomenclature. Australia is a signatory to the Customs Cooperation Council Convention and under article 16 is obliged to implement periodic changes to the harmonised system. Some of the changes are substantial and the following consequential amendments have been introduced:
a new subheading of heading 2106 has been created to maintain protective rates of duty for certain food preparations which have been reclassified;
subheading 2818.10 has been split to maintain protective rates for artificial corundum, not chemically defined; and

additional note 2 to chapter 61, additional note 1 to chapter 62 and the additional note to chapter 95 have been omitted. The substance of these notes has been incorporated in other notes or headings of schedule 3.
Other changes are of an administrative nature only and have no effect on classification or duty rates.
Schedule 8 will have effect on and from 14 days after this Bill receives royal assent, and contains the following changes:

denatured ethyl alcohol is amended by removing the revenue component from the current duty rate. Excise duty applies only to potable spirits for human consumption. Denatured ethyl alcohol, or methylated spirits, is free from excise duty when produced in Australia. The inclusion of an excise equivalent duty in the customs tariff is therefore an anomaly, as only the protective element of the customs duty should be applicable.

The amendment of this item will correct this anomaly and, together with associated administrative changes to the excise regulations, will streamline the import regime applicable to methylated spirits; and
. other minor administrative changes which are consequential to amendments contained in previous Customs Tariff Amendment Acts.
Financial Impact

Tariff changes to implement the terms of the Florence Agreement will involve a revenue loss of approximately $28m in 1991-92, $30m in 1992-93 and $32m in 1993-94. Customs duty forgone through the reduction of the duty rate for aviation gasoline is expected to be approximately $35,000 per annum. The inclusion of Czechoslovakia in the list of developing countries is expected to result in a revenue loss of around $1.7m per annum. The inclusion of Namibia will result in a loss of around $7,000 per annum. The initiative to reduce the duty rate for parts of wheelchairs is expected to cost less than $100,000 per annum.

Other changes contained in this Bill will have only minor revenue implications. Details of the amendments contained in this Bill have been included in an explanatory memorandum which has been circulated for the information of honourable members. I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Prosser) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Baldwin, for Mr Beddall, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baldwin The Hon P.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BALDWIN
TALKER.ROLE: -Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill proposes amendments to the Excise Tariff Act 1921 to incorporate into that Act two excise tariff proposals already tabled in Parliament. The first proposal relates to an increase in excise duty for naturally occurring liquefied petroleum gas, or LPG, and the second relates to a decrease in excise duty for gasoline for use in aircraft, or Avgas.
Liquefied Petroleum Gas

Clause 4 of the Bill will increase the excise rate for LPG for the period 1 April 1991 to 1 July 1991 from $5.78 per kilolitre to $35.94 per kilolitre. The amount of excise duty payable on naturally occurring LPG is adjusted in April and October each year in accordance with this Government's and the previous Government's longstanding policy of calculating the excise duty on the basis of 60 per cent of the amount by which the realised price for naturally occurring LPG exceeds $147 per tonne. The realised price is calculated as a weighted average of the prices received from exports and local sale of LPG during, in this case, the six-month period from 1 September 1990 until 28 February 1991.
