The increase in the excise rate effected by clause 4 reflects the higher export prices obtained for LPG during the relevant six- month period as a result of the Iraq-Kuwait conflict.

It is noted that as from 1 July this year the excise on LPG has been replaced by a resource rent tax, under the Petroleum Resource Rent Legislation Amendment Act 1991 which amended the Petroleum Rent Tax Assessment Act 1987. Transitional arrangements in that Act provide that excise collected since 1 July 1990 on naturally occurring LPG is offset against the producer's tax liability under the resource rent tax legislation.
Avgas

Clause 3 of the Bill will decrease the excise duty on Avgas with effect from 1 July 1991, by reducing the rate of excise from 27.395c per litre to 27.074c per litre. The decrease is due to the withdrawal of the Civil Aviation Authority's rescue and firefighting service from capital city secondary airports. When the Civil Aviation Authority was established on 1 July 1988, the Aviation Fuel Revenues (Special Appropriation) Act provided for the payment to the Authority of that portion of the revenue from Avgas excise which had historically been attributed to the functions transferred to the CAA.

Subsequently, the general aviation representative associations advised the Authority that they no longer required the rescue and firefighting service at capital city secondary airports. The capital city secondary airports are Archerfield in Brisbane, Bankstown in Sydney, Essendon and Moorabbin in Melbourne, Parafield in Adelaide and Jandakot in Perth. Accordingly, the Civil Aviation Authority Board decided to remove the service from those airports from 1 July 1991.

The CAA's decision to withdraw its rescue and firefighting services from the six secondary airports followed a comprehensive review of existing rescue and firefighting service arrangements which involved input from the aviation industry, local authorities, metropolitan fire brigades and the Federal Airports Corporation.
In view of the removal of the service the board requested that the rate of Avgas excise which had been calculated as an offset against the cost of providing the service be similarly reduced.
Financial Impact Statement
A) Liquefied petroleum gas
The increase in the excise rate for naturally occurring LPG is estimated to result in an increase of $9.4m in excise receipts for the three months commencing on 1 April 1991.
B) Gasoline for use in aircraft

Nil. The reduction in the rate of excise and customs duty on gasoline for use in aircraft will reduce the Commonwealth revenue by approximately $340,000 for 1991-92. Money appropriated to the Civil Aviation Authority will reduce by that amount so therefore there will be no net financial impact.
I commend the Bill to the House and present its explanatory memorandum.
Debate (on motion by Mr Prosser) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Howe, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: DEPUTY PRIME MINISTER; HEALTH, HOUSING AND COMMUNITY SERVICES

TALKER.NAME: Mr HOWE
TALKER.ROLE: -Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

As part of the Government's 1991-92 budgetary measures, I bring before the House a Bill to amend the Health Insurance Act 1973. The Bill rectifies what has previously been a deficiency in the legislation that enabled Medicare benefits to be paid when a medical practitioner rendered a medical service outside the scope of that medical practitioner's limited or restricted State or Territory registration.

The Bill also includes a new provision which ensures that a patient is fully informed concerning the non-availability of Medicare entitlements before a medical service is rendered outside a medical practitioner's State or Territory registration. The Bill includes a provision which requires that a medical practitioner, before rendering a medical service outside that medical practitioner's State or Territory registration, will be required to give to the patient a notice advising that a Medicare benefit is not payable in respect of such a service. The Bill introduces a penalty provision where, if a medical practitioner who is required to so notify a patient fails to do so, then a penalty, set at a maximum of $2,000, may apply.

Also included in the Bill is a discretion for the payment of Medicare benefits to ensure that patients are not disadvantaged by the proposed new arrangements. This will enable the payment of Medicare benefits for a medical service which is rendered by a medical practitioner outside that medical practitioner's State or Territory registration and where the medical practitioner fails to inform the patient that Medicare benefits are not payable. For example, such a provision would enable Medicare benefits to be paid where a medical practitioner acting outside that medical practitioner's State or Territory registration was required to provide an emergency service.

Honourable members will be aware that, for some time, the Government has been reviewing the key elements of the Medicare arrangements and, in particular, concerns related to excessive servicing by some medical practitioners. The Bill introduces a new penalty provision and new referral powers to a Medicare Participation Review Committee, which are considered necessary as deterrents to medical practitioners who render excessive services.

These amendments are part of the Government's broad initiatives to control the costs of Medicare. Medical practitioners, under the current legislation, may be required to appear before a medical services committee of inquiry, which is a committee of peers, to justify the necessity of the medical services rendered. To the extent that a medical services committee of inquiry finds that the medical practitioner has excessively serviced, that medical practitioner may be required to repay such Medicare benefits to the Commonwealth or the Commonwealth may not be required to pay Medicare benefits for such medical services. The Bill introduces a penalty, in addition to the non-payment or repayment of Medicare benefits, equal to the value of the Medicare payments in respect of those services, which have been found by a medical services committee of inquiry to have been rendered excessively.

The current legislation provides for the establishment of a Medicare Participation Review Committee. Such committees are empowered to review the continued participation of a medical practitioner in the Medicare arrangements, in certain circumstances, and may disqualify a medical practitioner from the Medicare arrangements for up to five years. The Bill introduces new provisions requiring that where a medical practitioner has been found to have rendered excessive services by a medical services committee of inquiry on two or more occasions, then such a medical practitioner will be referred to a Medicare Participation Review Committee.

On 1 November 1991 new Health Insurance (General Medical Services Table) Regulations will be implemented. From these regulations, it has been common practice to produce the Medicare benefits schedule, which is used by medical practitioners in relation to billing patients under Medicare. The Australian National Audit Office, Efficiency Audit Report No. 26 on the administration of the Medicare benefits schedule made four recommendations regarding presentational changes to the Medicare benefits schedule. The recommendations regarding the Medicare benefits schedule were, in substance, that it be restructured with more logical and appropriate headings to enable easier identification of the medical services items, and thus be more `user friendly'.

To implement the changes, the Bill introduces two technical amendments. These amendments will exclude the restrictive references in the current legislation to the words `Parts' and `Divisions' to enable more appropriate terms to be used in dividing up the various medical services in the Health Insurance (General Medical Services Table) Regulations. These changes do not affect in any way the substance of the medical services that are itemised in the current Health Insurance (General Medical Services Table) Regulations. I commend the Bill to the House. I now present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill.
Debate (on motion by Dr Bob Woods) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Staples, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Staples The Hon P.R.

TALKER.NAME: Mr STAPLES
TALKER.ROLE: -Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The Bill before the House provides for the establishment of the Hearing Services Authority from 1 July 1992. This Bill gives effect to Cabinet's decision of October last year that the National Acoustic Laboratories, NAL, hearing services program become a statutory authority, to be known as Australian Hearing Services.

The Bill will repeal the Acoustic Laboratories Act 1948 and amend section 9A of the National Health Act 1953, to bring the delivery of hearing services under one piece of legislation. Some may ask: what changes will eligible clients experience? I can assure them that eligible clients will experience enhanced quality, cost-effective, timely and relevant hearing services, both rehabilitation and hearing impairment prevention.

The new legislation will require the Authority to consult with relevant government, business, commercial, industry, and consumer bodies in delivering services to eligible clients. There will be no change to eligibility under the new Act--the Authority will continue to provide hearing rehabilitation services to Department of Social Security pensioners with a pensioner health benefits card and their dependants, Veterans' Affairs pensioners, anyone under the age of 21 years, people referred by Australian defence forces, Comcare, the Commonwealth Rehabilitation Service and the Australian Government Health Service.

These services will include hearing loss assessment, the selection and fitting of appropriate hearing aids and devices and counselling at no charge to the client. It is only in respect of the repair and maintenance of hearing aids and devices and for the annual supply of batteries that clients, other than those in receipt of the family allowance supplement and children of eligible clients, will continue to be required to make a small contribution. The Department of Veterans' Affairs will cover veterans for this cost.

The reorganisation of NAL as a statutory authority represents just one part of the reforms for the delivery of services to public interest clients who have a hearing impairment and who would, but for these services, not be able to afford the hearing aids and devices supplied by the private sector. It was for this, among other reasons, that the Government decided last year not to follow the Industry Commission's recommendation that the whole hearing services market be opened up to two-way competition.

Honourable members will be pleased to hear that considerable progress has been made with the joint venture between NAL and its commercial partner, Australian Hearing Aids, AHA. AHA is a joint venture between the Commonwealth NAL and AHA--which is a joint venture between Crystalaid Pty Ltd, a wholly owned Australian company, and Ascom, a Swiss communications consortium--for the design, development and supply of the third generation of programmable hearing aids to NAL's clients and for export markets in Asia, the United States and Europe.

This arrangement was possible because of the high international regard for the National Acoustic Laboratories and the Government's hearing services program. It means that NAL will be able to supply world leading programmable hearing products to eligible clients from 1 January 1993. The establishment of NAL as a statutory authority underpins this arrangement.

One of the objectives of the Authority will be to participate, as far as is practicable, in promoting and establishing export markets for the jointly designed and developed hearing products. From this NAL stands to earn royalties from both the hearing aids and remote control units sold overseas. The Government has been guaranteed minimum royalties of $2.6m on all exports, with projected royalties of over $9m over the period of the contract.

As with many government services, some may consider this scheme excessive in the current economic climate; however, when one considers that nearly one in every 10 Australians has a hearing impairment and that this ratio increases to one in every three people over the age of 65 years, this more than justifies the need for a readily accessible and affordable program to assist those people.

The Government's NAL hearing services program employs a team of highly trained and caring people, including university trained audiologists, some of whom specialise in either paediatric or adult services, technicians and administrative staff to ensure that eligible clients receive the level of service they require to enable them to communicate effectively in their everyday life. These services are delivered through a network of over 100 permanent and visiting NAL hearing centres to ensure that all clients receive the same level of service across Australia.

NAL provides a comprehensive hearing health care program which is aimed at improving the quality of life for many pensioners who could otherwise be cut off from everyday life. The services provided by NAL also target children to ensure that their early development and learning is not impeded by their hearing impairment. NAL currently sees some 200,000 hearing impaired people. Last financial year NAL assessed some 50,000 new pensioners, veterans and children and fitted a total of 80,069 hearing aids. NAL's technicians repair about 270,000 hearing aids and devices each year.

The Bill does not alter the delivery of services to NAL's traditional hearing impaired clients; it simply makes changes to the administrative and operational aspects of the program. The provision of hearing rehabilitation services to the traditional clients of NAL, including the fitting of appropriate hearing aids and devices, their maintenance and repair, as well as batteries, will continue to be provided by the Authority.

Another of the Authority's major activities will be research into hearing loss, hearing assessment and rehabilitation, hearing loss prevention, and the effects of noise on people. A further activity for the Authority, which fits with its more commercial orientation, will be the hearing impairment prevention services provided by NAL. These activities fit well with the Government's overall objective of promoting better health in the community.

The new organisational arrangements for the delivery of hearing services to eligible clients set out in this Bill will see the appointment of a board of management which will report directly to the Minister. Members of this board will be by ministerial appointment and will consist of representatives from business and consumer organisations as well as the General Manager of the Authority.

The board of management of the Authority, in accordance with the legislation, will develop and operate under a corporate plan that sets the financial and operational targets for the Authority. As with all government bodies and programs, the Authority will have to perform against set targets and performance indicators. The day to day operations of the Authority will be managed by a general manager and the organisation will be restructured to facilitate these arrangements. The general manager will also be appointed by the Minister. Staff of the Authority will continue to be appointed and employed under the Public Service Act.

The Authority will continue to operate under a group 2 trust account, which was established on 1 July 1991. All moneys and payment of all expenditures and disbursements relating to the Authority's operations will pass through this account. The Authority will also be subject to the same reporting requirements in relation to estimates and receipts of expenditure for each financial year, as is any government body. Similarly, the Authority will be subject to the Audit Act and its reporting mechanisms, as with any statutory body.

Under the new arrangements the Authority will continue to be primarily budget funded, with moneys being appropriated to the Authority by the Parliament. Although the Authority will be exempted from taxation, including payroll and sales tax, it will be required to pay customs duty, as it currently does.

Provision is made in the Bill for the levying of charges for products, services and facilities. Such charges will be set by regulation, as is currently the case for any fees or charges levied by NAL. The Authority can enter into contractual arrangements for up to $1m without the approval of the Minister, but must have ministerial approval for any contract above this amount or for the sale or acquisition of property.

The rights of clients are protected by the inclusion in the Bill of both independent internal review by the general manager and external review of decisions by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal affecting the rights of clients, including the imposition of charges.

The Government's endeavours to streamline the operations of NAL have already borne fruit, with the introduction of computer systems and dramatic reductions in waiting times in all hearing centres. As a statutory authority, NAL will have the flexibility to achieve further improvements in the cost and timeliness of its services, and as a bonus will have low cost, state-of-the-art hearing aids for Australians, together with technology transfer and export earnings. I commend this Bill to the House and present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill.
Debate (on motion by Dr Wooldridge) adjourned.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Suspension of Standing and Sessional Orders

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Mr Baldwin, for Mr Beazley) agreed to:

That so much of the standing and sessional orders be suspended as would prevent Notices Nos. 2 and 3, private Members' business given by the honourable Member for Dundas and accorded priority for Thursday, 12 September 1991, being moved in his absence by the honourable Members for Moore and Casey, respectively.
Debate resumed from 10 September, on motion by Mr Kerin:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wooldridge Dr M.R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I am continuing on from last night, when I was using this debate on the Appropriation Bill (No. 1) to discuss my responsibilities as shadow Minister for Aboriginal affairs. I reached a point at which I was being somewhat negative; although, to put it in some context, I have talked about the direction I see in Aboriginal affairs--what is going right in the portfolio, what is going wrong in the portfolio, areas of program delivery, some bright spots and some not so bright spots.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the gems that came up in the Budget Papers in Aboriginal affairs related to a program run by DASETT on Aboriginal public awareness of climatic change. The purpose of this program is to encourage and promote national strategies to minimise Aboriginal health problems due to climatic events. The need for this was said to be that Aboriginal communities are a high risk group in relation to the impact of the greenhouse effect. This is particularly interesting, because, as a doctor who had some interest in sun related skin disorders prior to coming into this place, I can tell the House that melanoma is absolutely unknown amongst Aboriginal people, as is basal cell carcinoma, and squamous cell carcinoma is so unusual as virtually not to be recorded in textbooks.

I am not quite sure what this money is going to. It may be for house design in the Torres Strait--how to make houses on stilts. But, in an area in which there is such great need, it is very frustrating to find programs that seem to have slipped through without anyone ever engaging their brain and thinking about whether there actually is a need for them. Another difficulty with Aboriginal affairs is that it is a portfolio which has a great deal of confrontation. Earlier today in this House we had a debate on the Aboriginal Education (Supplementary Assistance) Amendment Bill. The honourable member for the Northern Territory (Mr Snowdon) spoke after me. I apologise to him for not being able to stay for his contribution, but I did catch it in my office. Anyone who listened to the honourable member for the Northern Territory would think that Aboriginal education in the Northern Territory was the worst in Australia.

One of the privileges I have as a member of this Parliament is serving on the Standing Committee on Aboriginal Affairs, which is currently undertaking an inquiry into Aboriginal language maintenance. During the course of that inquiry, the Committee has travelled extensively throughout northern Australia examining Aboriginal education, particularly bilingual education. I have to say that, although the Northern Territory Government's efforts may not be up to the standard considered desirable by the honourable member for the Northern Territory, the Northern Territory is leagues ahead of any other place in Australia in terms of its treatment of Aboriginal people. One only has to look over the border at the Kimberley district of Western Australia to find that in some places Aboriginal children are still being punished if they are caught speaking their own language in the playground. In contrast to that, the Northern Territory has some very innovative programs, innovative curricula development and bilingual education, which increase the school retention rates.

The speech made by the honourable member for the Northern Territory really brought home to me how much confrontation is still associated with the Aboriginal affairs portfolio. Although he and I may often disagree on Aboriginal affairs, we confine our disagreements to this chamber. The difficulties arise because we carry so much political baggage and so much mistrust. This came home to me during the recent debate on the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation, which was the first major issue associated with Aboriginal affairs in a decade on which this Parliament spoke with a unanimous voice.

Prior to the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation Bill being passed by the Parliament, I issued a press release stating that I had some concerns about the Council, and I still do. I was concerned that the Council may not be adequately focused and about its accountability. I formed those views after travelling around the country for six months, using the very best part of my working life during that period in an effort to persuade, argue, beg, plead and generally drum up support for the Minister's Bill. In the end, the Opposition supported the legislation.

In spite of having expressed concerns in the most constructive way that I possibly could, my doing so led to a tirade of abusive letters from a wide range of people. One letter was written by the Australian Teachers Federation, saying, `How dare you run this thing off the tracks'. This correspondence came entirely from people who had contributed no input to the process over a period of months; yet they were prepared to criticise me on the basis of their fixed perceptions.

As I said, in the end result, the Opposition supported the Bill, and those concerns remain with me. However, the Opposition was prepared to pass the legislation and to approach the matter in a constructive way. The point I make is that it seems to be very difficult to have concerns about Aboriginal affairs without running the risk of suffering abuse for having honestly expressed them. I should add that, subsequently, I have engaged in correspondence with the Australian Teachers Federation. In the not too distant future, I hope to meet its representatives with a view to working out a basis of trust between us.

There are also areas of hope in the Aboriginal affairs portfolio, and one is the report of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody which was released earlier this year by Commissioner Elliott Johnston. I wish to cite a few passages contained in the report because I believe the views expressed should move every Australian. The report says:

The view propounded by this report is that the most significant contributing factor is the disadvantaged and unequal position in which Aboriginal people find themselves in the society--socially, economically and culturally.

The thrust of this report is that the elimination of disadvantage requires an end of domination and an empowerment of Aboriginal people; that control of their lives, of their communities must be returned to Aboriginal hands.
Commissioner Johnston went on to refer to the daily life of Aboriginal people and he expressed it in the following terms:
This petty tyranny, escalating to interference with the most fundamental of rights to practise ones own culture, ones own religion, to parent one's own children is deeply resented.
The resentment and bitterness are very real.

I believe it is a great pity that the Royal Commission's report is so lengthy. It comprises 11 volumes, which means that, almost certainly, it will not reach the audience it deserves. The very balanced and moderate treatment it gives to a very difficult and complex area is worthy of the attention of this House. To date, it has received bipartisan support in the Parliament.

When I was given the job of shadow Minister for Aboriginal affairs by the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson), I was asked to consider where we might be in the next decade. Three things were very obvious to me. First of all, 1992 will be the 500th anniversary of Columbus landing on the east coast of the Americas. It will focus world attention on the whole colonisation process in the same way Australia's Bicentenary focused attention on our history. The year 1993 will be the United Nations International Year of Indigenous People. As a result of the breakdown of East-West tensions, the Helsinki human rights process will almost certainly become a process for establishing indigenous rights, which will focus international debate on Australia in an unprecedented way. I do not say that in the sense that this country will be held to ransom, because I do not hold very much to threats; rather, I say that as someone who desperately wants Australia to win in the international arena--in business, innovation and science. In the future, the debate on indigenous people will be an international one, driven internationally. If Australia is not seen to be addressing the legitimate and reasonable aspirations and hopes of Aboriginal people, this nation will find itself in an increasingly hostile environment.

Having been the shadow Minister for Aboriginal affairs for nearly 18 months, I find it desperately disappointing that in some areas of Aboriginal affairs there is very strong evidence indicating that we are actually moving backwards. The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Tickner) recognises this. His comments were reported in the Weekend Australian of 7 September:
Aboriginal adults had a life expectancy 20 years less than that of others and the gap was growing.
It is significant that the gap is growing, not narrowing:
The central theme of a textbook launched by Mr Tickner yesterday is that the general health and well-being of Aborigines is worse now than 20 years ago.

In spite of this, the entire Aboriginal affairs debate is framed in terms of more of the same: that is, just a bit more money will fix it; just a bit more government involvement will fix it. That is in spite of the fact that what we are doing is in many cases sending things backwards. Australia already has the highest per capita expenditure on indigenous people in the world. We still seem to be looking at grand plans rather than realistic and achievable goals.

The position was stated very well recently by the Australian of the Year, Professor Fred Hollows, who said, `Bugger the reconciliation. Just fix the leprosy'. I hope that reconciliation will have a significant effect, but I share the point of view expressed by Professor Hollows. It will mean nothing unless we can `fix the leprosy'. A focus on programs and on services on the ground--in other words, on outcomes, not just processes--has to be the way forward for Aboriginal affairs.

As the shadow Minister for Aboriginal affairs, I sometimes have pangs of conscience. For the first time in my life, I have travelled extensively throughout rural and remote areas of Australia. I have been struck by the extent of rural poverty in this country. One cannot remove Aboriginal poverty from rural poverty. For example, a short while ago, I visited Cunnamulla in south-western Queensland and spoke to members of the local RSL. Someone came up to me and said, `I have lived here for 37 years. In all that time, only two kids from the local high school have gone on to tertiary studies'. A great deal is done to help Aboriginal people overcome their disadvantages, but not very much is done to help the people who live at Cunnamulla to overcome their disadvantages. I do not say that to suggest that less should be done for Aboriginal people. I am saying that if their problems are examined in isolation, without taking into account rural poverty generally, we miss the point. In the 18 months I have been the shadow Minister, I have not heard the issue of Aboriginal poverty raised in relation to rural poverty on even a single occasion.

Some of the sting is going out of the Aboriginal affairs debate, which makes it a very worthwhile and fulfilling area on which to focus one's activity. It is an area that does not have any impact on the daily lives of the majority of Australians, yet it is an area that cannot be ignored, because it will not simply go away. If Australia, as a country, cares about national unity and about national cohesion, it will not be possible to have a group of people who are marginalised and who are not fully able to participate in Australian life. That is the challenge confronting Aboriginal affairs during the next decade.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lindsay Mr E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —-It gives me great pleasure to support the Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1991-92 and this year's Federal Budget. There was an editorial in the Australian newspaper of 21 August 1991 which accurately identified the lasting benefits of the 1991 Federal Budget for the people of Australia. The editorial made this comment:

SPEECH.PARA: An inflation rate that will remain at a 20-year low level and a prospective positive trade balance, which in turn will reduce the current account deficit further and bring the growth in foreign debt under control.
The editorial went on to say:

Historically, for a Labor government in the trough of a recession, with its attendant unemployment, this is a considerable achievement. But it is also what we would expect of this Government. This is a Government with experience and expertise, one that realises the danger of trying to reflate the economy at a stage when the stimulus already injected into it (through lower interest rates and higher public spending) is set to drag it into recovery.

Yes, indeed. The Hawke Government is a government with experience and expertise. This Budget has laid the groundwork for an inspiring and fighting recovery of the Australian economy. Its fundamental priority is the well-being of the Australian people and, when the Australian people are called upon to pronounce their verdict on the performance of the Hawke Government, I know that they will give their confident endorsement of this Government's historic mission of reform; that is, to provide competent and compassionate government for all of the people of Australia.

The contrast between the positive programs contained in this Budget and the cold and heartless un-Australian policies of the Liberal and National parties could not be more stark. It is a contrast between an honest, credible and compassionate Labor Government and an Opposition which espouses the dark side of politics--the Liberal and National parties with their cynical and deceptive policies of unfairness, broken promises and spiralling taxes and charges. As the Prime Minister has said:

This budget aims to consolidate the work of its predecessors. Its aim is sustainable growth with low inflation. It is part of a continuing process toward structural reform and social justice. It continues the work--the task of the past eight years--of building an internationally competitive Australian economy. . . We are determined that this recovery will be different in character and quality from any merely cyclical recovery this country has seen in the past. We are determined that this recovery will unambiguously repay the pain of the recession with substantial and lasting gain.

The fundamental point about the Budget is that it is fiscally responsible. Because of the recession, outlays have jumped as a percentage of GDP; nevertheless, Budget outlays in 1991-92 as a percentage of GDP are 3 per cent lower than in the last year of the Liberal-National Party Government in 1982-83.

Whilst the fight against inflation is of paramount importance, Australia's economic recovery as a result of this Budget will in time produce the urgently needed growth in jobs. Unquestionably, unemployment is one of the major concerns of the Government. That is why an enormous effort--$540m--is being devoted to improving labour market opportunities. For example, there was an increase of $199m for labour market programs this year alone--an increase of 63 per cent. Not only is there increased funding for job market and training programs, but also there has been a substantial increase in funding for TAFE and higher education. Although the Government is investing a huge amount of the nation's wealth in policies designed to ensure a rapid recovery in employment growth, there still remain other avenues for the Government to accelerate rapid recovery in the job market. This brings me to the issue of jobs programs.

One of the realities of Australian society over the many decades has been the fact that, in good times and bad, hundreds of thousands of Australians are unable to obtain work. The Liberal and National parties have been notoriously indifferent to the plight of the unemployed. They shunt them aside. The present Liberal-National Party Opposition has threatened to take away the unemployment benefits from persons who are unemployed for more than nine months.

Past Australian Labor governments during periods of recession have initiated jobs programs designed to place the unemployed in productive work, not only for the benefit of the country but also for the self-esteem of the unemployed. For example, the Whitlam Government initiated the regional employment development scheme during the early 1970s, and the Hawke Government introduced the community employment program shortly after winning office in 1983. These programs made a solid and positive contribution towards relieving unemployment.

The United States has long experience in public job programs. There has been an enormous amount of academic research on the economic value of public job programs. An article in the US magazine Challenge, published in May-June 1991 by Sar Levitan and Frank Gallo of the George Washington University Centre for Social Policy Studies, described the value of job creation. They had this to say:

Public job creation serves four separate but overlapping needs: (1) The programs, of course, alleviate joblessness, hardship and poverty. (2) If sufficiently large, the expenditures can help the local or national economy emerge from a recession. (3) Providing jobs to able-bodied welfare recipients is a necessary complement to a welfare system, promoting the work ethic and self-sufficiency. (4) Jobs programs produce needed services that otherwise are neglected. Although precise estimates are lacking, the costs of jobs programs are mitigated if not outweighed by the benefits. The wages paid by jobs programs replace a portion of welfare disbursements and unemployment insurance. Subject to income taxes, the wages directly return money to government treasuries. The services and public works supplied through subsidised jobs provide useful and sometimes enduring benefits to society. Job programs in both the short and long runs reduce the likelihood of crime and welfare dependency.

President Roosevelt succinctly stated the moral case for subsidised jobs in his 1944 economic bill of rights: `True individual freedom cannot exist without economic security and independence. Necessitous men are not free men.'
The article went on:

The economic rationale for countercyclical public job creation is that market economies emerge slowly from downturns and that governmental spending accelerates recovery and may prevent lengthy stagnation.

I believe it imperative that the Hawke Government introduce a national public job creation scheme immediately. The community employment program was an outstanding success. In my own electorate of Herbert not only did it produce lasting benefits for the unemployed who participated in the program, but it also provided many excellent public works--for example: water reservoirs; roads; footpaths; bicycle tracks; sporting and recreation buildings; crown-of-thorns starfish surveys; public tree planting; and city beautification programs, just to name a few. The article by Levitan and Gallo recalls for me the many successes of the community employment program in my electorate. Writing of the US experience in job programs, Levitan and Gallo made this observation:

During the late 1970s, when poor youths aged sixteen to nineteen who had not completed high school were offered a guaranteed job, they responded en masse. In the seventeen communities that formed the basis for large-scale experiment to test this thesis, four of five eligible youths who learned of the program applied, and three-fifths of all eligible youth participated. The experiment increased the employment/population ratio of poor teens to 41 per cent, compared with 25 per cent in similar non-participating communities. The program was so potent that it raised the overall employment/population ratio of poor teenage blacks and Hispanics above that of poor whites.

I shall never forget one CEP project sponsored by the Uniting Church in my electorate. The Uniting Church had a holiday camp at Crystal Creek near Ingham and applied successfully for a CEP grant to upgrade the facilities at the camp. The church engaged a number of unemployed youths, some of whom were under 17 years of age.

I recall the coordinator of the program telling me of the poor physical condition of many of the youths and of their despondent emotional state when they were initially employed. He told me that at the end of the program the youths had dramatically improved their physique and had acquired a fresh sense of confidence and ebullience. The church coordinator found it a painful experience when the project was complete, for he was obliged to terminate the employment of the youths. Nevertheless, up to 60 per cent of the long term unemployed in my electorate who participated in the community employment program were successful in obtaining permanent employment.

As I said earlier, the Federal Government is spending huge sums of money on education and training programs. Combined education and labour market assistance in this Budget has increased by more than $1 billion. This is for increased support for job market and training programs, TAFE, Aboriginal employment assistance, higher education, and workplace and adult literacy. More than $9.8 billion is allocated in this Budget for these activities. Commendable as these initiatives are, I believe that, unless large scale job creation programs are instituted, the successful graduates of education or training programs will not have the opportunity to utilise their newly acquired skills, to the extent that they otherwise could, if there are no job vacancies.

Unfortunately for Australia, there are in this country self-styled economic experts who regard public job creation as a discredited idea. For example, the Liberal and National parties denigrate public job creation as a useful tool in assisting with economic recovery. Just as bad are those who regard public job creation with ambivalence. This Government is committed to the expansion and continuation of Skillshare programs and other job training programs. The Liberal and National parties are committed to abolishing Skillshare programs.

The conservatives are quite specific as to where they intend to make substantial cuts in jobs creation and job subsidy schemes. The Liberal and National parties economic and tax policy, published in October 1989, described in chilling detail what they would do were they to obtain office in this country. The Liberal and National parties' policy on labour and employment states:
The next Liberal/National Government will conduct a thorough review of all the Department's training and employment schemes. . . there will be less emphasis on job creation and job subsidy schemes.
JOBSTART, a wage subsidy scheme which replaced several other schemes, will be phased out as soon as practicable.
SKILLSHARE will also be phased out as soon as practicable.
Unemployment benefits under the next Liberal/National Government will be provided for a maximum period of nine months.

The Industry Training Support (ITS) Scheme will, in cooperation and consultation with employer groups, be phased out. The Liberal and National Parties strongly support industry efforts to upgrade workers' skills by providing training and retraining courses, but believe it is more appropriate for employers to accept the financial responsibility.

The CES demonstrably needs a massive overhaul. . . Its operations will be rationalised and some services will be privatised, for example, professional employment services. Other services will be contracted out and placed in the hands of State Governments, community and Church groups . . . Resulting cost savings are estimated to be up to 25 per cent of the total cost of operations, but additional savings are anticipated in later years.

The Liberal-National Party policy document then detailed the annual cuts it would make against the job schemes I have just mentioned: Jobstart, $85m; Skillshare, $61m; industry training support scheme, $36m; new enterprise incentive scheme, $7m; Australian traineeship scheme, $15m; and the Com- monwealth Employment Service, $50m. This gives an annual total of $254m. Those figures are in 1989 dollar terms.

These cuts which would be employed by the Liberal and National parties would destroy the combined efforts of thousands of dedicated and caring Australians to help the unemployed obtain work. But the fact is that employment opportunities must be available for the unemployed when they are job ready. It seems to be out of kilter that a nation can spend $9.8 billion on education and labour market assistance programs and not participate in job creation schemes. Job creation programs reduce unemployment and welfare payments.

The fact that community employment programs accounted for a small fraction of the total unemployment at the time has caused some people to mistakenly underestimate the true value of the community employment program. Perhaps one of the reasons for this is the inadequacy of the reports on the accomplishments of the community employment program. In Australia we do not find the so-called experts spouting more than vague generalities about the accomplishments and failures of job programs.

I have heard, and I am sure other members have heard, the mistaken assertion that the costs of job creation schemes are too onerous and therefore they should not be undertaken. But doing nothing is even more costly. The current budgetary deficit is mainly accounted for by the rapidly increasing income support payments and by falling tax revenues. I understand that higher employment benefits alone constituted 80 per cent of the real growth in Budget outlays this year. I urge the Government to act on this issue and act now. There is no shortage of job creation models, practical experience, both here and overseas, or indeed academic research work on the positive long term value of permanent job creation schemes. Levitan and Gallo make this additional observation:

Society's work is never done and there is no shortage of useful work that job creation programs would supply. A jobs creation program can offer ample work opportunities to fulfil needs currently unmet by the market economy. The limited skills of the workers assisted in jobs programs could be readily matched with many functions. . . Jobs programs have made and can make a tangible difference in alleviating hardship, supplying valued services (including labour intensive public works), and promoting the work ethic. Past mistakes justify improving--not abjuring--further efforts. President Roosevelt put it best in defending similar New Deal initiatives: `Better the occasional faults of a government that lives in a spirit of charity than the consistent omissions of a government frozen in the ice of its own indifference'.

Let me go on to record the fact that this Budget has been a wonderful boost to the well-being of Australian families. More than 200,000 families will benefit substantially from changes to the family payment system. For example, the family allowance supplement threshold will increase from $18,000 to $19,300. This initiative alone will make an extra 28,000 families eligible for the family allowance supplement. Another 81,000 families who are getting the part rate family assistance supplement will receive additional assistance. As a result of the increase in the threshold I referred to earlier, 109,000 families will be financially better off by $12 per week. The Government has altered the assets test arrangements to assist families, particularly in rural Australia, who have high assets but low incomes. I congratulate the Government on this initiative.

This Budget is a fair Budget and, above all, fair to the Australian people. It is one that contains many benefits--for economic growth, for jobs, for welfare, for social programs, and for the recovery of the Australian economy. Together, the Hawke Government and the Australian people, sharing the distinct Australian qualities of strength, resilience, and commonsense, will bring Australia confidently through the whole process of national reconstruction and renewal and thereby equip Australia, in the words of the Prime Minister:

. . . to enter the 21st Century with a strong, competitive economy as the essential foundation for our national goals of a progressive, enlightened, just society, uniquely diverse, but unshakeably united.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gallus Mrs C.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I wonder where the honourable member for Herbert (Mr Lindsay) is when he describes this Budget as a wonderful boost for Australians. With an unemployment rate of 10.4 per cent predicted, I wonder what would not be a wonderful boost for Australians.

SPEECH.PARA: The 1991 Budget is easily criticised and I do not think I can add much to this debate on the Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1991-92 by dwelling on the particular deficiencies already highlighted. Instead, I would like to look at one or two issues that this Government and this Government's Budget have failed to address.

I will first recount a conversation I had with a leading manufacturer which highlights part of my concern and the concern of my constituents about the present situation in Australia. The manufacturer was talking about Japanese investment in our country. He said:
They--the Japanese--want to invest here because we have cheap power, cheap labour and lower environmental standards than in Japan.

It sounds like something we might have said about emerging Asian countries three decades ago--cheap labour and low environmental standards. I believe we need Japanese investment in this country but if, indeed, these are the reasons why they invest here then I hang my head in shame. Australia--the nation that once had the highest standard of living in the world--is now a place to invest in because we have low environmental standards and cheap labour.

I have two reflections on this unhappy comparison. The first I have already alluded to--that our standard of living is falling and we are falling behind the rest of the world as it moves forward. The second relates directly to the environmental issue. One would think that this Government that has so aligned itself politically and rhetorically with the environmental lobby would have a better than average environmental record. I was concerned enough about my manufacturer's analysis to go to the library to check on the Japanese environmental standards compared to our own. What I found was sobering.

For instance, in Australia our per capita energy requirement is one-third greater than that of Japan. Per unit of GDP we have more than twice the carbon dioxide emissions from energy use than the Japanese and twice the per capita carbon dioxide emissions. Per unit of GDP our total emissions of greenhouse gases exceeded those of the Japanese by almost four times and per capita we exceeded them three times. Our municipal waste per capita was almost twice that of the Japanese. One good note was that our industrial waste was less than half theirs which, I suspect, reflects more our lack of industry than any particularly high standard of industrial waste control.

Our nation's emissions control standards are not adequate. Frequently we work on annual hourly averages for many of our pollutants--that is, the hourly average taken over one year. For example, in Japan sulphur dioxide is not permitted to exceed 0.04 parts per million as a daily hourly average. In Australia we cannot exceed 0.02 parts per million on a per annum hourly average. One does not have to be an Einstein to realise that with a shutdown of many industries at night time, and the majority at the weekend, there is large scope for wild fluctuations that harm health and the environment, and that by the time we realise we have a problem it is not sooner but later.

The statistics do not stop there. Japan still has 75 per cent of its native forests. Australia has destroyed 75 per cent of hers. Of total land area, 67 per cent of Japan is wooded and 14 per cent of Australia. Whereas 6.4 per cent of Japan has been designated a protected area, only 4.8 per cent of Australia has. On some issues we have a better environmental record than Japan. We do not slaughter as many dolphins and we have stopped killing whales. We import much less tropical timber. These are what may be described as sexy or vote winning issues. On the equally important, but less high profile, issues of pollution control Australia--which is not far from being, basically, an agrarian society--is worse off than one of the most highly industrialised countries in the world.

Care for the environment is basic to the survival of this country. What is needed is an overall strategy to protect our environment. That strategy needs to be an integral part of Government policy, not a quick fix solution to the more high profile issues. There is no indication from this Budget that in 1992 this Government will do any more than it has already done which is to pay lip service to populist issues and to pander to special interest groups. Neither the Budget nor Government policy has addressed the issue of the environmental needs of Australia as a whole, just as it has not addressed our major problems in other areas.

Recently, I heard Australia described as an international orphan. It struck me as particularly apt. Culturally and historically we are part of Europe but, having been colonised by Europe, Australia has been cast adrift by it. We are excluded from the European Economic Community--we have only limited access to its markets--and we are brought to our knees by European subsidies which force us to sell our major exports at bargain basement prices. Culturally, we are part of Europe; geographically, we are part of no-man's-land. We may claim to be part of South East Asia but I am not sure we even believe it ourselves. Our values, our system of justice, our major religions, our culture and our linguistic skills remain European based.

When our relationship with the rest of South East Asia is in the newspapers, more often than not it is because we have offended one or other of our South East Asian neighbours--the Malaysians, the Indonesians or the Singaporeans. Equally distressing, when we are not offending them we are currying favour or apologising for past misdemeanours in a way that I and many of my constituents find sycophantic and demeaning. Our relationship varies between the offensive and the fawning.

Our economic location in an ever shrinking world, where economic blocs are being forged on the basis of cultural and historical links as well as geographical proximity, is in desperate need of resolution. I am aware of the efforts of the Minister for Trade and Overseas Development (Dr Blewett) to overcome our trade problems. However, what I have not seen addressed--certainly not publicly--is the major question of how and, indeed, if, we can position ourselves for the new century in such a way that we can trade profitably and be accepted as part of South East Asia and the Pacific Rim without compromising either our identity or our heritage.

I will add nothing to this debate on the Budget if I comment that this Government is in disarray. That is obvious. I want to point out, on behalf of my constituents, that this Government is so far off the track that it has not the will, energy or time to address the current problems let alone the fundamental structural problems of Australia's role and place in the world in the twenty-first century. Far from being a blueprint for the future, the 1991-92 Budget offers the people of Australia the prediction of nothing but worse to come.

Several years ago we were aghast to learn the size of our net foreign debt. That debt has not shrunk; it has not stabilised. At $130.6 billion, it continues to grow. Now, in a betrayal of those people who elected it, this Government presides over an unemployment rate of 10 per cent, and the Budget predicts 10.4 per cent this year. The sad thing is that we are in danger of becoming numbed by the statistics and will fail to see the human misery they represent.

The unemployment problem is the result of the current recession, but it does not stop there. For reasons related and unrelated to the recession, more people will lose their jobs in the next few years. Australia is facing enormous problems. As a solution to some of these problems we are likely to lose some of our older industries, hopefully--although not certainly--to be replaced by more profitable ones.

The reduction of tariffs that has been started by this Government, and which will be hastened under a coalition government, is necessary for our long term survival. A country whose industries cannot stand alone without tariffs is on shaky economic ground. Tariffs exclude the possibility of export, as protected industries can rarely be competitive in the world market. They direct resources from possibly more efficient industries and, most importantly, they put up the prices of goods and services to the community.

Consumers have the right to the cheapest goods available and the country that puts tariffs on goods of a superior quality--whether it is shoes, clothes or cars--is acting against the interests and welfare of its citizens. However, there is another side to the reduction of tariffs and that is the collapse of those industries that only survive because they are protected by the tariff system. Industries are not living things--they neither breathe nor bleed. However, those people who work in them are living, breathing beings and the demise of particular industries has profound and devastating effects on the men and women who lose their jobs.

When industries collapse workers find they are unemployed. For many, this unemployment is not temporary and it is cruel to pretend it is. Retraining is only an option for the young, the literate and the mentally agile. For those people who have grown into middle age with an industry, their options are negligible. They face the next 20, 30, 40 or even 50 years as pensioners of the Government.

The recession has already pushed hundreds and thousands of such men and women onto government welfare; the restructuring of industry will add thousands more. The economic implications are profound but so too are the personal implications. Tears for the unemployed have been shed so frequently in this House of late that I suspect they have become devalued. What the unemployed want is not sympathy and not compassion; they want jobs.

Unemployment is not something that we tack onto a person's life like a car or a house. It is an essential part of the being of a person, who or what he or she is. A person's occupation is fundamental to what he is and how he sees himself. By taking away a person's job we can destroy him or her as a person. When the unemployed have families, their failure--it is perceived as a failure--is transferred to their children. Children growing up in a household where one or both parents are unemployed have a totally different childhood from children who do not have unemployed parents.

Earlier I provided some comparisons between the environmental record of Japan and Australia. Japan's unemployment rate is 3 per cent. Its youth unemployment is 5 per cent. We should compare that with our youth unemployment. With a 27 per cent youth unemployment, one in every three young people is unemployed. If the future of a country lies in its young people, what does that say about Australia's future?

We can already see the consequences of unemployment. Honourable members should look at our crime, vandalism and graffiti statistics. In my area it has risen by 10 per cent in the last year. Members of the community are justifiably up in arms about the increase in youth crime but they have no right to be surprised. What do young people owe a society that has wiped them off? What do they owe a society that says, `Oops, sorry, you can't get a job, you don't have a future, you'll never own a house, you'll never be able to buy your children nice clothes or let them sleep in a home that is theirs'? If we do not offer a future to our young people in this society there is a danger that they will form a society of their own--one that does not obey our rules. If we destroy the hopes of young people they will retaliate by attacking the people who abandon them. I hope that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Treasurer (Mr Kerin) are prepared for this, but I see no sign in the Budget or anywhere else that they are.

What was needed in Australia was a Budget that showed us a new direction and that indicated this Government was going to stop doing deals with unions and was going to get behind business--not just big business, but the hundreds and thousands of small businesses which do not need job creation schemes to employ people but simply a chance to prosper in an efficient and healthy business climate. But the Government has not done this and it has done nothing to assist the one million unemployed whose lives have been devalued.

I believe that it is not enough for us to provide our unemployed with welfare. I believe that governments and society have a responsibility to ensure that those who are unemployed and those who cannot get work have an alternative to being left alone with their welfare cheques and their frustration. I do not think the Government has the right to label unemployment as an economic necessity and walk away when that employment can render a person's whole life meaningless.

The Government's answer to date has been more training. Training is part of it but what is the point of training courses if people already have skills or if there are not enough jobs at the end of the training courses? Young people in my electorate get a terrible feeling of futility as they enrol in yet one more course.

Neither party in this House has a program of work for the dole--no longer, I suspect, because it is not fashionable to ask people who receive money from the state to contribute but because it is simply too expensive to run such schemes. What is the cost if we go on the way we are? In terms of human misery, it is probably incalculable. But economically the costs are also high and I do not think that this has been taken into account. Those who are out of work will lose their desire to work, they will lose their capacity to work and they will lose contact with those who do work. The Government will support them through their potential working years and on into old age and then we will probably support their children.

Our young people are unemployed and yet at the same time organisations that contribute to our society are collapsing for want of volunteers. There are environmental projects that are never undertaken because of a lack of workers and there are thousands of elderly people who need help in maintaining their homes. I cannot believe it is beyond the ingenuity of this Government and of this Parliament to bring these areas together. If it is, then I suspect the prognosis for Australia is not good.
This Budget has left me and many of my constituents with deep concerns about the future of this nation and the people who live here.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Free The Hon R.V.

TALKER.NAME: Mr FREE
TALKER.ROLE: -Minister for Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —-I rise to support the 1991-92 Budget. I will take this opportunity to comment on the Budget as it relates to my portfolio responsibility. This Budget has, once again, demonstrated the Government's strong commitment to science and technology. Mr Deputy Speaker, you will recall that last year Commonwealth support for science and innovation showed an increase of 2.4 per cent in real terms over the previous year. This year, in the context of fiscal restraint, Commonwealth support for major science and innovation programs has risen from $2,422m to an estimated $2,607m. This represents a real increase of 4.3 per cent. I will repeat that figure: it represents an increase in real terms of 4.3 per cent. This is clearly a successful outcome for science and technology and has been recognised as such. Let me read the comments of the Federation of Australian Scientific and Technological Societies, a group representing 60,000 people working in Australia on science and technology:

SPEECH.PARA: The 4.3% increase for science and technology was unexpectedly good.

It noted that last year the Government achieved a 2.6 per cent increase and said, `We thought that was excellent. This year's result is even better'. I point out to honourable members that this is not a one-off increase; it is part of the Government's continuing strategy to develop Australia's science and technology system and to ensure that it better meets national needs.

The Government has recognised the importance of science and technology since coming to office in 1983. Commonwealth support for science and innovation has increased 29 per cent in real terms since 1982-83. We have not only recognised the importance of science and technology in improving our national well-being and in helping develop internationally competitive industries; we have also done something about it. We have supported and strengthened our national science and technology effort.

I turn to some of the specific aspects of this year's Budget. The Government is to provide an immediate injection of $12m for CSIRO, the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation and the Australian Institute of Marine Science to enable these agencies to embark on a capital works restoration program. This program will include site development, building refurbishment, the upgrading and replacement of obsolete facilities and temporary buildings, and improved preventative maintenance. Total direct government support for the major research agencies will remain at the same real level in 1991-92 as in 1990-91. This is a real increase of 2.7 per cent for civil research agencies alone. This offsets a fall in funding for defence research and development, resulting from the Defence Force review.

In addition to its increased capital funding, the Australian Institute of Marine Science will be provided with $1.3m over three years. This will allow the Institute to conduct a more extensive investigation of factors adversely affecting the Great Barrier Reef.

The Budget appropriation to CSIRO has increased in real terms by 3 per cent. The research agencies receive funds in addition to those appropriated directly. These external funds include additional Commonwealth support won competitively through special purpose grants schemes, as well as funds received from business and from earned revenue. External funding to CSIRO has increased rapidly over recent years. The total amount to be spent by CSIRO this year will be $635m, of which $441m will be direct appropriation funding. In this Budget the funds available through directed research grants schemes are to increase from $309m to $384m, a real increase of 20 per cent. These grant schemes support areas such as medical, rural, energy and industrial research.

Support for research in the higher education sector will increase to an estimated $1,082m in 1991-92 from $987m in 1990-91. This represents a real increase of 6 per cent. The Australian Research Council funds, used to support university research, have increased in real terms by 37 per cent. Total support for industrial research, development and innovation, including both direct support through appropriations and the estimated costs to revenue forgone through the taxation concession for research and development, is expected to be $362m in 1991-92.

The Government has demonstrated its continuing commitment to science and technology in the most practical way that it can--by providing the funding needed to develop Australia's science and technology system as one of the best in the world. We have done this, and our success should be measured not by what we have put into the system but by the results that have been obtained. These results show in a clear and unambiguous way that the Government's approach, its strategic framework for science and technology, has been successful. The achievements, the important discoveries, advances and commercial applications that have resulted from this expenditure, and the longer term realignment of our science and technology effort to meet national needs, more than justify our commitment to science and technology.

I particularly draw the attention of honourable members to the sound performance of government research agencies in seeking to match their research directions more closely to national needs. The external funding targets set by government for a number of these agencies have certainly played a part in this, but the agencies have achieved a great deal themselves. Some members may be familiar with the priority setting mechanism which has been used within CSIRO. The work that CSIRO has carried out in this area has been a substantial achievement.

One very dramatic indicator of the success of the Government's strategic framework for science and technology has been the impressive increase in the level of research conducted by industry. Over the whole of the past decade, Australia has had one of the strongest rates of increase in business research and development of any country in the OECD. Over the period 1981-82 to 1989-90, the average real rate of growth in business research and development expenditure has been about 14 per cent per year. The latest figures show that in 1989-90, despite the slowdown in business activity, total business enterprise research and development continued to increase, although at a slower rate.

The growth in business expenditure on research and development has been accompanied by a growth of over 17 per cent a year in the number of overseas patent applications made by Australians. This rate in growth of patent applications to foreign countries is by far the highest growth rate of any country in the OECD, and it bodes well for future improvements in Australia's competitiveness.

I am not suggesting that there is no room for improvement. The Government is fully aware of the problems that continue to exist and is taking steps to overcome them. However, it cannot be denied that the progress made has been considerable. I now look forward to the opportunities which lie ahead. The Government will be taking, or continuing to act on, a number of initiatives over the coming year. The Government will shortly be receiving the recommendations of two task forces, which will identify impediments to the commercialisation of research and methods to improve our performance in this area.

In December the Government will announce the results of the second selection round of the cooperative research centres initiative, a program that will inject $100m annually into leading edge research.

Early in 1992 the winner of the prestigious Australia Prize for outstanding achievement in science and technology will be announced. Most importantly, however, in the first half of 1992 the Prime Minister will be tabling a White Paper on science and technology--the first such White Paper to be produced in Australia. The government intends that the White Paper will renew the sense of direction and purpose given by the 1989 statement Science and Technology for Australia.

The first stage in the preparation of the White Paper has already involved an unprecedented level of consultation with the representatives of all parts of the science and technology system, including the users of research. The White Paper will set strategic directions to guide Government decision making on science and technology into the future. It will cover all the key science and technology issues--such as major facilities and the balance of research funding--which have been dealt with in the past in a less coordinated fashion.

The White Paper will not, as has on occasions been suggested by the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran), prescribe detailed priorities within which all agencies must operate. The Government eschewed this approach in its 1989 statement Science and Technology for Australia. Rather, the Government's approach will continue to be one of devolving much of the responsibility for detailed priority setting to the people best qualified to do it--the scientists themselves and those who will be using the research outcomes.

I am sure that the honourable member for Gippsland, whose address to the National Science Forum Budget luncheon concentrated largely on an attempt to disparage the White Paper process, will in time come to understand and endorse the Government's approach to that process with the same belated alacrity with which last week he recognised the importance of achieving a highly skilled and suitably trained engineering work force in Australia. His contribution to the debate was no doubt enhanced by his reading of my speech to the 1991 engineering summit on this very matter some two months ago.

The Government's White Paper will provide a clear statement of the context in which science and technology are being carried out and will identify the important factors that should and will influence the priority setting process at all levels. It will be concerned with creating an environment which ensures that decisions are made in the most effective way and that we reap the best possible return from our considerable investment in science and technology--whether the return be measured in economic, social or cultural terms.

Throughout the 1980s, governments placed significant emphasis on maintaining excellence in scientific research while at the same time shifting the focus in educational and government research towards national goals. Government has also placed emphasis on lifting the level of private sector research and development.

More recently much has been said about forging stronger linkages between researchers and research users and about the need to concentrate on commercial outcomes of research. One object of this approach has been to achieve a fundamental change in attitudes to the role of research, and researchers, in society. It has been largely successful; even the most conservative of academic institutions now turn their minds to the utility of the work that they are performing.

The task now facing the Government is to capitalise on this mood: to ensure that research meets national goals and makes its contribution to Australia being internationally competitive and exporting the commercial applications of its scientific endeavour. The issues that the two task force reports, to which I have referred, will raise go beyond science and technology. They will include the availability of capital. Consideration must now be given as to how to make capital--both development and venture--more readily available to small, innovative Australian firms to facilitate their growth. In the past, attention has been drawn to cases where it was said Australia possessed significant competitive advantage but that required injections of capital were not forthcoming through the operation of the market. We must now find solutions to repairing the market's record in this respect.
I look forward to vigorously pursuing that issue both as Minister for Science and Technology and as Minister Assisting the Treasurer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Filing Mr P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —-This evening I would like to talk about the brave new Australia Labor has created under our southern skies, a brave new world where one million people are out of work, where we have record numbers of businesses going out of business, where the rural sector is in crisis and where the sick are turned out of hospital beds or left to rot in hospital queues.

SPEECH.PARA: This brave new Australia has just been subjected to another Commonwealth Budget in which nothing was announced that is likely to take us off the path towards which the former Treasurer, the honourable member for Blaxland (Mr Keating), predicted we would go--in other words, to the Third World status of a banana republic.

This evening I wish to address specifically that part of the Government policy that most heavily impacts upon the lives of the less fortunate, those who are sick and require the services of our health care system. The 1991- 92 Budget contained significant implications for the Australian health system. For the first time since 1983 the Government has introduced major changes to Medicare and in so doing has come reluctantly to acknowledge the magnitude of the crisis facing our health care system.

Let us look at the much-vaunted creation of the Federal Labor Government--Medicare and its funding. On 27 February 1983 the then Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Wills (Mr Hawke), defended his Party's proposed health plan, Medicare, as being viable, equitable and efficient. In 1983 Mr Hawke stated:
It will mean that nine out of 10 Australians will pay less for the health needs of themselves and their families.

Little time passed before that proportion was qualified to 75 per cent by the then shadow Minister for health, the honourable member for Bonython (Dr Blewett), in the election campaign, then it was changed to most and now one could say only some. On 24 May 1983 the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett), as he then was, said:
The introduction of Medicare is the biggest step ever taken by an Australian Government to ensure that every Australian has the best and cheapest medical and hospital care.

On 24 August 1983, the Minister is quoted as saying that Medicare would be self-financing once there was an upturn in economic activity. He said that this hoped-for economic upturn would substantially expand levy revenue in the coming years. He said:
This should more than compensate for increasing health costs so I am confident that the 1 per cent levy will make Medicare totally self-financing in future years.
Even as late as 4 June 1987, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) said:
. . . under the Government's Medicare proposals, the people of Australia, particularly those most in need, are significantly better off, as we promised they would be.
But Max Walsh in the Bulletin in 1983 obviously had much more foresight than the Prime Minister, by predicting a cuckoo in the nest for the Prime Minister and the Labor Government. He said:

The Cuckoo is a strange bird. It leaves its egg in the nest of another bird. The unsuspecting surrogate mother tends to look after the cuckoo chick with affection. This is repaid by the greedy young cuckoo quietly disposing of the genuine offspring. Medicare is a big cuckoo.

Medicare expenditure has increased from $2,018.8m in 1983-84 to an expected $8,583.7m in 1991-92--an increase of over 325 per cent. Collection of the Medicare levy has increased from $365m in 1983-84 to what is expected to be $2.58 billion in 1991- 92--far short of the total Medicare cost.

The decision by the Deputy Prime Minister and the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Affairs (Mr Howe) that was brought down in the 1991 Budget to effectively introduce a $3.50 Medicare charge for bulk-billed services is an admission that the high price of Medicare is not being met. Even in February 1991, the Minister was saying:
The Government has sought to manage an equitable approach to health insurance policy. It has been successful, it has been stable, it has resulted in the restraint of costs.

The $3.50 fee to be introduced in November will be increased to $5 next year and indexed thereafter. In addition, the Government has refused to rule out a further increase in the Medicare levy Australians pay, which currently stands at 1.25 per cent. The fact is that the levy has not covered the cost of Medicare. It does not even cover the cost of medical rebates under Medicare. In 1990 the Medicare levy raised $2.4 billion--a lesser contribution to health costs than the $2.7 billion provided by health funds.

In the early 1980s more than half of Australia's population was privately insured. The Commonwealth Government's encouragement of this in the form of rebates for those privately insured helped keep the price of private insurance down. Between 1984 and 1987, subsidies to the privately insured were withdrawn and costs of over $500m were imposed on insurers. The stock market crash in 1987 and the recession we had to have further exacerbated the problem with two results: cuts in Commonwealth funding to the States; and less disposable income for those who had private insurance. The number of privately-insured people fell from 63 per cent of the population in 1984 to 44 per cent in 1991.

The result is that today almost four million more Australians rely solely on Medicare than in 1984. There are now more Australians relying on Medicare, there is a greater demand on public hospitals which are reeling from funding cuts, there is less revenue for private hospitals as there are fewer private patients, and there is less revenue in the whole health system.
