Let us look at the first six years of Medicare. The total use of private medical services rose by 33.8 per cent from 112.7 million services in 1984-85 to 150.8 million services in 1989-90. Total fees charged rose by 77.7 per cent to $4,477.6m and Medicare benefits increased by 64.9 per cent to $3,738.8m. Medical service use per person increased by 23.2 per cent with the largest increase--42.6 per cent--in pathology.

The Minister for Health, Housing and Community Affairs claims that the $3.50 co- payment, dismantled bulk billing for medical services, and changes to rebates for pathology and radiology services will reduce over- servicing of medical services. But this must be looked at in light of a range of other factors that are inherent in our health system and need to be reformed. The introduction of the $3.50 fee, while acting as a price signal on doctor services, is likely to mean that doctors in poorer or rural areas will be disadvantaged and therefore should be compensated for an essential community service.

Currently, rural areas are under-resourced and under-staffed. Fewer than 25 per cent of doctors choose to practice in rural areas and there are five times as many doctors in city electorates as there are in rural Australia. Initiatives must be taken to improve this deplorable situation. Under the $3.50 rebate scheme, doctors would be encouraged to spend less time with their patients and valuable counselling services would be lost. Doctors would no longer have the incentive to offer better services. Instead, they would have incentives to cut corners, reduce services and provide lowest common denominator services.

One of the problems for the Labor Government associated with the fee, if realised, is that it would mean the end of free universal health care in Australia--which of course was the raison d'etre for the introduction of Medicare in the first place. Mr Wilson, the Western Australian Minister for Health, said on 31 August this year that the Federal Budget provision of a $3.50 payment for visits to general practitioners would mean that more patients would instead visit already overburdened public hospitals.

In my electorate of Moore a local public hospital, Wanneroo Hospital, provides the only accident and emergency services in the northern corridor of Perth. The northern corridor of Perth makes up the fastest expanding residential region in Western Australia and the second fastest in the country. This year the number of infant deliveries will approximate 1,100 and show an increase of 130 per cent from the 1986-87 figure of 466, typifying the growth in population surrounding the hospital.

Despite this overwhelming increase in population, Wanneroo Hospital--a medium- sized community-based hospital--has managed to decrease the number of accident and emergency admissions by 4 per cent from 15,600 in 1987-88 to 14,967 in 1990-91. This is largely due to the establishment of a number of general practice surgeries in the region which provide services for minor accidents that would otherwise require treatment at the Wanneroo Hospital outpatients clinic.

The main point here is that the treatment is being carried out at the appropriate level. Wanneroo Hospital has managed to deflect people to the appropriate service delivery point and valuable resources can be allocated to those who need emergency attention. The Wanneroo Hospital has not received an increase in real term funding for three years and, in order to cope with the funding cuts, may be forced to restrict theatre use and/or close wards.

The $3.50 charge that was brought down in the 1991-92 Budget is likely to encourage people back to outpatients clinics and to free `hospital Medicare'. Wanneroo Hospital simply could not cope if this became the trend. How long will it be before an admission charge in accident and emergency is introduced at public hospitals? Only time will tell.

The Western Australian Labor health Minister, Keith Wilson, said earlier this year that Federal general revenue and public hospital funding to Western Australia had declined in per capita terms by about 22 per cent since the introduction of Medicare. He said:

Federal funding for hospitals had dwindled, while patient demand rose because of Medicare's promotion of free hospital care . . . Public hospitals are reaching the point where we can no longer hold the floodgates . . . We're already over-loaded in terms of surgery waiting lists . . . The Commonwealth is just making the position more impossible.

In my electorate, a number of constituent cases have been brought to me which tell the sorry story of how Medicare is hurting the people it was originally set up to help--the low income earner who has been forced onto the waiting lists for elective surgery for up to two years.

One of my constituents, 70-year-old Mr Sid Dallas, is an aged pensioner. He is a diabetic who has had a number of heart bypass operations. He was diagnosed as requiring a cataract operation on his right eye over two years ago and was put on the waiting list then. On 23 July this year he was advised in writing of his admission to Royal Perth Hospital on 8 August 1991. On the morning of 8 August, and again at midday, Mr Dallas telephoned the hospital to check the schedule of his operation and was advised to come in to the hospital at 2 p.m. Mr Dallas took the lengthy bus trip to the hospital--it takes about 50 minutes from where he lives--and, on arrival, was admitted to his ward. After being examined by a doctor and being advised that his operation would take place the next day, Mr Dallas settled down to have his evening meal in the hospital. At about 5.30 p.m. Mr Dallas was visited again by a doctor who told him that the operation would not be going ahead the next day due to a shortage of staff and that he should go home.

Mr Dallas asked why he had not been told of this earlier and was told that there was no adequate explanation. He was told to contact the hospital again on Monday, but with no guarantee that there would be a suitable time for his operation. Mr Dallas then walked away from the hospital incensed and disappointed. He walked to the bus station and took the 50-minute journey back to a shopping centre near his home. By this time he was becoming short of sugar and short of breath from anxiety about the way in which he had been treated. On arrival at the shopping centre where the bus took him, he intended to phone for a taxi but, because of the number of larrikins in the vicinity, he decided to walk home. After the 25-minute walk from the bus station on a cold evening, Mr Dallas arrived home; his wife was shocked and alarmed at his exhausted state.

One of the most recognised patient problems associated with hospital operations is the anxiety experienced by the patient before he is admitted. A patient goes through a huge amount of trauma before he even gets to the hospital. People are scared of operations. They are worried about being anaesthetised, about not waking up and about all the other problems associated with operations. When a patient goes all the way to hospital and is then told that he has to go home because, through no fault of his own, his operation will not go ahead, a great amount of stress is naturally experienced. At the whim of the hospital he will have to go through all the pre-operation trauma again for his next hospital visit.

The message is that ultimately it is the people of Australia who are suffering from the declining standard in the provision of services. It is the low income earner, the man in the street on welfare benefits--the very person Medicare was introduced to help--who is staying sick under the Labor Government's health policy. The irony of this is quite incredible. The Royal Perth Hospital is reeling from this year's State Budget cut of about $6m in real terms. Western Australia's big public teaching hospitals will lose 3 per cent of their funding in real terms. To try to save money, the Royal Perth Hospital has wound back services on every fourth Friday in the month that will result in the further lengthening of waiting lists for elective services.

Only recently, an 80-year-old woman lost two toes through gangrene after waiting for attention at the Royal Perth Hospital. This catastrophe could have been avoided but, because she had to wait for treatment, her toes had to be removed. The hospital system simply cannot cope with the enormous pressure suffered under Medicare. At the Queen Elizabeth II Medical Centre, outpatient services on Fridays have been cut and even the internal pharmacy is closed, so no-one can buy drugs on Fridays.

The cutbacks in hospital funding will encourage the treatment of private patients in public hospitals to the detriment of the low income earner as public hospitals scramble for limited funding. According to the Private Hospitals Association of Victoria, there is evidence that private patients seeking treatment in public hospitals are given preferential treatment, thus reducing their waiting time, and that, for financial reasons, public hospitals give priority to private patients who yield a higher return to the hospital. According to the APHA, between 1982-83 and 1988-89 the average waiting list in Victorian public hospitals grew by over 100 per cent, from 10,000 to 20,400. This situation is similar in all States. The Australian Private Hospitals Association estimates that there are 75,000 Australians at any one time awaiting admission to public hospitals. One can guarantee that most of these people could not afford private health insurance, let alone pay their own way to better health.

According to the Voluntary Health Insurance Association of Australia Ltd, unless urgent action is taken now to reform the Australian health system, it is most unlikely that there will be an adequate financial base to meet the necessary costs that will face this nation and its population. A number of alternatives have been looked at, but what is overwhelmingly clear is that major reforms must be made to the financing of the health care system to encourage freedom of choice, economic rationalism, cost effectiveness and efficiency. A recent $8m scheme announced in the Western Australian State Budget involves both private and public hospitals submitting tenders for elective surgery, with the most cost effective program being accepted. However, the scheme is likely to reduce private health insurance further, as people who are currently privately insured see public patients having operations in private hospitals and realise that they could access the same service for free under Medicare.

Already thousands of Australians have passed up private insurance for the `free' alternative--Medicare--which, according to Government rhetoric and Prime Minister Hawke, is accepted by 70 per cent of the community. They are led to believe that if Medicare is there then they can do without private health insurance. Health insurance premiums have increased as, increasingly, a higher proportion of those insured are sick or think they will need access to medical services at some time. Of course, this pushes up premiums, more healthy people drop out and the downward spiral continues. These days a significant proportion of people who could otherwise afford private health insurance are opting to take their chances with public health services and are not taking out insurance. They are prepared to pay if something goes wrong, but this means not only that public hospitals will neglect the poor at the expense of the paying wealthy, but also that valuable money that could be spent on private health insurance is lost to the general health system.

ABS figures from last year show that a quarter of Australians who earned more than $800 a week were not privately insured. One- third of those who earned more than $600 a week were not insured, yet 650,000 Australians who earned less than $240 a week were insured. The answer must be to encourage those who can afford it to take out private health insurance and to put paid to the belief held by many Australians that the payment of 1.25 per cent of their taxable income is sufficient to provide them with benefits of 85 per cent of their doctor's bill and allow them access to a public hospital.

Australians have an incredibly high doctor visit rate of 7.8 per year, compared with 6.4 in Canada and 5.3 in the United States. The hospital admission rate in Australia is 21.6 per cent, compared with 14.5 per cent in Canada and 14.7 per cent in the United States. According to the Australian Institute of Health, in 1987-88 health expenditure was $23.4 billion, or $1,415 for every Australian. However, very little debate has taken place on whether these expenses were necessary or desirable. Of course, the costs of this are a huge burden on the public purse. The obvious intent of the $3.50 co-payment or co-charge is to reduce over-servicing and over-usage which has been encouraged by the lack of any co-payment by the patient. The Rand health insurance experiment conducted in the United States between 1974 and 1977 concluded that co-payments resulted in a significant decline in total medical expenditure; a significant reduction in the number of episodes of care initiated by patients but no change in the type of care provided by doctors; a disproportionate effect upon services used by the poor and sick; and little overall impact on general or mental health.

Obviously, the equity issue is of importance here, but the overall message is that patients should be made aware of the high cost of the health services they are utilising. If the Government offered incentives that induced 55 per cent of the public to take out private health insurance--an increase of only 10 to 11 per cent on present figures--Medicare outlays would fall, waiting lists would be reduced, private health funds could reduce premiums and become even more attractive to join, and, most importantly, the changes would make health care access quick and equitable.

Federal and State funding arrangements should be reviewed. One alternative would be to allocate funding to hospitals and health services according to the services provided and procedures performed, with the aims of rewarding and promoting efficiency, providing fairer returns to hospitals and ensuring appropriate standards of clinical effectiveness.

Medicare's main claim to fame--to provide free universal health care--is being challenged and will most likely be routed. In order for Australia's health care system to regain its footing, private health insurance must be encouraged for those who can afford it and in turn the injection of funds into the health sector via private insurance will contribute more to the standard of health services in Australia. This will contribute to the restoration of equity in health services so that the most needy can access adequate treatment with minimal waiting time. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson Mr L.D.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —-By largely limiting himself to doorstop interviews, the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) has managed to evince solidity and integrity. Admittedly, there were concerns about his grasp of reality and ideological rigidity. However, an intemperate Budget outburst and sneering references to those he perceived as vulnerable and unpopular have altered all that. A shameful tirade of cant and vindictive attacks is not excused by a lack of notes.

SPEECH.PARA: As the world faces a multitude of patently obvious environmental problems--hazardous chemicals, carbon dioxide levels, depletion of the ozone layer--none of these impresses the Leader of the Opposition. In one of his few forays into specific itemised retrenchments in the Budget, he deplores the $20m for the World Bank environment commitment and attempts to demolish the long overdue Environmental Protection Agency. Not for him a growing concern about global survival; not for him the push for international protocols.

The glorious statements of the honourable member for Hawker (Mrs Gallus) quite recently in this House received scant attention from the Leader of the Opposition who dismisses those people interested in this field as the Green movement and a new breed of bureaucrats. Despite the Opposition's public adherence to the reconciliation process, Aboriginals are just too easy a target for conservative politicians. It was thus no surprise that those who laboured to improve their conditions were dismissed with a derogatory reference about `the Aboriginal heritage movement'. The horrendous health problems and declining life expectancy, the internationally spectacular incarceration levels and the poor educational retention rates are of no concern to the Leader of the Opposition when the alternative option is a cheap kick.

Similarly, as the numbers of unemployed grow, family break-ups ensue and the homeless rise, we would expect some praise for those people out there trying to pick up the pieces. No, the best they get is the description `do gooders' and `community workers'-- apparently pejorative in the lexicon of the honourable member for Wentworth. This sits ill with the stream of crocodile tears for the unemployed and closing businesses. It sits ill with the derision of Labor's increased training programs and labour schemes--whether Job Search, the training and skills program, the self-employment assistance scheme or the employment access program.

Despite the persistent denigration of job creation schemes by the Opposition, this time we are assured it is simply, `throwing a bit of money in the direction of training'. It ill becomes the Opposition to deride these efforts in the face of its heartless calls for an end to employment benefits after nine months. If the Leader of the Opposition is to be believed we also have decreasing standards of service in Medicare and ever decreasing standards of education. They also require neither increased expenditure nor community workers.

Then we had the rather pitiful resort to little politician bashing--always a good standby. For that day and that day alone they were recipients of `fat salaries, fat superannuation and VIP aircraft and cars'. I have not noticed the honourable member for Wentworth advancing a boycott of conditions, calling for cutbacks or leading the charge for restraint on his back bench. Come to think of it, the Opposition is singularly unreceptive to the idea that anyone should share the sacrifice of restraint, bar wage and salary earners. Additionally, despite the historical, unrelenting attitude that any restrictions on overseas borrowings or regulation in the economy is anathema, we witness the use of Skase and another obviously identifiable entrepreneur as transitory targets. The Opposition Leader's unseemly references to the latter's private life typified a rather unsavoury performance. In a laughable curtsy to the John Birch brigade there was a passing reference to the supposed interference of the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) regarding what books students could read.

Finally, in a demonstration of unbridled hypocrisy, the Opposition Leader had the temerity temporarily to assail tax evasion. Obviously, the reference to the issue of favourable tax breaks for the wealthier in superannuation is simply a convenient political sideswipe at this laudatory government initiative. However, the comments on fringe benefits and negative gearing do not square with the historical record.

I was interested to read the debates of 8 May 1986 when the honourable member for Warringah (Mr MacKellar) led for the Opposition in a debate on fringe benefits. After hearing the Leader of the Opposition this week being so appalled at those people who cheat on fringe benefits, it was quite surprising to read the words of the leading Opposition spokesman in that debate in 1986. In that debate, the honourable member for Warringah said:

There are numerous other anomalies and difficulties with this appalling new business tax . . . We are totally opposed to this new payroll tax which will destroy investment and destroy employment. We will vote against it here . . . We will maintain our determination to oppose it both here and all around the countryside.

Just to show the lack of credibility of honourable members opposite in regard to their various projections for superannuation job losses, I was interested to read in the honourable member's speech his predictions on the number of jobs that would be lost as a result of the fringe benefits tax. He predicted that a $50m gain would cost 10,000 jobs in the motor industry alone. I do not think that the honourable member would repeat those predictions in this House today.

In summary, the Budget performance of the Leader of the Opposition consisted of a boots and all attack on all and sundry who in any way could be held up as scapegoats. There were limited references to a call for a balanced Budget with scant reference to how it could conceivably be accomplished, whether by itemised revenue increases or drastic expenditure cuts. His credibility has been further eroded with the Opposition advocacy of $1 billion worth of extra road funding for Queensland, pork-barrelling for the rural sector and the imminence of National Party demands for Job Search and job training increases in the context of its conference's new found radicalism.

What really was to be reduced in the throwaway suggestions about this Budget balance? Was it the national rail freight and related micro-economic reform or was it to be the family allowance assistance that spread to many more households in this Budget? Was it the much praised and more equitable child- care initiatives? Was it increased expenditure on the unemployed? We are all left wondering.

I turn now to some Budget initiatives. The honourable member for Ryan (Mr Moore) alone indicated endorsement of a nebulous national superannuation scheme and quite properly advocated prudential controls of funds. In all other respects the Opposition was limited to unsubstantiated allegations that superannuation is, to quote the honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher), simply a redirection of `the existing commitment people have to savings' and the predictable tunnel vision warnings of resultant job losses. There was absolutely no substantiation of the correlation of a decline in private savings and the onset of superannuation growth.

The Government has moved to consolidate a degree of security for Australians as they age. This is more pressing as the reality of the dependency ratio and the ageing hits home. Without taking inflation into account, over the next 20 years age pension costs of $4,860m will increase by 120 per cent. Equally, by the year 2030 the number of citizens over 65 years will have risen from 11 1/2 per cent to 21 1/2 per cent.

Obviously, this is not an Australian phenomenon and the developed world faces problems typified in figures for the former West Germany. Between 1950 and 1980 the life expectancy of West German citizens rose from 66 years to 73 years. With a fertility rate drop from 2.1 per cent to 1.4 per cent, the dependency ratio is reaching crisis point. In the OECD as a whole the old age dependency rate will rise from 18.9 per cent in 1980 to 33.3 per cent in 2010.

Turning to Australia again, the year 2011 will see the over 65-year-olds overtake in number those aged between 15 years and 24 years. In summary, our pension processes face increasing pressures. This is perhaps a contributing factor to the Opposition Leader's references to the broad brush statistic of PAYE contributions to social welfare moving from 68c to 86c in the dollar between 1982 and 1991.

As well as the abovementioned urgency of action on superannuation we had the widespread abuse of the existing system by some sectors of industry. This was despite the major gains made by the union movement and the Labor Government in its extension. When the Opposition tries to divert from its own scandalous record it is worth remembering that, when Labor was elected to government, of those people earning less than $200 a week a little over a quarter had superannuation, but for those people earning above $440 a week, nearly three-quarters had superannuation. So much for the Liberal's preoccupation with the issue of taxation preference for wealthy
superannuation contributors under Labor. They certainly found it relatively attractive under the previous regime.

What have we witnessed in the interim? The proportion of workers reported by employers to have superannuation coverage has been augmented from 41.6 per cent in 1986- 87 to 66.8 per cent in 1989-90. Of note, the private sector has seen an explosion from 32 per cent to about 57 per cent. Of the estimated 4.8 million people who have an entitlement, more than 80 per cent have been receiving it. Nevertheless there have been sectors that have been notable for abuse and avoidance of responsibility. The motor industry, clerical, hospitality and textiles are amongst those industries. Thus in October 1990 departmental officers found that the hotel industry had 38 per cent compliance. After a drive it reached 70 per cent in March the following year.

Excuses given by employers must leave some doubt as to their managerial skills. Thus in the same period a survey found that of those not paying, a massive 44.4 per cent allegedly did not know about superannuation and 17.2 per cent did not comprehend how it worked. This was despite constant Opposition harangues about the pernicious spread of superannuation. A very significant number of people in those industries did not seem to have picked up the message about superannuation. The range of measures by this Government is in the context of a 1991-92 wage outcome of 5 per cent.

The superannuation moves recognise the greater difficulties for small business--those with payrolls of less than $500,000. This is accomplished by a more steady progress to the prescription of 9 per cent aimed for the year 2000, with the levels becoming equal in 1995-96. Given another 3 per cent superannuation sought through employees' contributions and tax cuts, this adds up to 12 per cent of earnings going into superannuation at the century's turn.

Simultaneously, the Government has indicated that it will make overdue intervention into the regulation of these funds. The current practice of limited controls through the Occupational Superannuation Standards Act do not suffice. The threat of tax concession losses is not necessarily decisive. The gestures by the Insurance and Superannuation Commission to promote incorporation spells a necessary first step. Being discussed quite openly is the exclusion of the dishonest and previously bankrupt capital assets requirements, greater revelations of the financial position of companies in their annual reports and more precise details at entry and exit.

In conclusion, we have a package that cements the move to broader coverage, that amplifies prudential controls and ensures a process of enforcement by the Australian Taxation Office in regard to fee extraction with no deductibility--a firm ingredient for compliance, given the added calculation for superannuation earnings. Obviously, increasing amounts of money will lie with these funds--savings that would not otherwise pass to them.

Methods must be found to ensure that financial packages are constructed to accomplish some adherence to national needs, whether in national infrastructure, research and development or encouragement of value added export and import substitution industries. Rhetoric about managers' ultimate responsibility to bring home the bacon for the funds will serve little purpose if this nation's trade balance and internal infrastructure deteriorate for lack of investment, conditioned by market failure.

This brings me to the issue of the building better cities program, which will cost $800m over the next five years. It has been described by those opposite as `grand cities fantasies', `Alice in Wonderland', and the `mad cities program'. I prefer the view of the New South Wales Premier, Mr Greiner, who certainly has a better track record of electoral success than those opposite. He was a party to the Special Premiers Conference in June 1991, which concluded that this policy area is urgent; that there was a need for government cooperation; that the steady spread of urban sprawl had to be restricted; and that a more commercial orientation had to be given to some service delivery.

However, in the post-Budget period he has gone further in distancing himself from the negative attacks of the Opposition; in fact, he lamented what he regarded as a low figure of $57m for 1991-92. Further strong support for the scheme has been provided by the Australian Council of Social Services, which stated:
Over the last two decades public sector investment has fallen by more than 20%. It is now at its lowest levels for at least 40 years.

Of course, it has been particularly concerned with a decline by half in public housing funding since 1986-87. Other speakers have cited some of the statistical backing for this urgent program. The public funding proportion of fringe land development in Sydney is at 54 per cent. There is a 2.2 : 1 ratio of fuel use when compared with a group of 12 European cities, including London, Paris and Frankfurt. It is also estimated that 67 per cent of Sydney's household growth over the next 40 years will be in the fringe areas that are costing so much to the public. Public transport use is one-fifth to one-half less than that of the 12 European cities. Yet, to borrow an expression from one of the less reputable spiritual inspirations of those opposite, Spiro Agnew, these nabobs of negativism opposite can only squawk about the loony Left and mad cities plans.

Another example of the public perception of the importance--even for the Opposition--of this area is that this Parliament's Standing Committee for Long Term Strategies has constructed a subcommittee to deal with the pattern of urban settlement. That typifies the realities of the agenda that is being set rather than the rhetoric of those opposite that is convenient in this debate. That investigation will look at the economic and environmental impact of human settlement, major determinants of settlement patterns, desirable growth, ecologically sustainable patterns, equity in provision, the interrelation of new infrastructure and urban consolidation. The Premier of New South Wales, the Premiers Conference, the Council of Social Service, and the Committee for Long Term Strategies have all seen a need for it. Yet it is decried by those opposite for political convenience. Frankly, Australia cannot afford that attitude.

It is an attitude which certainly is dismissed, even under the Bush Administration in the United States. I will quote two people in the US who are aware of the infrastructure requirements. In the 1990 Economic Report of the President, Michael Boskin, the Chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers said:

Inadequate government infrastructure can impede improvements in productivity growth. . . Taking advantage of productive opportunities to maintain and improve the infrastructure is an important part of federal, state, and local government policies to raise economic growth.
Equally, the Secretary of Transportation, Samuel Skinner, stated:

It is intuitively apparent that some public investments--particularly those of infrastructure such as streets, highways, airports, and water and sewer systems--provide direct productive services and are complementary with private capital. Comparisons over time and across countries seem to indicate that some relationship may exist between additions to such capital and growth.

What is dismissed by those opposite as madness--the loony Left--is certainly being found to be a lot more interesting by the Bush Administration of the United States, as it perceives the failures of the deregulation period under the previous Administration.
In a similar vein, looking at the United States, in March-April 1991 there was an article in Challenge by David Aschauer from a 1990 paper by the Economic Policy Institute. He said:

The last decade has witnessed a third deficit--a deficit in spending on vitally needed public works--which is central to some of our most important long-term economic difficulties. . . our declining private profit rate on machinery and structures, our overall failure to invest adequately in our future, and our sluggish growth in productive efficiency.
A one per cent increase in the stock infrastructure capital will raise productivity by 0.24 per cent.

In the long run--in this case four or five years--the `crowding in' effect dominates and overall private investment is stimulated. Indeed, for every $1 increase in public investment, private investment rises by approximately 45c.
They are some of the indications of what other people with no axe to grind about the massive problems of urban expansion see as being required.

I turn now to the question of migration. I am pleased to support the increase in charges in this Budget. I think there has been deep concern in Australian society about the way in which the social security system in this country--including Medicare--has been threatened by recent arrivals. Unfortunately, in some countries they are able to obtain convenient doctors certificates. Five minutes after walking down the plank at Sydney airport they have congenital illnesses.

A series of measures in this Budget will ensure that there is at least some protection from fraudulence or, in some cases, change of circumstances which mean that people cannot make commitments to support new settlers. As well as that, it will discourage a significant number of people who have no intention whatsoever of fulfilling those requirements but who know very well that they will be soon dependent on the social security system.

I turn to foreign aid, which has been a very controversial area. It is one of the few areas in which the Opposition has been able to get its act together and has been able to itemise as an area that can be attacked. This Budget sees a one per cent increase in real terms in foreign aid. That follows a deterioration since 1985-86 of 4.8 per cent. It represents a very positive advance on the situation in 1990-91 when the Australian Council for Overseas Aid declaimed the `rubbery figures' in the Budget that were centred around the 100 million contributions to the World Bank and the Asia Development Bank being held over.

This Budget is very much appreciated. It represents a 10 per cent increase in aid to non-government organisations and $60m over four years to the environmental assistance program, which will deal with population, family planning, forestry, climate change and the World Bank global environment facility. It represents a significant trend away from previous downturns and recognises criticisms made by people such as the Anglican Archbishop of Sydney, the Reverend Donald Robinson, last year, when he spoke of a broken promise to maintain aid levels and of promises with `expiry dates set for just after the election'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Mr B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I rise this evening to contribute to the debate on the Appropriation Bill (No. 1). This Budget fails the 850,000 people who are currently unemployed. It fails to give business any confidence to invest in the future and, in so doing, it fails to create jobs. It fails to address the real problems of Australia's worsening balance of payments figures and it fails Australian families.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government's response to those areas of criticism has been to bring down a Budget which will mean that next year we will be $4.7 billion worse off than we are this year. Its response is to introduce a 5 per cent superannuation tax--a new tax on employment. The Government is set to bring in legislation which will increase fringe benefits tax--another tax on employment--and it will introduce an assets test on the family allowance, just to name a few of the areas that will impact on people's everyday lives.

I was elected 18 months ago and, since then, I have taken a hands-on approach when travelling around my large electorate. Recently I was in the far south-west and was hoping that I could take members of my electorate some good news--unfortunately, I had to take them bad news.

What I had to tell my constituents was that the Federal Government proposes to bring in an assets test on family allowances with a ceiling of $600,000. The artificial sweetener in the legislative package takes the form of the hardship provisions. I use the term `artificial sweetener' because the fine print of the legislation must be read. The fact of the matter is that this time last year an assets test did not apply to the family allowance.

The difficulty confronting people in rural Australia is that many of their assets are virtually worthless. They certainly are not saleable. `For sale' signs appear everywhere throughout rural Australia--and in the cities, for that matter--and it is very difficult to determine the worth of assets. There have been many instances in which people who are eligible for government assistance have had the value of their assets determined a year or so later by the Australian Valuation Office, resulting in their having to repay some of the government assistance they received. This has come as a particularly savage blow to families in rural areas who are suffering extreme financial hardship.

What assistance has this Government provided for rural education? In these extremely desperate times in rural Australia, I would have thought that the Government would increase the levels of assistance through Austudy and AIC. Alas, this did not happen. Unless this Government wakes up very soon, the kids from rural Australia will be the innocent victims of the recession that we `had to have'.

Prior to the winter recess, the Opposition called for hardship provisions to be included in the eligibility criteria for Austudy. The hardship provisions that are attached to educational assistance really mean that applicants have to be at the stage of leaving the family farm under part C of rural adjustment, which means they are on the way out, on their way to the cities to find a job. They virtually have to be destitute to receive assistance. The hardship provision that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) assured the President of the National Farmers Federation he would fix up is absolutely worthless and does not go to the core of the problems experienced by rural families. As a result, because so many parents who live in rural areas are unable to support their children while they are living away from home, it is likely they will be denied further education.

What does the Government propose to do about decentralising Australia? Over the next five years, the Government proposes to spend $800m on a better cities program. Surely the Minister for Land Transport (Mr Robert Brown), who is presently at the table, could have siphoned off some of that money to improve funding for roads throughout rural Australia. It might be all very well to talk about a better cities program; but what about decentralising the economy and decentralising Australia? Everyone knows that the cities are overcrowded, but there is no overcrowding in my electorate, where the population of the largest town is 8,000. My electorate could do with a population boost. Some of that $800m could well have been directed to rural Australia instead of to the `golden triangle' to which I often refer--Canberra, Melbourne and Sydney.

It is the local councils throughout rural Australia that will lose out. They will have to go to their ratepayers and increase their rates to maintain the infrastructure and to keep the services of the men who have worked there for years and live in caravans for weeks on end while they are grading roads. I invite the Minister for Land Transport to accompany me on a trip to a place I visited two weeks ago, namely, Thargomindah in the Bulloo Shire, and I hope he takes me up on my offer. The shire council had hoped to receive main roads funding and additional funding in these difficult times, but the allocations have been withdrawn.

Projects that have been on the go for many years have had to be pigeonholed. However, one important project that will definitely go ahead is the bridge over Cooper Creek at Nappa Merrie, which will be funded by the local ratepayers. The Minister for Land Transport may smile, but it will be a very important bridge. The Bulloo Shire Council has decided to locate the bridge two miles upstream from the site of the very historic Burke and Wills `dig tree'. Presently, there is no road to the site of the bridge and there is no road going away from it. The importance of the bridge is illustrated by the fact that behind every sand dune there is a four-wheel- drive vehicle driven by a tourist bringing money into the inland.

The bridge will be important in terms of not only tourism but also trade. During the wet season, the river floods and it is often four or five months before people can bring bullocks from the other side of the Cooper to the markets. So often during those five month periods potential trade is lost. I ask the Minister to come out there with me one day.

TALK.START.PARA: —-He wants to open it.

—-If he will give me some money, we will go out there together. We will need only $1m. An amount like that would be a good kick-start. That area is a beautiful part of the world and the bridge will be a very important bridge. It could eventually mean that Melbourne will be linked to Darwin. What a wonderful trade route, what a wonderful inland development road, that would be. It would allow products to be moved and allow tourists to see the great outback.

SPEECH.PARA: What did the Budget do in the area of health care? I ask the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services (Mr Howe) to look very critically at the proposal in respect of pathology services. It is proposed to introduce a licensing fee of $1,000 for pathology collection centres. In order to qualify for a transaction fee, which is designed to compensate for the reduction in the Commonwealth's refund on pathology tests, a pathology centre must process approximately 1,000 patients a month. The real issue here is the level of service provided in rural Australia. Although there are many pathology collection centres in my electorate, they do not process anywhere near 1,000 patients a month. I doubt whether there would be 1,000 patients a month through the entire electorate.

The Government should think very carefully before it casts the net and says, `Let's rationalise the overservicing that is taking place in the pathology industry. Let's charge a fee of $1,000 and have a transaction levy that will transfer some of the debt'. I ask the Government to exempt pathology collection centres in rural Australia from that fee. If it does not do so, there will be a further deterioration in rural health. Although the present infrastructure does not pay, it is critical that we keep it, otherwise this expertise will drift to the cities and jobs will be lost. The sad fact is that, as a result of the introduction of this fee, there will be a deterioration in health services in rural Australia.

The March economic statement made many promises. The people of my electorate are looking to this Parliament to keep some of those promises by enacting legislation. The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean) has referred to the exemption applying to oils and lubricants and the promise of an exemption on road vehicles that are used exclusively within the production premises, whether the activity is associated with mining or agriculture. The problem is that we have not seen that legislation yet.

There is an urgent need for the legislation to which I have referred to be introduced into this Parliament as a matter of priority. Right now, many people throughout rural Australia are preparing land to grow crops this summer and mining companies are continually extracting minerals and coal to sell on overseas markets. These producers would welcome the relief afforded by an exemption from sales tax. It clearly is a tax on production while it remains.

We only have to look at the plight of the woolgrower today compared with three years ago. We only have to look at the estimates from ABARE. God bless ABARE figures, though I criticise them all the time! In 1989-90, those figures showed that the average cash operating surplus for a woolgrower was $45,000. For the coming year, 1991-92, ABARE estimates a woolgrower will receive a mere $300. Any tax impost that can be removed from producers' cost inputs will be welcome. If the Minister has any influence in that area, I ask him to ensure that that legislation comes into this House as a matter of urgency, because it would be very welcome in rural Australia.

Let me focus some attention on the environment. This year the Budget allocation for the environment increased by $19.6m. In real terms, that is an increase of 12.6 per cent. That is a good thing and I commend the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Mrs Kelly), who has been in an awful lot of trouble this week, for that increase. But if we look at the fine print, once again we will find that much of the increase is dedicated to the international arena. We should be putting our own house in order before we start to increase spending overseas. In this very difficult time, there is very little in this Budget to give Australian farmers any incentive to go out and do something in the area of land care.

I ask the Minister responsible to consider some of the resolutions that were passed at the National Party conference at the weekend. I believe that they went a long way towards recognising the problems the rural sector and our farmers are going to be confronted with in the next few years. One of those resolutions, a very important one, was to implement a tax rebate or credit system for on-farm soil conservation. This would rectify the `profit before conservation' mentality of the current Government. To get any benefit from the current scheme, people have to be in profit to get the 100 per cent write-off for the cost incurred in the year of expenditure. If there were a tax credit or tax rebate scheme, it would be able to be passed on to a year when a profit did occur and it could be offset against tax in that year. I think that is a sensible approach. It encourages people in times when they do not have the cash to continue on with the land care which is necessary, and we certainly must continue to encourage that.

Another important resolution was to reinstate direct Commonwealth funding for drought aid. There are difficulties in determining what a drought really means. For that matter, I inform the Minister that many people out in Thargomindah in the far west of Queensland, in my electorate, have to look up the dictionary to see what `bitumen' means, because we do not have any of that out there, as we will show him when he comes to see our bridge. But we do recognise what a cyclone is; we recognise what a flood is. I do not think it is too difficult for us to identify what drought is and what it does.

The Darling Downs has just gone through the driest period in recorded history. The Darling Downs has records going back 100 years and has some of Australia's prime agricultural land; I believe it has some of the finest agricultural land in the Southern Hemisphere, for that matter. It has been devastated by drought, so I can really tell honourable members what a drought is. People are welcome to come out there and I will explain to anyone who wants to find out what the meaning of a drought is. It is there for all to see. Governments should recognise drought under the national disaster aid packages.

Another area I would have liked to see the Government address in this Budget is the area of zone rebates. Zone rebates are a form of compensation for uncongenial climatic conditions, isolation and high costs of living. The Government has introduced, as part of the Budget package, a better cities program. What about a little bit of consideration for the people who live in the outback, in the remote parts of Australia--in the far flung parts of my electorate, for example?

Let us compare the rebates people are receiving in Cunnamulla with those being received by people in Darwin. I do not say that people should not be receiving a zone rebate for living in Darwin. A single person there will receive a rebate of $270. Darwin is a city, the capital city of the Territory; it is located on an international air route and a domestic air route where each day many planes land. A single person in Cunnamulla, in the far south-west of Queensland, in my electorate, will receive a rebate of $45 per year. It is worthless; it means nothing. There is a huge inequity. For a married person who lives in Darwin the rebate is $1,247. A married person with two children who lives in Cunnamulla receives a rebate of $435. There is a huge inequity there.

I believe that is an area that the Government must urgently look at if it wants to avoid a further drift to the cities, with resultant overcrowding. I believe the Government certainly recognises this by the fact that it has brought in the package of $800m for the better cities program. I ask the Minister to consider the inequities that exist and try to address them; we will keep some people in rural Australia if the zone rebates really reflect some of the costs and burdens that people suffer living out there.

But there is a further disincentive which I believe this Government should address. It is a tax on production which I believe is quite unfair. Certainly, there is a diesel fuel rebate which applies to diesel machinery used in the area of mining or agriculture. But what is the difference between a diesel driven machine and a petrol driven machine? Why can someone who has a petrol driven machine not receive the same rebate as the person who owns a diesel driven machine?

Another inequity--and it is another tax which I believe is a tax on production--is avgas. Out in rural Australia, in many parts of my electorate, the aeroplane and helicopter are the means of mustering livestock. Properties use these forms of mustering almost exclusively. Yet when owners fuel these machines they have to pay fuel excise on the avgas they use. A typical example would be a cattle property in central Queensland, which would pay something like $700 per year in fuel excise on the avgas it consumes. That is an anomaly which I believe needs addressing, and I would have liked to have seen it addressed in this year's Budget.

My time is fast running out, but let me say that this Budget, which has been termed a Budget `towards a fairer Australia', really turns out to be a joke. Do the unemployed think this Budget will produce a fairer Australia? Do families think this Budget will produce a fairer Australia? (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hall Mr R.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —-This is the second to last Budget that this Government or any Labor government will for a very long time deliver in the national Parliament. The Minister for Land Transport (Mr Robert Brown) is the lone representative of the Government sitting on the Government benches; I understand that his own members are tired of supporting the Budget, because they have given up. They have dropped out of the lists, and well they might. As I look at the Minister representing the Labor Party in office in this national Parliament, I think of the retinue of State governments around Australia which, of course, are part of his organisation.

SPEECH.PARA: This Government took office in 1983. It went through the expensive 1980s, getting into surplus Budgets and coming the full cycle with this Budget with a deficit of something over $4 billion. We see it following the same dismal path--though not to the same degree--as the State governments in the southern half of Australia. Let the Minister cast his mind for a minute to the first State Government that fell over--Victoria. Victoria is still in the depths of despair as its debt ridden State Administration unravels further deprivations on the taxpayer in that State.

The royal commission in Western Australia is still at the height of its performance, bringing out day after day the defaults of the Western Australian Labor Party Government. We find enormous debts have been incurred as a result of State expenditure, with the Government paying over $300m for an empty paddock for the vision--the failed vision, the vision that never really got off the drawing boards--of a refinery. I turn to my own State of South Australia, the State we thought would escape these marauding Labor Party administrations. We find $2.3 billion of South Australian taxpayers' money has gone into the sinkhole of the failed State Bank.

This Government is part of all this. The Opposition has looked at this Budget, but other people have looked at it too. The Parliamentary Library has prepared a compendium of reports written by the various notable reporters and newspapers of Australia soon after the Budget was brought down in this House. I must say that Mr Alan Ramsay in the Sydney Morning Herald was quite colourful in his description. He said, simply, to begin with:
This is a dreadful Budget.
He went on to say:
It's really the Bob Howe Budget.

The other gem that was included in his writing was that he really thought it was a `stop Keating Budget' or a `save Bob Budget'. Everything was subordinate--the welfare of Australians was subordinate to the survival of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). It is pretty colourful stuff, but I think those of us who sit here and watch the Parliament from day to day and see the low standard of administration by the Government would agree wholeheartedly with it. In the Sydney Morning Herald of 21 August, Mr Max Walsh said:
This really is a bad Budget--dodgy, pork barrelling, and full of rubbery figures.
In the Australian Financial Review, the headline simply stated, `Why the economy went off the rails'. The Australian article was headed,`Levy a hidden trap in magic pudding', and said:
Paul Keating always had a belief in magic puddings and it seems that the legacy he left to John Kerin in yesterday's Budget was one of these.

And so it goes on. One can find these quotes which convey the thoughts and appreciation of the Budget as seen by some of Australia's leading commentators. It is true that the newspapers can carry in more simple terms to the public the complexities of the Budget documents. They are indeed complex, as they have to be, as they involve the financial transactions of the national Government. But what is not complex to the community is the hurt that is being felt right across Australia. It is not a complex thing for the people in the street to know that their businesses are failing and they cannot see signs of recovery or the light at the end of this dark business tunnel.

Employment is contracting and unemployment has risen far beyond that level of consistently unemployed who comprise the first 3 or 4 per cent of the figures. All of us today know highly qualified people who simply have no openings in their profession from which they can earn a living.

In a street pretty close to me I had a young man who was sleeping in a motor car night after night in the same spot. One of the neighbours became worried about what he was up to. They phoned the local police station and were told, `Well, he has got to sleep somewhere; he is probably one of the 1,200 people sleeping in motor cars around Adelaide tonight'. This is the sort of economy, with hardship and heartbreak, that this Government is presiding over.

This Government has failed. It failed to recognise the precarious position of the Australian economy. It kept its interest rates too high for too long and forced Australians to the breaking point. It failed to link the consistently low commodity prices for Australia's primary and mining industries with the weaknesses in our economy of low productivity, high inflation and the inefficient structures that supported industry and commerce.

It is rather laughable, but this Government now makes much of its intention to improve the efficiency of Australian rail services. How long has this Government been in office? Seven years! Seven years too long, but it has suddenly discovered the inefficiencies in the Australian rail system. Anyone who has read the history of the Australian rail system would know that in the 1970s the South Australian Government sold the South Australian railways to the Federal Government. It is about the one policy decision of the Dunstan Government that I approved of because it put the union dominated, State owned railway system under the control of a national administration. It is a great compliment to Australian National that it has been able to do what it has in South Australia, creating the most efficient rail service in this nation.

We can go back to the mid-1970s. Why did it take this Government so long, with all its talk of improving the infrastructure of Australia, to discover the simple truth that it had to take Australia's railways away from union domination? It has not done it yet. It speaks of intention but it has not yet done it.

This Government began to fail badly in the middle 1980s--the expansive 1980s--when it ran hand in hand, often with its mates, in the expanding financial scene in Australia. I will never forget the times in the old House when Ministers of the Hawke Government were actively campaigning for and assisting Robert Holmes a Court in his attempt to take over the Broken Hill Pty Co. Ltd. What a tragedy it would have been for Australia if that takeover had succeeded, with that company broken into many pieces and dispersed to ownership around the world. Yet these Minsters were actively meeting with him and encouraging him in that takeover.

Of course, we found out later that when the Holmes a Court companies failed because of their overexpensive, rather stupid--as we now know--approach to borrowing all that it needed to buy enterprises, Prime Minister Hawke's mates in the Western Australian Labor Government forked out hundreds of millions of dollars to help stabilise and save Robert Holmes a Court's companies from collapse. It purchased, via State Government instrumentalities, hundreds of millions of dollars of shares that he owned in BHP and property in the central business district of Perth.

It was an utter disgrace. While it ran and continued to expand, this Government was willing to go on with him. It openly encouraged the very behaviour that has brought Australia to this deep contraction in its economic performance. As a nation, we face a great deal of shoal water ahead of us. It is a fact that the Labor States of Australia ran hardest of all, as I have already mentioned.

There is a great deal of desecration and economic litter across the southern half of Australia as three State governments stagger on to defeat at the next elections, but the people in those States are staggering even more under their failed economic management. My own State is in a very deep hole in relation to its economic progress. The Premier is able to look at the State Bank and say that it lost $2.3m. He will take that money out of taxpayers' funds and put the State in debt. That will put the children of the State in debt for the rest of their lives, paying off the debt of a bank which now has the audacity to send a circular to members of parliament to say that next year it will make a modest profit. What a twisting of the truth in the short term that is.

The result is, of course, that the State governments of Australia are in a desperate plight and they cannot offer the services which are needed by their communities. They are cutting services. They cannot support new enterprise. It is one of the great tragedies of their administrations that they are no longer in possession of any funds to provide seed funds for new enterprises which States have, by and large, often done well in the past. They are instituting regimes of high taxation and there is a distinct lack of confidence in their economic performances.

When we look at this national Government we find in its recent references to the overseas trade imbalance--the enormous debt that Australia has built up under this Government's administration--that it is already talking of stabilising the foreign debt. In fact, advisers to the Prime Minister in papers published last year indicated that their view--and this is the advice tendered to the Prime Minister by his own advisers--was that the overseas debt of Australia would be stabilised only when it was increasing at 2 1/2 per cent of GDP per annum. Yet now that it has got down to 4 per cent from over 6 per cent, this Government talks in terms of the debt being stabilised. What utter nonsense. It has got only half way, in the sense of the advice tendered to this Government by its own advisers.

As I have said, we look forward to the fact that this is the second to last Budget of this Labor Government and the second to last Budget of any Labor government in this Parliament for a very long time to come, because this Labor Government will be judged, and there is no doubt what that judgment will be.

Before I sit down I want to mention briefly a facility in my own State called Adelaide Radio. It is run by OTC and the funds to support it are provided by the Australian Maritime Safety Authority. It has run for a long time on the basis of providing safety and communications--distress frequencies--to ships and boats at sea. Because the Commonwealth sees its responsibilities--and, in fact, its international responsibilities are only these--to be to provide frequencies for large vessels, and because new technical developments will allow the authorities to provide safety frequencies for large vessels from far fewer locations in Australia, it has decided to cut the number of stations around the coastline. The initial plan was to leave stations only at Darwin, Perth, Sydney and Townsville, cutting out Melbourne and Adelaide, and rely on the new technical efficiency to serve larger vessels.

This will leave, as far as Adelaide is concerned, a huge gap in reliable, safety radio frequencies for small craft which, of course, do not have the expensive and modern technological equipment that larger vessels have. The small boats generally relied on the lower band of frequencies in the HF band. I am told--I am not an expert myself--that this provides relatively low frequency communication within the high frequency band over about 200 nautical miles. The transmission is by ground effect whereas, of course, moving to the high frequencies it is by skip effect off the ionosphere. The reliable frequency for boats within this 200-mile limit is certainly within the lower frequencies, which will no longer be provided because the stations will not be there.

Tasmania reacted very strongly and, because of the strength of that reaction and good representation from the Tasmanian Government, the Federal Government through its authorities decided to retain Melbourne Radio. That does not serve all that Tasmania requires but it is a great help. It still leaves South Australia out on a limb as far as the range of the lower frequencies within the HF band is concerned.

It has caused a great deal of anguish among boat owners who operate within the Gulf of St Vincent and Spencer Gulf and around Kangaroo Island and further distances both sides on the South Australian coast. An Adelaide Radio task force has been formed and has written to the Premier setting this out clearly. Officials from the Maritime Safety Authority have attended meetings in Adelaide to explain the position and some little progress has been made in the sense that the meetings will provide a basis for some testings to be made over the next few months to really set out, in a technical sense, how deficient this procedure may be.

I must say that I find it ironic that if Adelaide is not maintained it will be the only capital without this sort of service. We have an expanding area of use of the sea. All Australian coasts and ports have, of course. It is one of the facts of life as we go along that more and more people use the sea and more and more vessels venture further from their ports. We see new marinas and a whole host of new clubs generally making greater use of the sea for recreational as well as industrial purposes. The people who have shown interest in South Australia include not only the pleasure boat owners through the various clubs but also the fishing industry through its associations, the rescue organisations and the commercial interests in cruise ships such as the Falie and the One and All.

When the Minister for Marine and Harbours in South Australia has been approached on this matter, he has made sympathetic noises but I must say that his approach to the Federal Government has been almost negligible in putting a case for safety at sea in South Australia. I wanted to mention in these remarks on the Budget my support for the retention of Adelaide Radio and the fact that we will need a continued safety frequency which is available to small craft in the waters of South Australia without having to spend many thousands of dollars on equipment which would overcome that problem. I believe that South Australia should not be left as the one State capital without this lower frequency distress safety factor.
I take pleasure in speaking to this Budget and, as I have said, I look forward to the tests that the Government will meet on it and the next and last Budget it will deliver next year.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford Mr F.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —-As earlier speakers have indicated, we will not oppose the Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1991- 92. That does not mean that we agree with its policy direction. In fact, like most commentators, we dispute its aims. I want to discuss some basic issues which received almost no attention in this widely condemned Budget. It does not mean that we agree with the spending priorities. It does not mean that we agree with the tax collection methods. It does not mean that we agree with the rates of taxes levied against the community.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to make a few comments on the tax system itself. The first is on its unnecessary complexity. Australia has thousands and thousands of pages of quite complex legislation. While this deplorable situation has been a bonanza for lawyers, it will ultimately contribute to the nation's impoverishment.

The tax Act is now little more than a dead hand on our business community. A whole industry has developed to interpret this legislation and help people comply with taxation requirements. If this industry promoted business, not placed a dead hand on business, the growth in GDP would be enormous.

There is another aspect of Australia's taxation system which is quite sinister and will forever hold the nation in its backward condition. It relates to what I call pre-profit taxes. Pre-profit taxes are built into each and every service and every article, but they are not shown in the cost to the customer. These taxes are insidious, yet governments, both State and Federal, continue to expand in size, number and complexity, subsidised by the citizens they purport to represent.

Let us look at a few examples of pre-profit taxes. These are the Federal taxes and include wholesale sales tax, fringe benefits tax, the Medicare levy, occupational superannuation, the training levy and financial institutions duty. Add to them the States' pre-profit taxes--payroll tax, also financial institutions duty, taxes on the utilities that supply gas and electricity and the cost of licences and permits--and we find that all of them add up to something like 30 per cent of the cost of any service or manufactured article in Australia. What a millstone when companies have to compete internationally! If we could eliminate all or just some of these insidious taxes, our nation would become so much more competitive. This is what makes the goods and services tax so attractive; it can replace a whole lot of them. The goods and services tax was attractive to the Hawke Government in 1985, and it is still attractive to the coalition as part of our overall taxation reform.

There are two primary problems in this country--the level of overseas debt and the queue of unemployed which would stretch from Melbourne to Sydney. Does this Bill address these problems in any way? Of course not! There is support for the unemployed, but there is not one item that will promote business so that genuine employment opportunities will follow.

It is just over five years since the honourable member for Blaxland (Mr Keating), the man who once imagined himself to be the world's greatest Treasurer, announced that this country was in grave danger of joining the ranks of those unhappy nations the banana republics of South America and central America. At the time much was made of this warning. Indeed, in the hearts and minds of many Australians, the ex-Treasurer's words sounded an alarm similar to the impact of Thomas Jefferson's `Firebell in the Night' address, which concluded with the dire prediction that the institution of slavery would ultimately threaten the very existence of the United States.

Like so many political leaders of the period leading up to the outbreak of the Civil War, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and his former Treasurer have completely failed to deal with any of the fundamental problems that continue to confront the country. The tragedy of the last five years is the tragedy of lost opportunity and the absolute failure of leadership on the part of this Government.

Australia's gross domestic debt now stands at $165 billion. Servicing this debt costs 20c in every dollar of export income earned. I do not believe that the people of this nation want to see it reduced to banana republicanism. They do not want to live in a country that has lost control of its future. I believe they want to live in a country where they are free to make their own decisions about where they live, where their children go to school, which organisations they join or do not join and how they organise their working lives. Nor do they want to live in a country where Nanny State tells them what is good for them, directs their lives and restricts their freedoms, and, as Nanny State so often does, punishes them when they do not behave as Nanny State decrees they must.

There is no doubt that a major contributor to the sorry condition of the Australian economy is the abysmal state of industrial relations and the ball and chain of the Higgins legacies of the early part of this century. How can a government which claims such great concern for the ordinary working people of this country exhibit such a contempt for those whom it takes for granted as its natural constituents? The answer is, of course, that the pampered middle class trendoids who captured the Australian Labor Party in the 1960s and 1970s and now claim it as their own could not care less about the plight of the unemployed, the farmers or the small business people groaning under the weight of a burdensome state.

Australia's archaic and inefficient system of industrial relations must surely stand as one of the greatest contributors to our growing inability to compete on international markets. Horrendous overseas debt and uncontrolled spending just add to this. What this country needed in 1986, and what it needs now, is a new approach to the way we work and how we are rewarded for our labours. We do not need more legislation, we do not need more rules and we do not need more Fabian inspired government imposts on hapless employers. Those who have been brought up in the Henry Bournes Higgins fairyland of just prices, comparative wage justice and the explicit preference for bankruptcy or voluntary liquidation rather than market-based wages continue to refuse, just as Higgins refused, to accept the realities of a world where the law of supply and demand holds sway.

Much can be learnt from looking at the Higgins era, when realities were ignored. The Higgins era in Australia began in the early days of the Federation with the now defunct Sunshine Harvester Company. In applying for a tariff protection under a new Commonwealth Act, H.V. McKay's Sunshine Harvester Works had to obtain a certificate from Higgins's Arbitration Court that the wages paid in the Sunshine plant were fair and reasonable. To be given the opportunity of deciding what was fair and reasonable was pure joy for Higgins. He summoned the housewives of Sunshine and required them to provide him with details of their household budgets. In hindsight, it is most regrettable that they did not tell this nosy social engineer to mind his own business or, in the words of Voltaire, to go and cultivate his own garden.

Instead we read in the `new province for law and order' of the Sunshine housewives' weekly shopping list for 1906, which, when added to Higgins's own ideas of what was required for the working man's extramural expenses, totalled 42 shillings. Precisely how a judge of his status and background could determine the extramural expenses of a working man remains a shrouded mystery. Yet his findings ultimately resulted in a mandatory increase in wages for unskilled labour of over 20 per cent. At that time Australia's pound was tied to the gold standard and inflation was zero, or even negative. It took the breaking of the nexus to gold and the inflation of the Great War to reduce the level of unemployment amongst the unskilled to the level which prevailed prior to the catastrophic Harvester judgment of 1907.

The legacy of eight decades of labour market regulation and centralised wage fixing, coupled with increased power of the trade union movement and its quest for monopoly rents, has resulted in the gradual impoverishment of this country and its citizens. In the cloistered world of the labour market regulators, however, the notion of competition and the suggestion that employers and employees might actually be capable of sorting out their own affairs, strikes at the very heart of the system of industrial relations in this country, not to mention the privilege enjoyed by those who have gained membership of that unashamedly elitist club, the IR club.

In these circumstances, it is very difficult, if not impossible, for people who have been conscientiously and painstakingly administering an extremely complex system of price controls--which is what the labour market regulators are doing, in effect--to admit that their activities are not merely pointless but positively harmful.
In his great work of Australia's economic history written in 1930, Edward Shann remarked:
The arbitration courts have been led on, pushed on and drawn into an increasingly elaborate rule over industry very widely defined.

Men may be expected to discover and brood over anomalies when benevolent justice may thus be moved to essay their correction. But industry and commerce are very complicated, and one may, in recent years, mark a certain weariness in the economic titans of the court.

Since the publication of Shann's words, the number of titans has continued to multiply greatly and the regulation of labour is spread over many people. The consequences of their decision making, however, are really understood only by those in export or import competing businesses. The egg and spoon race of the domestic economy is no yardstick of economic efficiencies. If business is to compete effectively in the international marketplace, the ball and chain of regulation must be removed. The first step in achieving this is the reform of industrial relations. This means enterprise bargaining, freedom of association, the right to establish new unions and the opening up of the labour market to those who have been excluded for so long.

While this incompetent Government fiddles at the edges of our problems, the people of Australia burn. As our society is engulfed by the worst recession since the Great Depression, the Prime Minister and his colleagues sit on their hands--the pathetic captives of the ACTU and the new class social engineers. We do not need more government regulation; we do not need more government spending; we need leadership and a new province for employment and prosperity.

Unemployment is a grave problem and should be addressed. We should not just be giving support to the unemployed, as this Budget does. On Monday the honourable member for Dobell (Mr Lee) made a quite pathetic attempt to criticise my appeal to the Government to introduce a moratorium on debt.

TALK.START.PARA: —-He did not convince anyone.

—-I thank the honourable member. Suggesting that such a moratorium means that people would no longer be able to use their credit cards or to borrow money is to trivialise something that has become one of the most serious issues facing this country. Obviously the honourable member has completely failed to comprehend my message; or perhaps he simply does not care that nearly a million Australians are unemployed.
—-That is more likely.

—-I think the honourable member is right. Perhaps he does not care that many of the nation's farmers are being forced off their land. Perhaps he does not care that the number of bankruptcies in the small business sector has reached record levels and is increasing. However, as the headline in today's Australian suggests, even the ACTU is concerned about the rising numbers of jobless. The ACTU knows unemployment is getting dramatically worse.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course it is getting worse. It is the consequence of multitudes of business failures. A cynic might say that it is not the least bit surprising that the Government's mates at the ACTU are attempting to assume the moral high ground and appear in the guise of deeply concerned advocates for the unemployed. Could it be that the ACTU would like to see these jobs in non-union enterprises? In reality, we all know that the crocodile tears of the ACTU are a front for a much more destructive agenda. Its main worry at the moment is the declining base of union membership.

As David Clark recently pointed out in the Australian Financial Review, less than a third of private sector workers are union members, and since 1986 only about 8 per cent of new employees in the private sector have joined unions. So where are most unionists in 1991? One does not need to be a Rhodes scholar to work out the answer--of course, they are in the public sector. And where, one might ask, do the ACTU mates want their 200,000 new jobs to be created? It is easy to guess--not on the farms or in the small business sector; certainly not. No, what Kelty and Co. want is a return to the good old days of pump priming and Keynesian solutions of leaf raking exercises and make work schemes, none of which will produce any wealth or any real jobs.

However, there can be no genuine increase in employment unless the nation's wealth creating sector is freed from unnecessary interference and allowed to get on with the job that it does best, which is creating jobs and prosperity. So again I ask the Government to introduce a moratorium on debt for farmers and small business people. Something must be done to halt the haemorrhaging of our wealth creating sector. In recent times the farmer and the small businessman has become an endangered species.
