Many are threatened with extermination, while others have already fallen victim to the onslaught of the recession we had to have, high interest rates, rapacious creditors and an over-regulated labour market, and a system which has completely failed to deal with the corporate crooks of the 1980s. Connell, Skase and Bondy still travel first class.

TALK.START.PARA: —-They are all Labor's mates.

—-The honourable member for Moore is right. But their hapless victims are relentlessly pursued by those same financial institutions which were only too willing to lend vast sums of customers' money to the phoney entrepreneurs of the 1980s. Unless appropriate action is taken now, there is no doubt that there will be an ever increasing number of bankruptcies, while the human tragedy of poverty and unemployment will continue to stand as a monument to the weakness of this Government.

SPEECH.PARA: Inevitably, the consequences of the current situation are continued and are undermining the living standards and the ability of Australia to compete on world markets. A thriving business sector is the lifeblood of our nation. It is our future. It is our children's future. Australia needs its mines, it needs its farms and it needs its businesses. If the Government is sincere in its desire to do something to help the unemployed, it will not resile from taking the hard decisions, nor will it be seduced by the superficial and self- interested solutions advanced by Kelty and his mates at the Swanston Street soviet.

In calling for a moratorium on debt, I am not supporting greater government interference in the economy, except to halt the tragic outcome of failed policies. Indeed, the policies of interference have contributed almost totally to this sorry state. The deliberate policies of high interest rates, the recession we had to have, the failure to deal with the nation's grossly over-regulated labour market and trade union immunity from common law have directly contributed to the problems of today.

Unemployment is already at about one million, costing some $10 billion a year to support. Instead of allowing the unemployment figure to reach two million--costing $20 billion--we should protect real jobs. I repeat my assertion: the Government acted to support unlisted property trusts; it should and must act to support a section of the economy five to 10 times bigger than unlisted property trusts. If action is not taken, two million unemployed in Australia is inevitable, as our business base is obliterated. At this point recovery would be all but impossible. With no business base to speak of, the possibilities for growth and expansion are limited to say the least. I hope my plea is not ignored. I appeal for immediate action.

Attention to micro-economic reform was abandoned back in 1906. Micro-economic reform is now well overdue; even the Budget considers it essential. I ask: where is it? Where are the results of the hundreds of millions of dollars spent on shipping and waterfront reforms? Farmers and small businessmen have been basically ignored.
Debate (on motion by Mr Tickner) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Mr Tickner) proposed:
That the House do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edwards Dr H.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Last Friday evening, after attending an early official function, my wife and I decided it was a good opportunity to relax at the cinema. In the Australian that day, in the section headed `Recommended films', on which we have been wont to rely as a guide to quality films, the first film mentioned was Thelma and Louise. It was described, inter alia, as `wildly entertaining', `feminist'--that did not faze us--with `some brilliantly photographed desert scenery'. The review concluded on the note: `A terrific film'. The classification was M, as it is for a wide range of films today.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to comment on this film in the context of the controversy over gun laws in the wake of the recent Strathfield Plaza shopping centre killings. A small handgun made its appearance early in the film, almost incidental to what was going on at that time--Thelma packing to go away for a fun weekend with her friend Louise. Before long the gun was used to shoot and kill a would-be rapist--a maybe justifiable homicide. Next, after some vivid shots of the loading, it was used to carry out an armed robbery--easy to do, no problems. And hear this: when asked how she managed it, the reply was, `You learn how to do it from the TV'.

The gun was again pulled on a traffic policeman who flagged them down for speeding. The policeman's own gun was added to the Thelma/Louise arsenal and shots were fired to blast his radio out of action; whereupon--with perhaps a touch of farce--the traffic policeman was locked in the boot of his car with the boot lid penetrated by a few further shots. The guns came into play again in an episode with a road tanker driver and his load of petrol, and so on.

The pair ended up committing a series of crimes--murder; armed robbery, possibly robberies; malicious damage, wilfully destroying, as the spectacular effect of handgun fire, a large fuel-carrying semitrailer; and more--for which long prison sentences or even the electric chair may have been the outcome. But of course there is not the slightest suggestion of that to the largely teenage audience. Even the suicide at the end was not presented, or thought of, as such--it was just a car ride to oblivion; a sort of chariot ride through the sky, fading out long before anything like a fatal impact took place.

What concerns me is the impact of this on impressionable minds. All this is presented as being easy; all in a day's work--perhaps, in the early stages, a somewhat frustrating, bitterly disappointing day's work. It was presented in a totally amoral way with the focus on a gun, and then guns, and the power so conferred by those guns.

Such movies--in the cinema, on video and on television--are sources of very powerful and stimulating images and messages; messages conveying an impression that violence is, at least, `okay' and, at best, `great' as a source of very high levels of excitement. The thrills are further related to the exercise of power; especially the ultimate form--the holding of the power of life and death over another person.

That brings me to an aspect I want to stress, that is, whereas for days after the Strathfield massacre the newspapers carried front page stories with headlines printed inches high suggesting that guns must be banned, it was hard to find anything in print or hear anything said about the violence which is so realistic these days--the graphic, stimulating, so readily available, depiction of violence, and especially the power of the gun, that we are confronted with daily.

As my colleague the honourable member for Macquarie (Mr Webster) said in this place the other day, this community--this country--is faced with a serious problem which is particularly threatening to the women and children of Australia. It is a problem distinct from, although undoubtedly exacerbated by, the unacceptably high level of unemployment and deprivation caused by the recession in this country. It is a serious problem which the country has barely begun to grapple with.

As the honourable member pointed out from the basis of long experience, while the majority of people may be little affected--and I have a great belief in the moral fibre of my fellow Australians--that still leaves many people in our community who have a relatively low level of control over impulses to violence, sexual assault and so on and it only takes the final stimulus of a video or such like to spark them off to commit a serious crime.

Our community has become a much more dangerous place and commonsense is enough to tell us that the impact and effects of violent videos, movies and publications are a major factor in the serious situation that confront us. No doubt, there must be merit in the film I described, but that only underlines the complexity of the issue. I join with my colleague in calling upon the men and women of Australia to rise up against this evil that strikes at the very heart of our society today and threatens a lesser and more dangerous society for our children to grow up in. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Catley Dr R.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I have been perplexed by the insistence of the Liberal Party of Australia that it will, on the twenty-fifth of this month, announce its plans for the consumption tax. I was further perplexed by the fact that so many honourable members opposite intend to pursue this course, despite the obvious unpopularity of such a tax and the resistance they have encountered at every party meeting in getting it through. So I took the opportunity to publish a small pamphlet on the subject, pointing out what is wrong with a consumption tax.

SPEECH.PARA: Among other things, in the pamphlet I puzzle on the question as to why those opposite should want to introduce such an unpopular tax in such a climate which will ensure their defeat at the next election. Self-immolation may have been quite popular in other circumstances, but in this circumstance it seems so irrational that a former academic like myself has had to undertake research to find out why they should bother to do this.

What do I find, Mr Deputy Speaker? I find that it is the case that many other rich countries have a consumption tax, but that Australia does not. However, we have a mix of indirect and direct taxes which are very similar to those of other OECD countries. Other arguments put forward include, for instance, the fact that a consumption tax will increase the nation's savings. I am very much in favour of improving the nation's savings and I am very happy to note that our superannuation scheme is producing precisely that effect. A consumption tax, however, will do nothing to improve the nation's savings. I note that the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) admitted as much on 13 April 1990 in the Sydney Morning Herald. He said that not only would it not increase the nation's savings; it would almost certainly reduce them. Those opposite also argue that it might reduce tax avoidance. It is interesting that they should argue this when they wish to reduce those very labour reforms which have already reduced tax avoidance--such as capital gains tax and the fringe benefits tax. In any case, the mere imposition of a consumption tax does not prevent the sale of goods and services at a discount when cash is tendered.

We also find the argument that a consumption tax will be easier to administer. This, again, is fallacious. The wholesale sales tax is not costly to administer and involves only 75,000 taxpayers. The consumption tax would involve just about everybody who undertakes the sale or purchase of goods or services in this country being a tax collection agency for the Commonwealth Government.

We also need to take into account the social justice implications of such a consumption tax. The effect of it would be, essentially, to reduce the costs of luxuries which are presently taxed at a rate higher than 15 per cent--which is the rate at which the Liberals sometimes say they will introduce a consumption tax. Of course, often they say it will be at 22 per cent--it is difficult to be sure until the twenty-fifth. The cost of the necessities of life, which are presently exempt from wholesale tax, would go up by a similar amount.

What would be the effect? We would have no way of compensating retirees who are living off their life savings for the reduction in the purchasing power of their savings that would result from this. For example, a 15 per cent consumption tax, with a big price rise of somewhere around 7 per cent, means a cut in the real value of the savings of superannuants and retirees who are living off their savings of 7 to 10 per cent--something they will never recover from.

All of this is well known in the community. Eric Risstrom, the national director of the Australian Taxpayers Association, said that the purchasing power of superannuation, life insurance policies and savings would be ripped away. He added that the coalition would not win the next Federal election if it vowed to introduce a consumption tax. Another impeccable source--the Australian Catholic Social Welfare Commission--on 15 February 1991 expressed the gravest doubts about the equity or efficiency of expanding indirect taxation. In particular, it noted that a broad-based consumption tax, such as a goods and services tax, would impose more taxes on the poor.

We need to ask ourselves, against the logic that I have just presented, why the honourable gentlemen opposite wish to introduce a consumption tax. None of the arguments they have put forward work. We are left with two possibilities: one is that they wish to reward their yuppie supporters in the sub-branches of the leafy glades of the rich suburbs of our major capital cities with a big boost in income and that was the only thing they could think up; the other much more significant factor is that they have a political novice as a leader who is a hairshirt free market economist who has committed himself and, therefore, his party to a consumption tax. Therefore, all those politicians who do not want to argue for it will have to argue for it at the next election and go down, self-immolating, in flames.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Taylor Mr W.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I am delighted to see that the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Tickner) is at the table because what I have to say falls very much into his portfolio. Over the last couple of weeks I have received a number of letters from concerned professional photographers in my electorate about restrictions imposed in Uluru National Park. I would like to quote from one of those letters. It states, in part:

SPEECH.PARA: As a member of the Australian Institute of Professional Photography I wish to protest most strongly at the draconian restrictions governing the taking of non-advertising photographs in the Uluru National Park which have been progressively introduced since the hand over of Land Titles to the Aboriginal people in 1985.

These restrictions have been implemented without any discussion whatsoever with the people they affect and without any inclusion in any Plan of Management document, the purpose of which is supposed to take into account input from the wider community before new rules and regulations are introduced.

The latest Draft Plan of Management (June 1991), did not include any written guidelines concerning landscape or editorial photography. It simply stated that all photography could be within the guidelines issued, without seeking any input from the public and photographers in general, and without any thought for the livelihood of professional photographers.

Whilst making it illegal for landscape and editorial photographers to photograph certain areas, these very same places are shown to the public (including Aboriginal people) in the Visitors Display Centre at Yulara. These photographs are enlarged to an enormous size for all to see and include images taken on top of Uluru. . . and until the middle of this year, the inside of the Olgas. These images have been on display since about 1984 when Yulara was opened.

The wider implications of these restrictions have obviously not been thought through. Once established as guidelines for Uluru, the same procedures will almost certainly be applied in Kakadu, and then other National Parks in Australia.

I am sure that you will agree that the restrictions place unacceptable restraints on the rights of individuals to appreciate and enjoy one of the most beautiful parts of Australia and also to help others to understand an area which is unique in global terms. The Olgas and Ayers Rock are a geological gift to the planet, and, as such, should be freely enjoyed by everyone.

I, and my associate photographers, believe that the great majority of both the Olgas and Ayers Rock should be made available to ALL photographers and also that it is most unfair that the religious views of a minority group can be forced onto a majority who do not necessarily share these same views.

In view of the above, I strongly urge you to do everything in your power to reverse these draconian regulations in order to create a fair and equitable situation for all concerned, and I look forward to a favourable reply.

I simply ask the Minister at the table to look into these matters and to advise the House and, hopefully, me of the rationale underlying these decisions. On the face of it, this letter and others highlight that some anomalies do indeed exist; they need to be addressed and, hopefully, corrected. I hope that the Minister will take these on board and pave the way for a more equitable outcome. On a separate subject, I cannot let the honourable member for Adelaide (Dr Catley) get away scot free on the question of a goods and services tax.

TALK.START.PARA: —-He is coming back to listen to you.

—-I notice that he is not here but, whilst he may talk about a goods and services tax, I take him back to what happened in June in Hobart. What happened in Hobart with the Labor Party and what was the honourable member talking about? He was talking about a wealth tax. He talks about the goods and services tax, but what about the suggestion of a wealth tax that has come from his side of the House?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Courtice Mr B.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —- Tonight I feel very sorry for the eight members of the Opposition on the other side of the House because they have been made the bunnies by the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) and the Leader of the National Party (Mr Tim Fischer). While they are sitting there trying to defend a goods and services tax--that is, a tax on food and clothes--and they do not know at what level it will be set, there is a hayseed from the Northern Territory, a CLP candidate, who does know the level of tax. He is one Arthur Palmer, who was interviewed today on radio. This young fellow said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . and I can assure you, and your listeners, that it will not be above 15 per cent and that's an assurance that I have directly from the Leader of the Opposition.
He stated further:
. . . I'm quite properly being briefed very extensively by both Peter Reith and Dr Hewson and also Tim Fischer, particularly Tim Fischer.

But the poor bunnies on the other side of the House who have to go out and wear this and tell their constituents how they will be better off by having a 15 per cent tax on all food, clothes and services do not know about it. One Arthur Palmer is obviously seen as a genius by the conservatives, because he has been given knowledge and information that no-one else on the other side of the House has. It just goes to show where the direction and continuity of those opposite is.

It is interesting to note that the National Party in particular is bitterly divided over the consumption tax, a tax that would force struggling farmers to the wall. It is ironic that people on the other side of the House get up and complain. Before I came into the House I did some quick sums. Bundaberg produces $135m worth of fruit and vegetables a year and honourable members opposite want to put a tax of 15 per cent, which is $20m, onto the backs of the farmers up there.
Mr McGauran interjecting--

TALK.START.PARA: —-I wonder whether the member for Groom (Mr Taylor) wants to go to the Lockyer Valley. I have seen him on television crying puppy dog tears. He can go and tell the farmers in the Lockyer Valley that he is going to slug them with a 15 per cent tax. When they get someone out to fix their motors, they will have to pay 15 per cent.
—- Order! Did I hear the honourable member for Gippsland use an unparliamentary term? Did he use the word `lie'?
—-Mr Deputy Speaker, you will understand the provocation extended by the honourable member.
—-If the honourable member used that word, he will have to withdraw without reservation.
—-A series of untruths totals a lie, as you would know, Mr Deputy Speaker, but I do withdraw in deference to you.
—-No, the honourable member will just withdraw.
—-I substitute the words `deliberate mistruth'. I withdraw the use of the word `lie'.

—-I would not expect anything else from the honourable member for Gippsland. One day I saw him stand up here in Parliament and support Pinochet, a bloke who was the most discredited person to run any country in the last 20 years.
—-Mr Deputy Speaker, I rise on a point of order. The honourable member seems to be making some sort of personal slur on me. That is a complete and utter lie.
—-It is not. It is in Hansard and the honourable member knows that full well. The honourable member made a 90-second statement on it.
—-Order! There is no point of order, but the member must withdraw that unparliamentary term.
—-I invite the honourable member to produce this Hansard, and at that time I will certainly withdraw the word `liar'.
—-The honourable member has to withdraw now.
—-I withdraw the actual word `lie' but suspend judgment as to his truthfulness.

—-Most of his former colleagues in Queensland are behind iron bars. I return to the real facts and the tax on food and clothing. I ask the honourable member for Groom to stand up in Toowoomba and the Lockyer Valley and tell the farmers that he is going to take 15 per cent out of their incomes, because that is what will happen. It will happen for one very simple reason that surely even honourable members opposite can understand. If a housewife has $100 to spend on fruit and vegetables, whether it be over a week, a month or six weeks, and the Opposition puts a 15 per cent tax on those items, that 15 per cent will not go back into the pockets of the farmers; it will go back into Consolidated Revenue.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition will put a tax on fruit, vegetables and meat, items which are not taxed at the present time. These items are the very foundation of the staple diet that Australians need to exist and for their kids to develop. People will have to pay 15 per cent from the very minute that a child is born. Opposition members should tell the people with money in the bank that their money will be devalued by 15 per cent, because all their savings will lose 15 per cent the day the Opposition introduces a consumption tax. They should tell the people who want to buy a home that 15 per cent will be put on top of the cost of housing. Opposition members have the audacity to stand up in this House and say that they care about families and working men and women. They do not. They are butlers for the rich. All they want to do is reduce the revenue that comes from those people who can best afford to pay in this country and put the burden onto the backs of the working men and women of this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —-And the farmers.
—-And the farmers and the pensioners. Honourable members opposite are only butlers for the rich; that is all they have been for the last 100 years and they will never change. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ronaldson Mr M.J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Mr Deputy Speaker, as you are well aware, I regularly address this House on the difficulties being faced by my constituents and the dramatic effects that the depression is having on my electorate. It gives me no joy to address two new issues that further threaten my region.

SPEECH.PARA: The first is the outrageous Budget decision of the Kirner Labor Government to close the Creswick hospital and convert it to a nursing home. The nursing home proposal comes after three years of discussions between the Health Department and the hospital regarding redevelopment plans that included an expanded, not reduced, role for the hospital. I believe that it is an absolute disgrace that hospital management, the Chief Executive Officer, Chris Ward, and the head of nursing, Maree Rodini, were not given any forewarning of the Budget decision. A meeting had been held some two or three weeks prior to the Budget and at no stage was there any mention of the proposal. The hospital board, the people of Creswick and I do not believe for one minute that the decision to close the hospital had not been made well prior to that meeting. In light of that, the pre-Budget maneuverings of the Health Department and the Minister are nothing short of deceitful and the Minister should immediately discontinue the closure plans.

By way of background, it is important for the House to know that the redevelopment proposal was initiated by the Department in 1988, involving a role conversion from the then 36 acute beds to 10 acute and 20 nursing home beds. The redevelopment was also intended to include the retention of midwifery, the development of the day care centre, a community health component and retention of outpatient care. At the end of 1989 the then Health Minister, Caroline Hogg, visited the hospital and gave an assurance that funding would be received in the 1990-91 Budget. The Chief Executive Officer, Mr Chris Ward, has stated that prior to the commencement of the project in 1988, until 1 p.m. on Tuesday 27 August of this year, the hospital board and the Creswick community had been led to believe by the Department and the Ministers that the project was top priority.

Some $182,282.15 has been spent on the redevelopment project and, on top of that, there has been an extraordinary amount of work put in by hospital board members, hospital staff and Health Department staff. The community of Creswick is justifiably outraged over these closure plans. The hospital board has decided to form an action subcommittee which consists of the president, Ernie Robinson, Maree Rodoni, Chris Ward and board members Colin Wrigley and Joan McMillan. At a public meeting in Creswick last Wednesday, nearly 1,000 people attended and showed their anger.

Of great concern to me is a statement attributed to the regional director of the Central Highlands Wimmera Region at the meeting that Victoria could no longer afford the standard of health care that it has been used to. The statement is a tragic indictment of the State Labor Government and it is not surprising that bumper stickers are now being displayed bearing the slogan `Creswick Hospital--Shame Labor, you lied'. I attended the first crisis meeting held after the Budget announcement and the hospital board, the hospital staff and the people of the Creswick region know that they have my total and ongoing support.

The other matter I wish to address in the time left to me this evening concerns the future of the Ballarat airport. The Government has been desperate to curtail ALOP funding, thereby throwing the sole responsibility for local airports back onto local government municipalities. I am the first to admit that some restructuring has been, and is, appropriate, but airports of regional importance such as those at Ballarat and Stawell have been lumped in with smaller airports whose regional importance is minimal.

The latest move by the Government in this campaign of airport responsibility divestiture is the recent move by the Civil Aviation Authority in relation to licences. The CAA has now proposed that in order to hold a licence, airports must be used regularly by aircraft seating more than 30 passengers or be engaged in scheduled or chartered public transport operations. The catch-22 here is that, without a licence, the Federal Government subsidy--in the case of the Ballarat airport, to the tune of $50,000 plus capital works--is at risk.

Councillor Barbara Hughes, the Shire President of the Shire of Ballarat, and Mr Rex Hollioake, the Shire Engineer, are naturally extremely concerned about the situation at the Ballarat airport. With only minimal usage by aeroplanes with a seating capacity of more than 30 and no charter service, the airport's future is grim under the proposed licensing conditions. Mr Hollioake has quite rightly described the proposal as another ploy to force the Ballarat airport out of its $50,000 subsidy.

Councillor Hughes and her council are enraged by the ploy and the dramatic effect that it will have on the airport's viability. This viability threat has significant implications for the region. A closure, for example, may deny air ambulance availability as well as aerial firefighting and aerial fire spotting capabilities. Both MAF-Air and Field Air have operated from the airport for some 30 years. Between them they employ 50 or 60 people. Regrettably, those jobs are very gravely at risk.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Mr L.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I am extremely pleased that the honourable member for Ballarat (Mr Ronaldson) talked about nursing homes because that is an area that will be severely affected by the stupid consumption tax which members of the Opposition are talking about introducing. This afternoon I rose to make a personal explanation to defend the rights of people in nursing homes and welfare agencies in my area. Both the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Tim Fischer) and the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran) found it necessary during the whole time that I was trying to make my personal explanation to interfere----
—-You were abusing Standing Orders.
—-He was doing it just as he is doing now, and just as he does every time someone tries to speak in this place.
—-You do not know your Standing Orders.

—-He has been doing it all day. He continues to do it all the time because he does not care. The National Party does not care about the aged. It does not care about the poor. It does not care about the children of our nation. All it cares about are the rich. They are the people who will benefit from a goods and services tax. We know that very well.

SPEECH.PARA: In a lot of cases, people who go into nursing homes these days purchase units. They will be hit by a 15 per cent consumption tax, at least, by honourable members opposite. They will not be able to stop them doing that. That is what honourable members opposite want to do. Honourable members will be taxing their entry fee; they will be taxing their toothbrushes--everything for aged people will be taxed. It is not just accommodation that will be taxed--there will be a charge on everything. What about the nursing services I was trying to protect in my comments today in this place--comments which the honourable member for Gippsland was trying to interject on all the time?

Let us not forget the Leader of the National Party. The good people in my electorate, who work extremely hard, will be severely disadvantaged by a goods and services tax. What about things such as Meals on Wheels? That is a service. A consumption tax is all about goods and services. Let us underline the services. Let us think about the services that will be affected by a tax imposed by honourable members opposite. It is $2.30 for a Meals on Wheels meal now. The only people that aged pensioners who live on their own see are Meals on Wheels people.

TALK.START.PARA: —-They want to put a consumption tax on Meals on Wheels.

—-That is what they want to do. In most cases they would probably tax their own grandparents. They would not care about them. This will be a tax from the cradle to the grave. It will be attacking people right across the board. Honourable members opposite know it too. The only sensible National Party members around the place are the Queensland Nationals. I do not know how the National Party got a breath of fresh air like that. Even the National Party's leaders in Queensland are having some reservations about the goods and services tax.
—-They are all in Boggo Road.

—-They are the ones still out of Boggo Road. But there will not be too many of them left after the next election either. Let us look at a $40,000 contribution for entry to nursing homes. There will be another $6,000 in tax. No trouble at all--$46,000 taken from an aged pensioner who has got to the stage of having to go into a nursing home. We would encourage these people to stay in their own homes by giving them as much help as we possibly can by providing services. In my electorate we have tremendous services. We have welfare agencies such as the Blue Nursing Service. They provide great services to our people. A goods and services tax will take those services out of the reach of the people who really need them.
—-What about all the unemployed in Ipswich?

—-The unemployed will be severely affected by honourable members opposite. Honourable members opposite want to take their payments away altogether. Then honourable members opposite want to attack our Skillshare program. Those services are included in the area we have been talking about today. These are all the services that honourable members opposite want to attack.
—-You could not lie straight in bed.

—-We will talk about who can lie straight in bed. We know clearly what the honourable member for Gippsland is about. He is all about the goods and services tax. It is all right for him because he was born with a silver spoon in his mouth. He does not have to worry about the people who really need the help. Honourable members opposite do not really care and they never have cared. That is typical of the National Party--and the Liberal Party runs along with it as well. They are trying to attack the people who can least afford it. A goods and services tax would be the biggest attack that we could ever have on the people who could least afford to pay. The sooner honourable members opposite realise what they are doing the better. Of course, the electorate will sort the matter out at the next election. We all know that. We will keep reminding the people all the way to the next election what a ruthless tax it is and what a ruthless group the Liberal- National Party people are. All they want to do is tax people from the cradle to the grave. They want to tax baby food. Even when people die they will still want to tax their funeral expenses--even the coffin, the whole lot. That might be all right for some people.
—-Even the wreath.

—-Even the wreath we might purchase for someone when they pass on. What a dreadful bunch of people honourable members opposite are to attack those people--the people who cannot afford it. (Time expired)

—-The motley crew opposite will have egg all over their faces and the wind taken out of their sails. When the details of our tax policy come down honourable members opposite will be running from here with their tails between their legs, simply because we are committed to a tax system in this country which is fair and equitable. Quite clearly in the years that honourable members opposite have been in government the tax system in this country has got out of control. We have pages and pages and reams and reams of tax legislation which really complicates the whole of the tax system. I put it to honourable members opposite that we are seeking to introduce into Australia a completely new tax system which will be fair and equitable.
—-How can you be trusted?

—-Honourable members opposite have been scaremongering and peddling misinformation for the last few months because they are running scared. The honourable member for Moreton (Mr Gibson) will not even be here after the next election. The honourable member for Bowman (Mr Sciacca) will not be here after the next election. Honourable members opposite are running scared on this issue simply because they know that this is the right decision to make for this country. If I take honourable members back to 1985 they will recall that both the Treasurer at the time, the honourable member for Blaxland (Mr Keating), and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) were running around this country saying that we should have a consumption tax. It was the right decision then, and it is the right decision now.
—-Who said that?

—-The honourable member cannot refute that. Honourable members opposite are embarrassed because we have taken the bit between our teeth. We have taken the initiative and we will introduce a tax system which will be fairer and which will advantage everybody in this country. People will not be worse off. People, in fact, will be better off under our new tax system. Let me tell honourable members, good things come to those who wait. If honourable members opposite will just be patient for a little longer, they will get the good news.
—- Order! It being 8 p.m., the debate is interrupted.
—-Mr Deputy Speaker, I require that the debate be extended.
—-The debate may continue until 8.10 p.m.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tickner The Hon R.E.

TALKER.NAME: Mr TICKNER
TALKER.ROLE: -Minister for Aboriginal Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Aboriginal Reconciliation)

TALK.START.PARA: —-I would like to take the opportunity to respond briefly to the matter raised by the honourable member for Groom (Mr Taylor). In doing so, I hope he will appreciate that in the short time available to me I can give only a preliminary response to the matters he has raised. These matters also fall within the portfolio of the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Mrs Kelly), and I will be seeking further information from her in relation to the matters raised by the honourable member.

SPEECH.PARA: I have received preliminary advice from the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission that the protocols for the taking of commercial photographs in the Uluru National Park were developed following extensive consultations between the National Parks and Wildlife Service, which operates the park, the Mutitjulu community, representing the traditional owners who live in the park, and the board of management, which has responsibility for managing the park. I understand that those protocols are not of recent origin but have been in place for some time. I think they date back to 1987. I understand that those protocols are now under review as part of the latest proposal for a new five-year plan of management of the park, as set down in the original lease-back agreement. I am aware also, from letters that I have received, that the Australian Institute of Professional Photography has been conducting what I think might be called a campaign to have these protocols altered, and that this campaign is particularly active in view of the fact that the new draft plan of management is being renegotiated. I am advised further that the introduction of the original prohibition was motivated, at least in part, by a concern among the Aboriginal community that photographs of certain places should not be seen by other Aboriginal people who have not gone through the level of tribal law that enables them to see those sites.

I will make a number of other brief comments in concluding my preliminary advice to the honourable member. First of all, I appreciate that these concerns of Aboriginal people are not readily understood by non-Aboriginal Australians. They are concerns based on tribal and spiritual beliefs which are very different from the spiritual beliefs held by non- Aboriginal Australians. I recognise that it is legitimate for the Institute of Professional Photography to make its concerns known to the Parliament and to the wider community.

The only additional comment I make is that obviously these are sensitive matters, and I only hope that, in drawing attention to concerns about the issues which are the subject matter of the campaign, the Institute will conduct itself in such a way so as not to diminish the respect that non-Aboriginal Australians ought to have for Aboriginal people. I hope that when honourable members raise these matters they can be dealt with in the most constructive manner possible. From what I heard of the remarks of the honourable member for Groom, I think that he couched his remarks in those terms. I will undertake to provide him with further information at the earliest available opportunity.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Anderson Mr J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Resources, upon notice, on 3 June 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Will a former staff member of the Department of Primary Industries and Energy, now employed by the consultants Ernst and Young, be involved in the inquiry into the Australian Quarantine Inspection Service (AQIS); if so, could the outcome of the inquiry be tainted or prejudiced by this involvement.
(2) Which meat establishments employ AQIS inspection staff and what is the (a) number of staff assigned to and (b) average staffing requirement of each of these establishments.
(3) What is the average number of (a) pigs, (b) sheep, (c) goats and (d) cattle inspected by the average AQIS inspector per day.
(4) Do any meat establishments require fewer inspectors than reside in the establishment's locality; if so, which establishments.
(5) Have any (a) producer organisations or (b) meat establishments expressed complete satisfaction with the current rate of inspection fees; if so, which organisations or establishments.

(6) Is he able to say whether two veterinary practitioners who have trained meat inspectors at Cowra, NSW, inspected the same volume of carcasses as would require 8 AQIS inspectors; if so, how is this possible.
(7) Is he able to say whether the administrative costs of quarantine inspection in the USA are borne by the government.

(8) Does the imposition of quarantine inspection charges on the Australian meat industry and producers place them at a competitive disadvantage on world markets; if so, why are the charges imposed on them.

(9) What (a) number of meat inspectors were employed, (b) total (i) salary and (ii) travel allowance was paid to them and (c) sum in inspection fees was recovered from the meat industry in (A) 1987-88, (B) 1988-89, (C) 1989-90 and (D) 1990-91.
(10) Does AQIS operate risk management techniques for inspection regimes other than those with respect to meat; if so, has AQIS considered operating those techniques for the inspection of meat.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Griffiths The Hon A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No former staff member of the Department of Primary Industries and Energy employed by Ernst and Young is involved in the independent consultancy which I have commissioned on AQIS' corporate form and management arrangements.

(2) AQIS provides inspectors on both full-time and part-time arrangements at export abattoirs, export boning rooms, domestic abattoirs and domestic type boning rooms cold stores and meat products establishments. For the week ended 11 June 1991 there were 311 of these establishments. Staffing levels and average staffing requirements vary from time to time according to seasonal and other variables etc.
(3) From 1 July 1990 to 17 May 1991, the total number of species processed in the categories nominated by the honourable member were:

To determine the average number of each species inspected per day by each inspector as requested by the honourable member, would entail a detailed examination of each shed, the type of species processed and the number of inspectors assigned to each shed. I am not persuaded that it would serve the public interest to devote the large staff resources necessary to undertake this task.

(4) Yes, there are occasions where meat establishments do require fewer inspectors than reside in the locality. This can occur as a result of fluctuations in throughput and seasonal differences. AQIS seeks to provide an effective and efficient service and relief staff are headquartered at some establishments to service those plants in that Region during times of authorised leave and during training of staff.
(5) AQIS has not solicited the views of particular organisations on the charging regime nor has it received any unsolicited expressions of complete satisfaction with the charging regime.

(6) AQIS has no information which would allow it to determine if the two veterinary officers who inspected carcasses at the Cowra abattoir on 16 April carried out full inspection procedures of the kind which AQIS inspectors are required to carry out by law.

(7) If the honourable member means by `quarantine inspection' the activity of meat inspection in the USA, that cost is met by the US administration except for overtime and non-core activities. Quarantine Inspection fees in the USA are currently borne by the government.

(8) Government inspection and certification of meat and meat products for export is undertaken to meet the requirements of importing countries for access to their markets. It is the Government's view that the beneficiary of meat inspection in the export area is the export meat industry and consequently it should bear the cost of this service. Australia is not alone in requiring industry to pay for inspection services. Both New Zealand and Argentina have full cost recovery regimes in place, while the European Community has from 1 January 1991, required member countries to charge for inspection services. Rather than being placed at a competitive disadvantage, Australian meat exporters are advantaged by having an efficient and internationally respected organisation undertaking meat inspection, thereby guaranteeing access to world markets.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Scott Mr J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs, upon notice, on 22 August 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: Is the Minister able to say whether the 13th World Congress of the International Organisation of Consumer Unions (IOCU) passed a motion in July 1991 opposing the use of food irradiation.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable Member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The 13th World Congress of the International Organisation of Consumer Unions (IOCU) in July 1991 considered the following motion:

`Irradiation as a method of reducing food borne disease has not yet been proved to be sufficiently safe, especially for long term use. It is yet to be demonstrated satisfactorily that irradiation would contribute significantly to the reduction of food borne diseases, to improvement in the world supply of foods, or to the economic benefit of exporting countries as claimed by the proponents of the process.

`There is currently no simple and economical way of detecting whether food has been irradiated and there can therefore be no guarantee that labelling requirements are being met, or would be properly observed. Irradiation has been used illegally as a means of treating contaminated food that was unsafe for human consumption and there are insufficient safeguards against its misuse, and the possibilities of re-irradiation.
`Irradiation is a costly process that would raise the cost of food and its extensive use would increase the risks of accidents at the plants and during any transportation of nuclear materials.'
In its resolution, the IOCU General Assembly:

REAFFIRMED its opposition to the use of irradiation and its commitment to a moratorium on the process until the outstanding safety questions are satisfactorily answered and the need for its use demonstrated;
CALLED on governments to involve consumer organisations and IOCU in all decisions about the proposed development and use of irradiation if they are not prepared to ban it;
URGED scientists, governments and the food industry to research more effective, safer and appropriate food preservation technologies; and
URGED governments of countries where the process is legal to review the use of the process, and monitor illegal use and infringements of labelling requirements.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hawker Mr D.P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Land Transport, upon notice, on 22 August 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) With the establishment of the National Rail Corporation, will steps be taken to ensure that the accounting system separates costs and revenue for the east-west corridor from those for the north- south corridor; if so, what steps.
(2) Will he ensure that the east-west corridor is not used to cross-subsidise the north-south corridor.

(3) Will mechanisms be implemented to ensure that the governments of New South Wales, Victoria, Western Australia and the Commonwealth do not interfere in the operation of the Corporation to allow cross-subsidisation between the corridors referred to in part (2); if so, what mechanisms.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The National Rail Corporation (NRC) will be incorporated under the Companies Code as a strictly commercial corporation at arms-length from government. It will prepare its accounts in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles. Operational and commercial matters such as accounting systems will be a matter for the commercial judgement of the Corporation.

(2) Operational matters such as investment decisions, sources of financing and the relative margins on various services, products and corridors will be commercial matters for the NRC Board and management to determine, in the same way as would any privately owned corporation established under the Companies Code.

(3) The relationship between the Governments who are shareholders of the NRC and the corporation is determined by the provisions of the Companies Code and the Articles of Association. In keeping with the commercial model adopted, the shareholders' role is limited to strategic oversight, through approval of the Corporate Plan, and does not extend to operational issues such as pricing. It is also worth noting in this context that Directors of the NRC will be required, under the Companies Code provisions, to act in the interests of all shareholders. The NRC also will be subject to the laws of the Commonwealth and relevant states, on the same basis as any privately owned company.
